17He said, “I wouldn’t do that. The one the cup was with will be my slave. The rest of you can go up to your father in peace.”	Gen 44:14-17

18Judah came up to him and said,

“May I say something to you? Don’t be mad; you’re equal to Pharaoh. 19You asked us if we had a father or brother. 20We told you we had an elderly father and a young brother that was born when our father was old. He’s the only one left from his mother, and his father loves him (a full brother of his is dead).”

21“Bring him down so I can see him.”

22“The boy can’t leave his father. His father would die.”

23“Unless he comes with you, you won’t see me again.”

24“We went up and told him what you said.

25“Later, he told us to come back and buy more food.

26“But we said, ‘We can’t. If our youngest brother’s not with us, we won’t be able to see the man.’

27“You know my wife had two sons. 28One of them went out and must have been torn to pieces by wild animals. I haven’t seen him since. 29If you take this one and something happens to him, you’ll send my gray hair down to Sheol in grief.” 	Gen 44:18-29

30-31“If I go back and he sees the boy’s not with us, he’ll die. His life is wrapped up in the boy’s life. We’ll send his gray hair down to Sheol in grief. 32I became a guarantee for the boy, I said I’d bear the blame permanently if I didn’t bring him back. 33Let me stay in his place so he can go with his half-brothers. 34How could I go up to my father if he’s not with me? I’d see how hard it would be on him.” 	Gen 44:30-34

Joseph Reveals Himself to His Brothers

45:1Joseph couldn’t control himself in front of everybody that was standing there. He cried out, “Everybody out!” Nobody was with him when he introduced himself to his brothers. 2He cried so loud the Egyptians heard it, and Pharaoh’s household heard about it. 3He told his brothers,

“I’m Joseph. Is my father still alive?”

They were so overwhelmed by his presence they couldn’t answer him.

4Then he said, “Come closer.”

“I’m Joseph that you sold into Egypt. 5Don’t grieve or be angry with yourselves. God sent me ahead of you to save you. 6The famine has been in the land for two years. There won’t be any plowing or harvesting for five more years. 7God sent me ahead to preserve you as a remnant here and keep you alive by a great rescue. 8It wasn’t so much you as God. He’s made me like a father to Pharaoh, manager over his household and ruler over Egypt. 9Hurry back and tell my father his son Joseph says, ‘God has made me lord over Egypt. Come down to me right away. 10You’ll live in the territory of Goshen near me—you, your children, grandchildren, flocks and herds, everything you own. 11I’ll take care of you there so your household and possessions won’t perish. The famine’s going to last five more years.’ 12You and my brother Benjamin can see I’m telling you this directly. 13Tell my father about my splendor in Egypt and everything you’ve seen. Hurry and bring him down here.”

14Then he embraced Benjamin and cried, and Benjamin cried and embraced Joseph. 15Joseph kissed his brothers and cried on them. Afterward they talked. 	Gen 45:1-15

16When Pharaoh’s household heard that Joseph’s brothers had come, they were happy. 17Pharaoh said,

“Tell them to load their animals and go to Canaan, 18get their father and households, and come to me. I’ll give them the best land in Egypt. They’ll eat off the rich land. 19Have them take wagons for their wives and little ones, and bring their father. 20Tell them not to worry about their personal belongings; they’ll have the best in Egypt.’”	Gen 45:16-20

21Joseph gave them wagons and supplies for their trip. 22He gave each of them a change of clothes, but he gave Benjamin 300 pieces of silver and 5 changes of clothes. 23He sent his father 10 donkeys loaded with the best things Egypt had to offer and 10 female donkeys loaded with grain, bread, and provisions for his father’s trip back. 24He sent them off, “Don’t quarrel on the trip.” 25They went up to Canaan 26and told their father, “Joseph’s still alive! He’s actually the ruler of Egypt!” He was stunned! I’ll go see him before I die.”  	          Gen 45:21-28

Joseph and the Famine in Egypt

13There wasn’t any food in the whole region because the famine was so severe. Egypt and Canaan were starving. 14Joseph collected all the money in Egypt and Canaan for the grain people bought, and brought it to Pharaoh’s house. 15When the money was gone in Egypt and Canaan, the Egyptians came to Joseph, “Give us food. Why should we die in front of you? Our money’s gone.” 16Joseph said, “Trade your livestock for food.” 17So they brought their livestock, and he gave them food in exchange for horses, flocks, herds, and donkeys that year.

18At the end of the year, they came and said,

“We won’t hide it from you that we’ve spent all our money, and the livestock belong to you. We don’t have anything left except our bodies and land. 19Why should we and our land die in front of you? Buy us and our land for food, and we and our land will be Pharaoh’s slaves. Give us seed so we can stay alive, and the land won’t be desolate.”	 Gen 47:13-19

20Joseph bought the land in Egypt for Pharaoh. Every Egyptian sold his field because the famine was so severe. The land became Pharaoh’s. 21He moved the people to the cities from all over Egypt. 22He didn’t buy the priests’ lands because they lived off their allotments from Pharaoh. 23Joseph told the people,

“I’ve bought you and your land for Pharaoh today. Here’s seed so you can sow the land. 24At harvest, give a fifth to Pharaoh, and four-fifths will be yours for planting and for feeding your household and little ones.”

25They said, “You’ve saved us! Be gracious to us, my lord, and we’ll be Pharaoh’s slaves.” 26Joseph made it a statute about land in Egypt that’s still in force: Pharaoh would have a fifth. The priests’ land was all that didn’t become Pharaoh’s.  	Gen 47:20-26

He swore to him.

The Israelites Oppressed

8In time, a new king came to power in Egypt who didn’t know Joseph. 9He told his people, “There are too many Israelites, and they’re too strong. 10Let’s deal with them wisely so, if there’s war, they won’t join our enemies and leave.” 11They appointed taskmasters and subjected the Israelites to hard labor. They built storage cities for Pharaoh: Pithom and Raamses. 12But the more they mistreated them, the more they multiplied and spread. The Egyptians were afraid of them [13] 14and made their lives miserable, making bricks and mortar and laboring in the fields. 	  Ex 1:8-14

15The king told the Hebrew midwives Shiphrah and Puah, 16“When you’re helping the Hebrew women on the birth stool, kill the boys.” 17But the midwives respected God and let them live. 18The king called them in and asked, “Why have you let the boys live?”

19“Hebrew women aren’t like Egyptian women. They deliver quickly before midwives can get there.” 20God was good to the midwives, and the people kept multiplying. 21Because the midwives respected God, he gave them families of their own. 22Pharaoh kept telling his people to throw the boys in the Nile but keep the girls.	Ex 1:15-22

The Birth of Moses

2:1A descendant from Levi married a woman from Levi, 2and she had a son. When she saw he was such a handsome baby, she hid him for three months. 3When she couldn’t hide him anymore, she got a papyrus reed basket and covered it with tar. She put him in it and set it in the reeds by the bank of the Nile. 4His sister stood a distance away to see what would happen to him. 5Pharaoh’s daughter came down to bathe at the Nile with her attendants. As she walked along the river, she saw the basket in the reeds and had her maid bring it to her.

6When she opened it, she saw the baby crying and felt sorry for him, “This is one of the Hebrews’ babies.”

7Then his sister asked her, “Do you want me to call a Hebrew nurse for you?”

8“Go ahead.”

She went and called his mother.

9Pharaoh’s daughter said, “Nurse him for me, and I’ll pay you.” 10He grew and she took him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses because she ‘pulled him out’ of the water.	Ex 2:1-10

Moses Flees from Egypt

11When Moses grew up, he went out to his relatives and looked at their hard labor. He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew. 12He looked around and saw nobody was there; he struck down the Egyptian and hid him in the sand. 13He went out the next day, and two Hebrews were fighting. He asked the one that started it, “Why are you hitting your friend?”

14“Who made you a ruler or judge over us? Are you going to kill me like you did that Egyptian?”

Moses was afraid, “Clearly, people know what I did.”

15When Pharaoh heard about it, he tried to execute Moses, but he fled to Midian.

Ex 2:11-15

He sat down by a well. 16The priest in Midian had seven daughters that came to draw water and fill the troughs for their father’s flock. 17Some other shepherds came and drove them away, but Moses got up and helped them and watered their flock. 18When they went to their father Reuel/Jethro, he asked,

“How did you get back so soon today?”

19“An Egyptian protected us from the shepherds. He even drew water for the flock.”

20“Where is he? Why did you leave him behind? Invite him to have something to eat.”

21Moses was willing to live with the man, and he gave him his daughter Zipporah. 22She had a son he named Gershom, “Because I’ve been a ‘foreigner’ in a foreign country.”	 Ex 2:16-22

23After a long time, that king of Egypt died. The Israelites groaned under the slavery. They cried out and their call for help went up to God. 24He heard their groaning and remembered his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. 25He took notice of them; he knew who they were.

Ex 2:23-25

Moses and the Burning Bush

3:1Moses was pasturing Jethro’s/Reuel’s flock and led it to the west side of the open country around Horeb/Sinai, the mountain of God. 2The angel of the LORD appeared to him in a blazing bush. Moses looked up and saw the bush on fire, but it didn’t burn up. 3He said, “I have to go over and see this curious thing. Why isn’t it burning up?” 4When the LORD saw him coming to look, he called from the bush,

“Moses!”

“Yes?”

5“Don’t come any closer. Take your sandals off. You’re standing on sacred ground. 6I’m the God of your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”

Moses hid his face, afraid to look at God.

7“I’ve seen my people’s suffering in Egypt and paid attention to their outcry because of the taskmasters. 8I’ve come down to deliver them and bring them out to a good land with lots of room, a land flowing with milk and honey, the territory of the Canaanite, Hittite, Amorite, Perizzite, Hivite, and Jebusite. 9I’ve seen how the Egyptians are oppressing them. 10Go; I’ll send you to Pharaoh so you can bring my people out of Egypt.”

11“Why me?”

12“I’ll be with you. This will be the sign that I’ve sent you: when you’ve brought them out, you’ll worship me at this mountain.” 	Ex 3:1-12

13Moses said, “So I’m going to the Israelites to say their ancestors’ God has sent me. What if they ask me what your name is? What will I tell them?”

14“I AM WHO I AM. Tell them, ‘I AM sent me, 15Yahveh God of your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’ That’s my name forever, the name all generations will remember me by. 16Get the elders in Israel together and tell them that Yahveh, your ancestors’ God, appeared to you and said, ‘I’m concerned about youpl and what they’re doing to you in Egypt. 17I’ll take you away from the sufferings to the territory of the Canaanite, Hittite, Amorite, Perizzite, Hivite, and Jebusite, a land flowing with milk and honey.’ 18They’ll listen.

“Go to the king of Egypt with the elders and say, ‘The LORD God of the Hebrews has met with us. Let us go a three-day journey into the open country and sacrifice to him.’ 19He won’t let you go unless he’s forced to. 20I’ll strike Egypt with my miracles. Then he’ll let you go. 21I’ll make the Egyptians favorable to you so when you leave, you won’t leave empty-handed. 22Every woman needs to ask her neighbor and the woman that lives in her house, to give her silver and gold items, and articles of clothing. Put them on your sons and daughters. That’s how you’ll ‘plunder’ the Egyptians.” 	Ex 3:13-22

Signs for Moses

4:1Moses answered, “What if they don’t believe me, ‘The LORD hasn’t really appeared to you!’?”

2“What’s in your hand?”

“A staff.”

3“Throw it on the ground.”

He threw it on the ground, and it became a snake. Moses jumped back.

4But the LORD said, “Grab its tail.” He caught it, and it turned back into a staff in his hand. 5“They’ll believe that the LORD God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob has appeared to you. 6Put your hand into your chest.” He did; when he took it out, it was leprous like snow. 7“Put it in again.” He did, and it became like the rest of him.

8“If the first sign doesn’t convince them, the second may. 9If neither one does, dip some water out of the Nile and pour it on dry ground. It’ll become blood.”	Ex 4:1-9

10Moses said, “Lord, I’ve never been good with words before, or lately since you’ve spoken to me. I stammer and stutter.”

11“Who made people’s tongues? Who makes people mute or deaf, seeing or blind? Isn’t it me, the LORD? 12Go on; I’ll be with your mouth and tell you what to say.”

13“Lord, send the message by whoever else you want to.”

14The LORD’s anger flared at Moses,

“Don’t you have a brother, Aaron the Levite? He speaks fluently. Besides, he’s coming out to meet you; he’ll be glad to see you. 15Give him my message. I’ll be with you and him and tell you what to do. 16He’ll speak to the people for you. He’ll be your mouth, and you’ll be like God to him. 17Take this staff and perform the signs with it.”	Ex 4:10-17

Moses Returns to Egypt

18Moses went back to Jethro/Reuel and said, “Let me go so I can go to my relatives in Egypt and see if they’re still alive.”

“Have a safe trip.”

19The LORD told Moses in Midian, “Go back to Egypt. The men that were trying to kill you are dead.”

20Moses put his wife and sons on a donkey and left with God’s staff.

21The LORD told him,

“When you get to Egypt, perform the wonders for Pharaoh that I’ve made you able to do, but I’ll harden his heart so he won’t let the people go. 22Then tell him that the LORD says, ‘Israel is my son, my firstborn. 23I’ve told you to let him go so he can serve me,’ but you’ve refused. So I’ll kill your son, your firstborn.’”

24At a place where they stayed on the way, the LORD met him and threatened to put him to death. 25Zipporah took a flint and cut off her son’s foreskin and threw it at Moses’ feet. She said, ‘You’re a bloody groom 26(because of the circumcision)!” So God let him alone.      Ex 4:18-26

27The LORD told Aaron, “Go meet Moses in the open country.” He met him at the mountain of God and kissed him. 28Moses told him what the LORD had sent him to do. 29They gathered Israel’s elders, 30and Aaron told them everything the LORD had told Moses. Moses performed the signs for the people, 31and they believed. When they heard the LORD cared about them and had seen their adversity, they bowed low in worship.	Ex 4:27-31

Moses and Aaron Speak to Pharaoh

5:1After that, Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh, “The LORD, Israel’s God, says to let his people go so they can celebrate a festival to him in the open country.”

2Pharaoh said, “Who is the LORD that I should obey him? I don’t know him. I’m not going to let them go.”

3They said,

“The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Let us go a three-day’s journey into open country to sacrifice to the LORD our God so he won’t fall on us with disease or sword.”

4The king said,

“Moses and Aaron, why are you trying to pull the people away from their work? Get back to work! 5Look at how many there are, and you want them to stop working!”

Making Bricks Without Straw

6That same day Pharaoh told the taskmasters and their foremen,

7“Don’t give them straw anymore to make bricks. They can gather their own straw! 8But don’t reduce their quota. They’re lazy, so they’re crying out, ‘Let us go sacrifice to our God.’ 9Give them more work so they won’t get false ideas in their heads.” 	Ex 5:1-9

10The taskmasters and their foremen went out to the people, “Pharaoh says he’s not going to give you straw anymore. 11Get your own wherever you can find it, but your quota will stay the same. 12The people scattered out across Egypt to gather stubble. 13The taskmasters pressed them, “Make your daily quota like when you had straw.” 14What’s more, Pharaoh’s taskmasters beat the Israelite foremen that they’d set over them, “Why haven’t you completed your required amount yesterday or today?”	     Ex 5:10-14

15The Israelite foremen came and appealed to Pharaoh, “Why are you treating us like this? 16We don’t have any straw, but they keep telling us to make bricks! They’re beating us, but it’s your own people’s fault.”

17“You’re lazy, very lazy. That’s why you want me to let you go sacrifice to the LORD. 18Get to work. You won’t be given any straw, but you still have to make your quotas.”

19The foremen saw they were in trouble. 20When they left him, they met Moses and Aaron, waiting for them. 21They said, “The LORD condemn you! You’ve made us offensive to Pharaoh and his officers! You’ve put a sword in their hand to kill us!” 	Ex 5:15-21

22Moses went back to the LORD and said,

“Why hurt the people? Why send me? 23Since I spoke to Pharaoh in your name, he’s been hurting them more. You haven’t delivered them at all.”

Promise of Deliverance

6:1The LORD told Moses,

“Now you’ll see what I’ll do to Pharaoh. He’ll have to let them go. I’ll make him send them out of his country. 2I’m Yahveh. 3I appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as ‘God Almighty’ [El-Shaddai]. I didn’t make myself known to them by my name ‘Yahveh.’ 4I made a covenant with them to give them Canaan, where they were living as nomads. 5I’ve heard the Israelites’ groaning because the Egyptians are holding them in slavery, and I’ve remembered my covenant. 6Tell the Israelites, ‘I’ll take you out from under Egyptian bondage and redeem you with power and great acts of judgment. 7I’ll take you to be my people and be your God. You’ll know I’m the LORD your God who brought you out from under the burdens the Egyptians put on you. 8I’ll take you to the land I swore to give Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’”

9Moses told the people, but they wouldn’t listen. They were beat down by the cruel slavery.

Ex 5:22-6:9

10The LORD said to Moses, 11“Go tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites leave his country.”

12But Moses said, “They haven’t listened to me. Why would Pharaoh listen to me? I’m not a good speaker.”

13The LORD gave Moses and Aaron a charge for Pharaoh and the people of Israel about getting the Israelites out of Egypt. 	Ex 6:10-13

14The Heads of Families

The sons of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn: Hanoch and Pallu, Hezron and Carmi

15The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohab, Jachin, Zohar—and Shaul, the son

of a Canaanite woman

16The sons of Levi according to their generations: Gershon, Kohath, Merari. Levi lived

137 years.

18The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 years.

20Amram married his father’s sister Jochebed. She had Aaron and

Moses. Amram lived 137 years.

22The sons of Uzziel: Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri

Nahshon. She had Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

Putiel. She had Phinehas.

26It was the same Aaron and Moses that the LORD told, “Take the Israelites out of Egypt according to their armies.” 27They were the ones that spoke to Pharaoh about taking them out.    	Ex 6:14-27

28That day the LORD told Moses, 29“I’m the LORD. Tell Pharaoh everything I tell you.”

30But Moses said, “I’m not a good speaker. How will he listen to me?”

Aaron’s Staff Becomes a Snake

7:1The LORD told him,

“I’m making you like God to him, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet. 2Say what I tell you, and Aaron will tell Pharaoh to let Israel leave his country. 3But I’ll harden his heart so I can multiply my signs and wonders. 4When he won’t listen to you, I’ll lay my hand on Egypt and take out my people with tremendous acts of judgment. 5The Egyptians will know I’m the LORD.”

6Moses and Aaron did what he said. 7Moses was 80 and Aaron was 83 when they spoke to Pharaoh.	Ex 6:28-7:7

8The LORD told Moses and Aaron, 9“When Pharaoh says to work a miracle, throw down your staff, and it’ll become a snake.” 10They went to Pharaoh. Aaron threw down his staff for him and his officers to see, and it became a snake. 11Pharaoh called the wise men and sorcerers, and the Egyptian magicians did the same thing with their magic. 12Each one threw down his staff, and it turned into a snake. But Aaron’s staff swallowed up theirs. 13Pharaoh’s heart was still hardened, and he wouldn’t listen.         	 Ex 7:8-13

The Plague of Blood

14The LORD told Moses,

“Pharaoh is stubborn and refuses to let the people go. 15In the morning, go meet him on the bank of the Nile. Take the staff that turned into a snake 16and say, ‘The LORD God of the Hebrews sent me, “Let my people go to serve me in the open country,” but you’ve ignored me. 17This is how you’ll know I’m the LORD: I’ll strike the water in the Nile with my staff, and it’ll turn to blood. 18The fish will die, and it’ll stink. The Egyptians won’t be able to drink it.”’”

19Then the LORD said to Moses,

“Have Aaron hold his staff out over the water in Egypt’s rivers, canals, pools, and reservoirs so it will turn to blood. There will be blood everywhere in Egypt, even in wood and stone containers.” 	Ex 7:14-19

20Moses and Aaron did that. He struck the water in the Nile with his staff for Pharaoh and his officers to see, and the water turned to blood. 21The fish in the Nile died, and it stunk. The Egyptians couldn’t drink it. There was blood everywhere in Egypt. 22But the Egyptian magicians did the same thing with their magic. Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he wouldn’t listen.

23Pharaoh returned to his palace without concerning himself with that either. 24The Egyptians dug along the Nile for water because they couldn’t drink the water in it. 25A week went by.	Ex 7:20-25

The Plague of Frogs

8:1The LORD said to Moses,

“Go tell Pharaoh the LORD says to let his people go so they can serve him. 2If you don’t, he’ll strike the whole country with frogs. 3The Nile will teem with them. They’ll come up into your house, your bedroom, your bed, your officials’ houses and on your people, in your ovens and kneading bowls. [4]’”

5Then the LORD said to Moses, “Tell Aaron to hold his staff out over the rivers, canals, and pools, and make frogs come up all over the ground.”  6Aaron held his hand out over the water, and frogs came up and covered the whole country. 7The magicians did the same thing with their magic, and made frogs come up on the ground everywhere in Egypt.   	 Ex 8:1-7

8Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron, “Ask the LORD to take the frogs away; I’ll let the people go sacrifice to him.”

9Moses asked, “When should I ask for the frogs to leave you and your houses, and be only in the Nile?”

10“Tomorrow.”

“All right; so you can know there’s nobody like the LORD our God, 11the frogs will leave everywhere except in the Nile.”

12Moses left Pharaoh and called out to the LORD about the frogs. 13The LORD did what he asked; the frogs died in the houses, courts, and fields. 14They piled them up and the country reeked. 15When Pharaoh saw relief, he hardened his heart and wouldn’t listen. 	Ex 8:8-15

The Plague of Gnats

16The LORD told Moses, “Tell Aaron to strike the dust on the ground with his staff so it becomes gnats everywhere in Egypt.” 17He struck it, and it became gnats everywhere in Egypt. 18The magicians tried with their magic to bring gnats, but they couldn’t. There were gnats on people and animals. 19The magicians told Pharaoh, “This is the finger of God.” But Pharaoh hardened his heart and wouldn’t listen.	Ex 8:16-19

The Plague of Flies

20The LORD told Moses,

“Get up early and present yourself to Pharaoh when he comes out to the water. Tell him the LORD says to let his people go so they can serve him. 21If you don’t, he’ll send swarms of flies on you, your officers, your people, and in your houses. They’ll infest the Egyptians’ houses and cover the ground. 22But he won’t send them on Goshen, where his people live. You’ll know he’s in the land. 23He’ll distinguish his people from yours tomorrow.’”

24The LORD did that. Huge swarms of insects were in Pharaoh’s palace and his officers’ houses. They covered the ground everywhere in Egypt. 25Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron, “Go sacrifice to your God inside the country.” 	Ex 8:20-25

26But Moses said, “That won’t work. We’d be sacrificing to the LORD our God what’s detestable to Egyptians. Wouldn’t they stone us? 27We have to go a three-day’s journey into the open country and sacrifice to the LORD like he said.”

28Pharaoh said, “I’ll let you go so you can sacrifice to the LORD your God in the countryside. But you can’t go very far. Pray for me.”

29Moses said, “I’m leaving; I’ll pray to the LORD that the swarms of insects will leave tomorrow. But you must not lie again and not let the people go sacrifice to him.”

30Moses left and prayed to the LORD, 31and he took the swarms away completely. 32But Pharaoh hardened his heart that time too and wouldn’t let the people go.	Ex 8:26-32

The Plague on Livestock

9:1The LORD told Moses,

“Go tell Pharaoh, ‘The LORD God of the Hebrews says to let his people go so they can serve him. 2If you keep holding them, 3he’ll bring a severe plague on your livestock in the pasture—horses, donkeys, camels, herds, and flocks. 4But he’ll distinguish Israel’s livestock from Egypt’s. Nothing will die that belongs to the Israelites.’”

5The LORD set a time, “I’ll do that in the country tomorrow.” 6The next day he did it. Livestock in Egypt died, but none of the Israelites’ livestock died. 7Pharaoh sent to find out that not a one of the Israelites’ livestock died, but he hardened his heart and wouldn’t let the people go.	Ex 9:1-7

The Plague of Boils

8The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

“Take handfuls of ashes out of a kiln and throw them up in the air in front of Pharaoh. 9They’ll become fine dust all over Egypt, and make boils break out with sores on people and animals everywhere in the country.”

10They took ashes out of a kiln and stood in front of Pharaoh. Moses threw them up in the air, and they made boils break out in sores on people and animals. 11The magicians couldn’t withstand Moses because of the boils. They came on the magicians as well as all the Egyptians. 12The LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he wouldn’t listen.       	Ex 9:8-12

The Plague of Hail

13The LORD told Moses,

“Get up early, present yourselves to Pharaoh and tell him, ‘The LORD God of the Hebrews says, “Let my people go so they can serve me. 14This time I’ll send my plagues on you, your officers, and your people so you can know there’s nobody on earth like me. 15If I’d struck you and your people with a deadly plague, you wouldn’t be here 16 to see my power and to make myself known all over the world. 17You still rise up against my people and won’t let them go. 18About this time tomorrow, I’ll send heavy hail beyond anything Egypt has ever had. 19Bring inside whatever livestock you have in the pasture. People and animals will die that are not inside.”’”

20Pharaoh’s officers that respected the LORD made their servants and livestock get under shelter. 21Those who didn’t pay attention left them out in the open. 	  Ex 9:13-21

22The LORD told Moses, “Hold your hand toward the sky so hail will fall on the people, animals, and plants out in the open everywhere in Egypt.” 23He pointed his staff at the sky, and the LORD sent thunder and hail, and lightning struck the ground. 24There was really severe hail and lightning flashing continually in the hail, like nothing that had ever happened in Egypt since it became a nation. 25The hail struck everything that was out in the open everywhere in Egypt—people, animals, plants in the field, and shattered the trees. 26Only in Goshen, where the Israelites lived, there wasn’t any hail.           	Ex 9:22-26

27Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron, “I’ve sinned this time. The LORD is right; my people and I are wrong. 28Pray to him. We’ve had enough of his thunder and hail. I’ll let you go for good.”

29Moses told him,

“As soon as I leave the city, I’ll spread out my hands to the LORD. The thunder and hail will stop, and you’ll know the world belongs to the LORD. 30But I’m sure you and your officers still won’t respect him.”

31(The hail ruined the flax and barley crops because the barley had headed out and the flax had budded. 32It didn’t ruin the wheat and spelt, which ripen later.) 33Moses left Pharaoh and the city and spread out his hands to the LORD. The thunder, hail, and rain quit pouring down. 34When Pharaoh saw it stop, he and his officers sinned again and hardened their hearts. 35He wouldn’t let the people go.	Ex 9:27-35

The Plague of Locusts

10:1Then the LORD told Moses,

“Go to Pharaoh; I’ve hardened his and his officers’ hearts so I can perform these signs among them 2and you can tell your sons and grandsons how I mocked the Egyptians with my signs, and so you can know I’m the LORD.”

3Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh,

“The LORD God of the Hebrews says, ‘How long will you refuse to humble yourself toward me? Let my people go so they can serve me. 4If you don’t, I’ll bring locusts to your realm tomorrow. 5They’ll cover the ground so thick you can’t see it. They’ll eat what the hail didn’t ruin, every tree that sprouts in your field. 6Your houses, your officers’ houses, every Egyptian’s house will be full of them—something your fathers and grandfathers have never seen.’”

He turned and left. 7Pharaoh’s officials said, “How long will that man hold us hostage? Let the men go so they can serve the LORD their God. Can’t you see that Egypt’s destroyed?”

8Pharaoh brought Moses and Aaron back, “Go serve the LORD your God! Who are going?”

9Moses said, “We’ll all go with our flocks and herds to hold a festival to the LORD.”

10-11Pharaoh said, “Oh, no! The LORD help you if I ever let you and your little ones go! Don’t tempt me; you have ulterior motives. The men among you can go serve the LORD. That’s what you’ve been asking for.”

Pharaoh drove them out. 	Ex 10:1-11

12Then the LORD told Moses, “Hold your hand out over Egypt; locusts will come up on the land and eat the plants the hail left.” 13He held his staff out over Egypt, and the LORD made an east wind blow all that day and night. In the morning, it brought the locusts, 14and they landed everywhere. There had never been so many, and there never would be again. 15They covered the ground till it was black. They ate every plant and fruit tree the hail had left. There wasn’t anything green on the trees or plants anywhere in Egypt.

16Pharaoh hurried and called for Moses and Aaron, “I’ve sinned against you and the LORD your God. 17Forgive me just this once and pray to him to remove this death from me.”

18Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the LORD. 19He shifted the wind to a strong west wind that blew the locusts into the Red Sea. Not a one was left in Egypt. 20But the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he wouldn’t let the people go. 	Ex 10:12-20

The Plague of Darkness

21Then he told Moses, “Lift your hand toward the sky; it’ll be so dark you can feel it.” 22Moses raised his hand toward the sky, and a dense darkness covered Egypt for three days. 23People couldn’t see each other, it was so dark. Nobody got up from where they were for three days, but the Israelites had light in their houses.

24Pharaoh called to Moses, “Go serve the LORD. Just leave your flocks and herds here. Even your little ones can go with you.”

25But Moses said,

“You need to let us have sacrifices and burnt offerings to the LORD our God.  26Our livestock has to go with us. Not a hoof will stay here. We’ll take some of them to serve the LORD. We don’t know what we’ll serve him with till we get there.”

27But the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he wouldn’t let them go. 28He told Moses, “Get out of here! I’m warning you, don’t ever see me again. The day you do you’ll die!”

29“You’re right. I’ll never see you again.”	Ex 10:21-29

Plague on the Firstborn

11:1The LORD told Moses,

“I’m going to bring one more plague on Pharaoh and Egypt. After that, he’ll let you go. When he does, he’ll drive you out completely. 2Tell each man and woman to ask their neighbors for silver and gold articles.”

3The LORD gave the Egyptians a favorable attitude toward the people. Furthermore, Pharaoh’s officers and the people in general respected Moses a lot.  	Ex 11:1-3

4Moses said, “The LORD says, ‘About midnight I’ll go out into Egypt, 5and all firstborn will die—the firstborn of Pharaoh on his throne, the firstborn of the slave girl behind the millstones, the firstborn among the livestock. 6There’ll be such an outcry everywhere in Egypt as has never been heard or will be. 7But among the Israelites, not even a dog will bark at people or animals. You’llsg see how the LORD distinguishes Israel from Egypt.

8‘Yoursg officials will come and bow to me and say, “Leave, you and your people.” Then I’ll leave.’”

He left Pharaoh really mad.

9The LORD told Moses, “Pharaoh won’t listen; so I’ll multiply my wonders in Egypt.” 10Moses and Aaron performed those wonders for him, but the LORD hardened his heart, and he wouldn’t let the people go.	 Ex 11:4-10

The Passover Instituted

12:1The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

2“This month will be the first month of your year. 3Tell the assembly of Israel that on the tenth of this month, each family is to take a lamb according to their families. 4If a family is too small for a lamb, that family and a nearby neighbor can take a lamb the size the number of people can eat. 5It needs to be an unblemished male a year old. Take it from the sheep or goats. 6Keep it till the fourteenth of the month.

“The whole community is to kill it in the evening. 7Put some of its blood on the doorposts and lintel of the house where you eat it. 8Eat the meat that same night, roasted with fire. Eat it with bitter herbs and bread without yeast. 9Don’t eat any of it raw or boiled. Roast the head, legs, and entrails. 10In the morning, burn what’s left over. 11Eat it in a hurry, dressed, with sandals on your feet and staff in hand. It’s the LORD’s Passover. 12I’ll go all over Egypt that night and strike down the firstborn people and animals. I’ll execute judgment on Egypt’s gods. I’m the LORD. 13The blood on your houses will be a sign. When I see it, I’ll ‘pass over’ you. No plague will fall on you when I strike Egypt.  	Ex 12:1-13

14“Today will serve as a memorial day for you. Celebrate it as a festival to the LORD, a permanent ordinance. 15Eat bread without yeast for a week. On the first day, take the yeast out of your houses. Whoever eats anything with yeast in it from the first till seventh day will be excluded from Israel. 16On the first day, hold a holy assembly. On the seventh day, hold another one. Don’t work on those days except for what needs to be eaten by each person that only you can fix. 17Observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread throughout your generations; that’s the day I brought your hosts out of Egypt. 18In the first month, eat bread without yeast from the fourteenth in the evening till the twenty-first in the evening. 19For a week, no yeast can be in your houses. Whoever eats anything with yeast in it will be excluded from the community of Israel, foreign or native. 20Eat bread without yeast in all your houses.” 	Ex 12:14-20

21Moses called Israel’s elders,

“Butcher a Passover lamb for each family. 22Dip a bunch of hyssop in the blood that’s in the basin and apply it to the lintel and doorposts. 14“If you borrow something that gets injured or dies while its owner’s absent, you’ll make full compensation. 15If its owner’s present, you won’t make compensation. If you rented it, it came for the rent.

Laws About Social Justice

16“If a man seduces a virgin that’s not engaged and lies with her, he has to pay a dowry for her to be his wife. 17If her father refuses to give her to him, he’ll still pay money equal to the dowry for virgins.

18“Don’t let a sorceress live.

19“Execute whoever has sexual relations with an animal.

20“Execute whoever sacrifices to any god but the LORD.

21“Don’t wrong or mistreat a foreigner; you were foreigners in Egypt.

Ex 22:14-21

22“Don’t abuse a widow or orphan in any way. 23If you do and the person cries out to me, 24my anger will flare. I’ll kill you with the sword and make yoursg wives widows and your children orphans.

25“If you lend money to the poor among my people, don’t charge interest.

26If you take your neighbor’s cloak as a pledge, give it back before sundown. 27That may be the only covering your neighbor has to sleep in. When your neighbor cries out to me, I’ll listen because I’m gracious.

28“Don’t curse God or a ruler of your people.

29“Don’t put off giving your offerings from your crops or vintage.

“Give me your firstborn sons. 30Do the same with your cattle and sheep. After it’s with its mother for a week, give it to me on the eighth day.

31“You’ll be holy people to me; so don’t eat any animal torn to pieces in the pasture by wild animals. Feed it to the dogs. 	Ex 22:22-31

23:1“Don’t pass on false rumors, join sinners in giving malicious testimony, 2or follow the crowd in doing something bad. In a dispute, don’t join other people to pervert justice. 3Don’t be partial toward a poor person in a dispute.

4“If you run onto your enemy’s ox or donkey wandering around, return it. 5If you see a donkey that belongs to someone that hates you lying helpless under its load, free it.			 Ex 23:1-5

6“Don’t pervert justice for your needy neighbor in a dispute.

7“Avoid making false charges. Don’t execute an innocent or good person. I won’t acquit you.

8“Don’t take a bribe; it blinds the clear-sighted and undercuts what good people are trying to do.

9“Don’t oppress a foreigner; you know what it’s like to be one; you were foreigners in Egypt.

Laws About Sabbaths and Festivals

10“Plant and harvest your ground for six years. 11Let it lie fallow the seventh year so the needy among your people can eat what grows volunteer. Whatever they leave, the wild animals can have. Do the same thing with your vineyard and olive trees.

12“Work six days. On the seventh, stop working so your ox and donkey can rest, so the son of your female slave and the foreigner that’s with you can refresh themselves. 13Pay attention to everything I’ve told you.

“Don’t even say the names of other gods.	 Ex 23:6-13

14“Celebrate three festivals to me each year. 15Observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread. Eat bread without yeast for a week at the scheduled time in the month Abib, the month you came out of Egypt. Nobody is to come to me empty-handed. 16Observe the Festival of the Harvest, the first part of the harvest from what you sow. Observe the Festival of Ingathering at the end of the year at harvest time. 17Three times a year all males are to appear in front of the Lord GOD.

18“Don’t offer the blood of my sacrifice with bread containing yeast. The fat from my feast is not to remain till morning. 19Bring the best of the first harvest from your ground to the house of the LORD your God.

“Don’t boil a kid in its mother’s milk.	 Ex 23:14-19

Conquest of Canaan Promised

20“I’ll send an angel to take you safely to the place I’ve designated. 21Be sure to obey him. He won’t pardon your sins because he wears my name. 22If you sincerely obey him in everything I say, I’ll be an enemy to your enemies, an adversary to your adversaries. 23My angel will take you to the Amorite, Hittite, Perizzite, Canaanite, Hivite, and Jebusite; and I’ll destroy them.	 Ex 23:20-23

24“Don’t worship and serve other gods or do what they do. Overthrow them completely and break their sacred pillars to pieces. 25Serve the LORD your God, and he’ll bless your bread and water, and keep you from getting sick. 26There won’t be any miscarriages or barrenness in your country, and you’ll have long lives. 27I’ll spread fear in front of you, and throw into confusion the people you invade, and make your enemies flee. 28I’ll send hornets ahead of you to drive out the Hivites, Canaanites, and Hittites. 29I won’t drive them out in a single year; the land would grow wild and wild animals would take over. 30I’ll drive them out little by little till you gain possession of it all and make it productive.

31“I’ll set your boundary from the Red Sea to the sea beside the Philistines, from the desert to the River Euphrates. I’ll deliver the people to you to drive out. 32Don’t make any treaty with them or their gods. 33Don’t let them live in your country and end up making you sin against me. If you serve their gods, they’ll be a snare to you.” 	Ex 23:24-33

7The LORD told Moses,

“Go down right now. The people have corrupted themselves. 8They’ve turned aside so soon from what I commanded them. They’ve made a molten calf and worshiped it, sacrificed to it, and said, ‘This is your god, Israel, that brought you out of Egypt!’ 9These are stubborn people. 10Let me alone so my anger can burn against them and destroy them. I’ll make a great nation out of you.”

11Moses asked the LORD his God,

“Why does your anger burn against the people you brought out of Egypt with such power? 12Why should the Egyptians be able to say you brought them out to kill them in the mountains and destroy them from the earth? Turn from your furious anger and change your mind about harming them. 13Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, the servants you swore to by yourself, ‘I’ll multiply your descendants like stars in the sky, and this land I’ve talked about I’ll give your descendants as a permanent inheritance.’”

14So the LORD changed his mind about harming them.	 Ex 32:7-14

15Moses went down the mountain, carrying the two tablets of the Testimony, engraved on both sides 16with God’s writing. 17When Joshua heard the people shouting, he told Moses it sounded like war in the camp.

18But Moses said, “That’s not the shout of triumph or defeat.  I hear singing.”

19As soon as he got close to the camp, he saw the calf and the dancing, and his anger flared. He threw the tablets down and shattered them at the foot of the mountain. 20He took the calf they’d made, burned it, and ground it to powder. He scattered it on the water and made the people drink it.	 Ex 32:15-20

21Moses asked Aaron, “What did these people do to get you to bring such a great sin on them?”

22“Don’t be furious with me. You know they’re prone to evil. 23They told me, ‘Make us a god to go ahead of us. We don’t know what’s happened to this Moses who brought us out of Egypt.’ 24I told them, ‘Whoever has gold, take it off.’ They gave it to me; I threw it into the fire, and this calf came out.”	 Ex 32:21-24

25Moses saw that the people were out of control (Aaron had let them get out of control to be ridiculed by their enemies). 26So he stood at the entrance to the camp and said, “Whoever is for the LORD, come to me!” Levi’s descendants went to him,

27He said,

“The LORD God of Israel, says, ‘Every one of you, put a sword on your thigh, and go back and forth from gate to gate in the camp. Each man, slay your brother, friend, or neighbor.’”

28The Levites did that and slew about 3,000 men that day. 29Then Moses said, “Dedicate yourselves to the LORD (because every man has been against his son and brother) so he can bless you today.”	 Ex 32:25-29

30The next day, Moses told the people, “You’ve committed a serious sin. I’m going up to the LORD. Maybe I can atone for you.” 31He went back to the LORD, and said,

“The people have committed a serious sin by making a god out of gold. 32But if you will, forgive them. If not, erase me out of your scroll!”

33The LORD told him,

“The ones that have sinned against me are the ones I’ll erase out of my scroll. 34Go lead them where I said. My angel will go ahead of you. When I punish, I’ll punish them for their sin.”

35The LORD struck the people because of what they’d done with the calf Aaron made.

Ex 32:30-35

33:1The LORD told Moses,

“Leave here and go to the land I swore I’d give the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. 2I’ll send an angel ahead of you to drive out the Canaanite, Amorite, Hittite, Perizzite, Hivite, and Jebusite. 3Go up to a land flowing with milk and honey. I won’t go up with you, because you’re stubborn, so I won’t destroy you on the way.”

4When the people heard that discouraging word, they went into mourning; nobody put on jewelry. 5The LORD had told Moses, “Tell them, ‘You’re being stubborn. If I’d go up among you for a moment, I’d destroy you. So take off your jewelry so I’ll know what I’m to do with you.’” 6They didn’t wear jewelry from Mount Horeb/Sinai on.	 Ex 33:1-6

The Tent of Meeting

7Moses would pitch a tent a good distance outside the camp—what he called The Tent of Meeting. Anybody that wanted to consult the LORD would go out to it. 8Whenever Moses went out, everybody would stand at the entrance of his tent and watch him till he went into the tent. 9Then the pillar of cloud would come down and stand at the entrance, and the LORD would talk to him. 10When people saw the pillar, they would worship at their own tents. 11The LORD would speak to Moses directly, the way you talk to a friend. When Moses would come back to the camp, his assistant Joshua son of Nun, a young man, would stay behind at the tent. 	Ex 33:7-11

Moses Sees the Glory of the LORD

12Then Moses told the LORD,

“You tell me to bring the people up, but you haven’t let me know who you’ll send with me. You’ve said you knew me by name, and you’ve been gracious to me. 13Let me know your ways so I can know you and please you.  Consider this nation your people.

14“My presence will go with yousg, and I’ll give you rest.”

15“If you don’t go with us, don’t take us away from here. 16How can your people and I know we’re being pleasing to you? Isn’t it by having you with us so we can tell the difference between ourselves and other people?” 	Ex 33:12-16

17“I’ll do what you’ve asked, because you’re pleasing to me, and I know you by name.”

18“Show me your glory.”

19“I’ll make my goodness pass by in front of you, and show you who I am. I’ll decide who to give grace to and who to show mercy to. 20But you can’t see my face. Nobody can see me and live! 21Here’s a place beside me; stand on that rock. 22While my glory is passing by, I’ll put you in a crevice in the rock and cover you with my hand till I’m past. 23Then I’ll take my hand away, and you can see my back; but you won’t see my face.”	 Ex 33:17-23

The New Stone Tablets

34:1The LORD told Moses,

“Carve out two stone tablets like the first ones, and I’ll write on them what was on the tablets you shattered. 2Be ready by morning. Come up to the top of Mount Sinai and present yourself 3alone. Nobody can be on the mountain. Flocks and herds can’t graze by it.”

4He carved two stone tablets like the first ones, got up early, and took them up to Mount Sinai. 5The LORD came down in a cloud and stood there with him as he called on the LORD. 6He passed by Moses and proclaimed,

“The LORD, the LORD God, merciful and gracious, slow to anger, abounding in kindness and faithfulness;7who shows kindness to thousands; forgives iniquity, transgression, and sin; yet doesn’t leave guilty people unpunished, and visits the consequences of parents’ sins on their descendants for three or four generations!”

8Moses immediately bowed to the ground in worship.

9“LORD, if I’m pleasing to you, go along with us, even though we’ve been so stubborn. Pardon our sin and take us as your own.”	  Ex 34:1-9

10God said,

“I’ll make a covenant. I’ll perform miracles for the people that haven’t been done in any nation. The people you live with will see my working; it’ll be terrifying. 11Be sure to observe what I’m commanding you today; and I’ll drive out the Amorite, Canaanite, Hittite, Perizzite, Hivite, and Jebusite in front of you.

12“Don’t make any treaty with the people where you’re going. That would be a snare among you. 13Tear down their altars, smash their sacred pillars, cut down their Asherah poles. 14(Don’t worship any other god, because I am an ‘exclusive’ God. Exclusive is my name.) 15Destroy those things so you won’t be making treaties with them, carrying on prostitution with their gods, sacrificing to them, eating their sacrifices with them—16so you won’t be taking their daughters for your sons, and their daughters carry on prostitution with their gods and get your sons to do it.

17“Don’t make molten gods.”	Ex 34:10-17

18“Observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread. For a week at the specified time in the month Abib, eat bread without yeast like I told you. That’s the month you came out of Egypt.

19“The first male offspring belongs to me, including the first male offspring of your cattle and sheep. 20With a lamb, redeem the first offspring of a donkey. If you don’t redeem it, break its neck. Redeem firstborn sons. None of them are to appear in front me empty-handed.”  	Ex 34:18-20

21“Work six days, but rest on the seventh, even during plowing time and harvest.

22“At year’s end, celebrate the Festival of Weeks, that is, the first part of the wheat harvest, the Festival of Ingathering.

23“Three times a year, males are to appear in my presence. 24I’ll drive out nations in front of you and enlarge your territory. Nobody is to covet your land when you go up three times a year to appear in my presence.

25“Don’t offer the blood of my sacrifice with bread containing yeast or leave the Passover sacrifice over till morning.

26“Bring the first of your ground’s produce to my house.

“Don’t boil a kid in its mother’s milk.

27“Write those things down; with them I’m making a covenant with you and Israel.”

28Moses was there with the LORD for 40 days and didn’t eat bread or drink water. The LORD wrote the terms of the covenant on the tablets: The Ten Commandments. 	Ex 34:21-28

The Glowing Face of Moses

29When Moses was coming down from Mount Sinai (with the tablets in hand), he didn’t realize his face was glowing because he’d been speaking with the LORD. 30When Aaron and the Israelites saw his face glowing, they were afraid to get close to him. 31He called out to them, and Aaron and the rulers in the community came back to him. 32He told them to do everything the LORD had told him on Mount Sinai. 33When he finished talking, he put on a veil. 34Whenever he went to speak to the LORD, he’d take it off till he came out to report what the LORD had said. 35The people would see his face glowing, and he’d put the veil back on till he went in to speak to the LORD again. LEVITICUS

Burnt Offering from the Flock

1:1The LORD called to Moses from the Tent of Meeting and told him,

2“When you take an offering to the LORD, take it from the herd or flock. 3For a burnt offering from the herd, offer a male without defect. Offer it at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting 4and put your hand on its head to make it acceptable to atone for you. 5Slaughter the young bull, and the sons of Aaron, the priests, will offer up its blood and sprinkle it around on the altar at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.  6Skin the burnt offering and butcher it. 7The sons of Aaron will put fire on the altar, arrange wood on the fire, 8and arrange the pieces, head, and fat on the wood. 9But you’ll wash its entrails and legs, and the priest will offer it up in smoke for a burnt offering,	 Lev 1:1-9

10“If your burnt offering is a sheep or goat from the flock, it’ll be without defect. 11Slaughter it on the north side of the altar in front of the LORD, and the sons of Aaron will sprinkle its blood around on the altar. 12Then butcher it with its head and fat, and the priests will arrange the pieces on the wood on the altar. 13You’ll wash the entrails and legs, and the priest will offer it up in smoke for a burnt offering on the altar, an aroma pleasing to the LORD.	 Lev 1:10-13

Instructions for Priests

21:1The LORD told Moses to tell the sons of Aaron the priests,

Blessings for Obedience

26:1“Don’t make idols, set up images or sacred pillars, or put stone figurines in your country to bow to. 2Keep my Sabbaths and reverence my sanctuary. 3If you follow my statutes and keep my commandments, 4I’ll give you rain in its season so the ground will grow crops and the trees will bear fruit. 5Threshing time will last till grape harvest, and grape harvest will last till planting season. You’ll have plenty to eat, and you’ll live securely in your country. 6I’ll grant peace so you can lie down without feeling afraid. I’ll eliminate dangerous wild animals from the land, and no sword will pass through your land. 7You’ll chase your enemies, and they’ll fall by your sword. 8Five of you will chase 100, and 100 will chase 10,000. 9I’ll favor you, multiply you, and confirm my covenant with you. 10You’ll eat the old supply and clear out the old because of the new. 11I’ll live among you 12and be your God, and you’ll be my people. 13I’m the LORD your God that brought you out of Egypt so you wouldn’t be their slaves. Punishment for Disobedience

14“If you don’t carry out these commandments, 15if you reject my statutes, abhor my ordinances, and break my covenant, 16I’ll bring panic over you. Consumption and fever will make your eyes sink in and depress you. You’ll plant your seed for nothing because your enemies will eat it. 17I’ll oppose you, and your enemies will strike you down. 18“If you still don’t obey me, I’ll punish you seven times over 19and break your strong pride. I’ll make your sky like iron and your ground like bronze. 20You’ll spend your strength for nothing, because the ground won’t grow crops and the trees won’t bear fruit.

21“If you’re still hostile toward me and refuse to obey, I’ll strike you with plague seven times over. 22I’ll let wild animals loose among you to terrorize your children, destroy your livestock, and decimate your population till your roads are deserted.

When you retreat to your towns, I’ll send a plague and deliver you to your enemies. 26When I break your staff of bread, ten women will bake your bread in one oven and bring it to you in rations. I won’t smell your pleasing aromas. 32I’ll make the land so desolate it will appall your enemies that settle in it. 33I’ll scatter you among the nations and draw out a sword after you as your land grows desolate and your towns become ruins.

34“The land will enjoy its Sabbaths during its desolation while you’re in your enemies’ country. 35It will get the rest it didn’t get on the Sabbaths while you were living in it. 36You that are left, I’ll make lose heart in your enemies’ countries. 16aMoses sent them to spy out the land.

17He told them,

“Go up into the Negev, then to the hill country. 18See what the land is like, how strong the people are, how many there are. 19See if the land is good or bad. See if the towns are like open camps or if they’re fortified. 20Is the ground lush or with little vegetation? Do they have trees? Bring back some fruit.”

It was the season for the first-ripe grapes.

21They spied out the land from the Wilderness of Zin as far as Rehob to Lebo-hamath. 22After they’d gone up to the Negev, they went to Hebron, where Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, descendants of Anak, lived. (Hebron was built 7 years before Zoan in Egypt.) 23They went to the Valley of Eshcol and cut off a branch with a single cluster of grapes. They carried it on a pole between two men along with some pomegranates and figs. 24They called that place The Valley of Eshcol because of the “cluster” of grapes they cut off there. 	Num 13:16-24

The Report of the Spies

25When they came back after 40 days, 26they went to Moses, Aaron, and the whole community in the Wilderness of Paran, at Kadesh. They brought back their report and showed them the fruit from the land:

27“We went into the land, and it does flow with milk and honey. Here’s some of its fruit. 28But the people are strong, and the towns are fortified and big. Besides, we saw descendants of Anak there. 29Amalek lives in the Negev; the Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites live in the hill country; and the Canaanites live by the sea and along the Jordan.”

30Caleb quieted the people in front of Moses, “We should certainly go up and take possession of it. We can conquer it.”

31But the men that had gone up with him said, “We can’t go up against the people. They’re too strong for us.”

32They gave the people a discouraging report,

“The land overruns its people. They’re big people. 33We saw the Nephilim [Descendants of Anak are one part of the Nephilim.]; we felt like grasshoppers, and that’s what we looked like to them.”	Num 13:25-33

The People Rebel

14:1The community cried out loud that night 2and complained to Moses and Aaron,

“We should’ve died in Egypt! We should’ve died in the desert! 3Why is the LORD taking us to this land to fall by the sword? Our wives and little ones will become spoils of war. Wouldn’t we be better off to go back to Egypt?”

4They said to one another, “Let’s appoint a leader and go back.”

5Moses and Aaron fell on their faces in front of the assembly. 6Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh tore their clothes 7and told them,

“The land we passed through is really good land. 8If the LORD is pleased with us, he’ll take us in and give it to us, a land flowing with milk and honey. 9Don’t rebel against him or be afraid of them; they’ll be our prey. Their protection has been removed, and the LORD is with us.”

10But the community said to stone them. Then the glory of the LORD appeared in the Tent of Meeting to the Israelites, 11and he told Moses,

“How long will these people spurn me? How long will they not trust me despite all the signs I’ve performed among them? 12I’ll hit them with a plague and disinherit them, and I’ll make you into a nation bigger and stronger than them.”

Num 14:1-12

Moses Intercedes for the People

13But Moses told him,

“The Egyptians will hear about it, because by your strength you brought these people up from among them, 14and they’ll tell the people in this land. They’ve heard you’re among the people. You’re seen eye to eye while your cloud stands over them, and you lead them in a pillar of cloud in the daytime and a pillar of fire at night. 15If you kill this whole nation, the nations that have heard of your fame will say 16you couldn’t take them to the land you promised them with an oath; so you killed them in the desert. 17Let your power be great like you’ve said, 18‘You’re slow to get angry, you abound in kindness, and forgive sin. But you won’t by any means acquit the guilty. You visit the consequences of parents’ sin on their descendants for three or four generations.’ 19Pardon these people in keeping with your great kindness—like you’ve done from Egypt till now.”

God Measures Out Judgment

20The LORD said,

“I’ll pardon them; 21but as I live, I’ll fill the whole world with my glory. 22The people saw my glory and signs in Egypt and in the desert, but they’ve tested me ten times and ignored me. 23None of them that spurned me will see the land I swore to their ancestors. 24I’ll take my servant Caleb in. He’s had a different spirit and followed me faithfully. His descendants will take possession of it. 25The Amalekites and Canaanites live in the valleys. Turn around tomorrow and set out to the open country by the Red Sea.”	Num 14:13-25

26The LORD said to Moses and Aaron,

They’ll experience the land you rejected. [32] 33Your offspring will be shepherds in the desert for 40 years. Because of your unfaithfulness, they’ll suffer till your corpses lie in the desert. 34So you’ll realize how displeased I am, you’ll suffer for your guilt one year for every day you spied out the land. 35I’ve spoken, and I’ll do it to this community that has united against me: you’ll die in this desert.”

6“For a ram, prepare as a grain offering .22 bushel .2 ephah of fine flour mixed with ⅓⅓ him of olive oil. 7For a liquid offering, offer ⅓ gallon ⅓ hin of wine as an aroma pleasing to the LORD. 	Num 15:1-7

8“When you prepare a bull as a burnt offering or sacrifice—to fulfill a special vow or for peace offerings to the LORD —9offer it with a grain offering made from .33 bushel .3 ephah of fine flour mixed with 3 quarts ½ hin of olive oil. 10Offer as the liquid offering 3 quarts ½ hin of wine as an offering by fire, as an aroma pleasing to the LORD. 11That’s the way it’s to be done for each ox, ram, male lamb, or goat, 12the same for each sacrifice.

13“Every citizen of you will do those things when you present an offering by fire, as an aroma pleasing to the LORD. 14If foreigners staying with you—temporarily or permanently—want to make an offering by fire, they’ll do it the same way you do. 15-16There’ll be one statute, one law, one ordinance for you and for foreigners among you throughout your generations.” 	Num 15:8-16

Unintentional Sins

22-23“When the whole community unintentionally fails to observe any commandment, 24they’ll offer 1 bull for a burnt offering (as an aroma pleasing to the LORD, with its grain offering and liquid offering) and 1 male goat for a sin offering. 25The priest will atone for the whole community because they brought the offering to the LORD for their error. 26He’ll forgive the community, including any foreigner among them, since it wasn’t intentional.	 Num 15:22-26

Water of Purification

19:1The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

2“This is a statute of the LORD, ‘Tell the Israelites to bring you an unblemished red heifer that’s never worn a yoke. 3Give it to Eleazar to take outside the camp and slaughter in his presence. 4He’ll take some of its blood with his finger and sprinkle it toward the front of the Tent of Meeting seven times. 5Then the heifer will be burned in front of him—hide, meat, blood, and refuse. 6The priest will take cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet material, and throw it onto the burning heifer. 7Then he’ll wash his clothes, take a bath, and afterward come into the camp, but he’ll be ceremonially unclean till evening. 8The one that burns it will also wash his clothes, take a bath, and be unclean till evening. 9A man that’s clean will gather the heifer’s ashes and deposit them outside the camp in a clean place, and the community will keep it as water for removing impurity from sin. 10The one that gathers the ashes will wash his clothes and be unclean till evening. 11‘Anyone of you that touches a human corpse will be ceremonially unclean for a week. 12Purify yourself with the water on the third and seventh days, and you’ll be clean. If you don’t, you’re still unclean; 13you’re defiling the LORD’s Tabernacle, and you’re excluded from Israel.

That is why I have commanded you to observe the Sabbath.

16‘Honor your parents so you can live a long time and things will go well for you in the land I your God am giving you.

18‘Do not commitf adultery.

22“With a loud voice the LORD said that to your whole assembly at the mountain out of the fire, cloud, and dense darkness. He didn’t add anything else. He wrote it on two stone tablets and gave them to me. 23You heard him speak out of the blackness while the mountain was burning. The leaders and elders in your tribes came to me, 24‘The LORD our God has shown us how great and glorious he is. We’ve heard him speak out of the fire. Call to Commitment

6:1“The LORD your God told me to teach you those statutes 2so you and your descendants would respect him and keep them your whole life and live a long time. 3Do them, Israel, so things will go well for you, and you’ll multiply in a land flowing with milk and honey.

4“Listen, Israel, the LORD is our God, the LORD only. 5Love him with all your heart, soul, and strength. 6Keep in mind the things I’m commanding you. 7Teach them diligently to your children. Talk about them when you’re sitting at home, walking down the road, lying down, or getting up. 8Tie them like signs on your hand and make them like frontlets on your forehead. 9Write them on your gates and doorposts. 	Deut 6:1-9

10“The land the LORD is taking you to has big, splendid cities you didn’t build, 11houses full of good things you didn’t put there, hewn cisterns you didn’t dig, vineyards and olive trees you didn’t plant. Driving Out the Nations

7:1“The LORD will take you to the land and clear out the Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, Jebusites—seven nations bigger and stronger than you. 2He’ll deliver them to you, defeat them, and destroy them. He’ll lay them on people that hate you. 16You’ll consume the nations he delivers to you. Don’t show them any mercy or serve their gods. That would be a snare to you.

Call Not to Forget the LORD

8:1“Do every commandment I’m giving you today, so you’ll live and multiply, and take over the land. 2Remember the way the LORD led you in the desert those 40 years to humble you. 11“Make sure you don’t forget him or neglect his commandments, ordinances, and statutes. 12That way you’ll eat till you’re full, build nice houses and live in them, 13have herds and flocks that multiply, and increase your silver and gold along with everything else you have. 14Then you won’t get proud and forget about him. 15He led you through the big, terrible desert, its poisonous snakes and scorpions, its thirsty ground with no water. He brought water out of flint rock. 16He fed you manna to test you and humble you, to do you good in the end. 17Otherwise, you might say to yourselves that your own power and strength have created this wealth. 18Remember that he’s giving you the opportunity to create wealth in confirmation of his covenant. 19If you ever forget him and go after other gods, I’m telling you today, you’ll certainly perish 20like the nations he’ll make perish in front of you. Victory by God’s Power

9:1“Israel, you’re crossing the Jordan now to take over nations bigger and stronger than you, to take over big cities fortified to the sky, 2to take over people big and tall, the Anakim you’ve heard people say about, ‘Who can stand up to the descendants of Anak?’

6“It’s not your goodness; you’re stubborn.			         Deut 9:1-6

The Gold Calf

7Don’t forget how you’ve provoked the LORD in the desert. From the time you left Egypt, you’ve been rebellious toward him. 8Even at Horeb/Sinai you provoked him. He was so angry with you he was ready to destroy you. 9When I went up on the mountain to receive the stone tablets of his covenant with you, I stayed there 40 days and nights without eating or drinking. 10He gave me the tablets he wrote that contained everything he’d told you out of the fire at your assembly. 11At the end of the 40 days, he gave them to me, 12‘Quick, go down. Your people have acted corruptly. They’ve turned aside so soon from what I commanded and made themselves a molten image. 13I’ve seen how stubborn they are. 14Stand aside so I can destroy them and erase their name. I’ll make a nation out of you that’s bigger and stronger than they are.’

15“I came down from the burning mountain with the two tablets in my hands. 16I saw you’d really sinned against him and made a molten calf. 17I threw the tablets down and shattered them in front of you. 18I fell down to the LORD as at the first for 40 days and nights. I didn’t eat or drink anything because your sin stirred him up. 19I was afraid his anger was going to destroy you, but he listened to me that time too. 20He was angry enough with Aaron to destroy him; so I prayed for him at the same time. 21I burned the sinful calf you’d made, pulverized it, ground it up, and threw the dust into the creek that was running down from the mountain.	 Deut 9:7-21

22“Again at Taberah, Massah, and Kibroth-hattaavah you provoked him. 23When he sent you from Kadesh-barnea to go up and take over the land he’d given you, you wouldn’t listen or trust him. 24You’ve kept rebelling since I first knew you.

25“I fell down to him for 40 days and nights because he said he’d destroy you. 26I prayed, ‘Lord GOD, don’t destroy your people, the permanent possession you redeemed with your greatness, the nation you brought out of Egypt by your power. 27Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Don’t just look at these people’s stubbornness and sin. 28Otherwise, the country you brought us from will say, “The LORD took them out to kill them in the desert. Fear the LORD

One Central Place of Worship

12:1“You’re to observe these statutes and judgments as long as you live. 2Destroy the places where these nations worship their gods—on hills and mountains and under every green tree. 3Tear down their altars, smash their sacred pillars, burn their Asherah poles, cut down the carved images of their gods, erase their name from those places.

[23-24] 25Don’t eat the blood, so things will go well for you and your descendants; you’ll be doing what’s right in front of God. 26But where he designates take your holy things and offerings to fulfill a vow. 27Offer your burnt offerings on the altar, pour out the blood on the altar, and eat the meat. 13:1“If a prophet or dreamer arises and gives you a sign or wonder 2that comes true, and uses it to say, ‘Let’s serve other gods,’ 3ignore him. Ceremonially Clean and Unclean Animals

14:1“You’re the people of the LORD your God. Don’t cut yourselves or shave your eyebrows for the dead. 2You’re set apart to the LORD. Out of all the nations, he’s chosen you to be his nation.

3“Don’t eat anything detestable. 4You can eat these animals: cattle, sheep, goats, 5deer, gazelles, roebucks, wild goats, ibexes, antelopes, mountain sheep. 6You can eat any animal that has divided hoofs and chews their cud. 7Don’t eat camels, rabbits, and rock-badgers. They chew the cud, but don’t divide the hoof. They’re unclean. 8Don’t eat pigs. They divide the hoof, but don’t chew cud. They’re ceremonially unclean. Don’t touch their carcasses. 	Deut 14:1-8

11“You can eat any clean bird. 12You can’t eat eagles, vultures, buzzards, 13red kites, falcons, kites of any kind, 14ravens of any kind, 15horned owls, screech owls, sea gulls, hawks of any kind, 16the little owls, great horned owls, white owls, 17pelilcans, carrion vultures, cormorants, 18storks, herons of any kind, hoopoes, or bats.

21“Don’t eat anything that dies on its own. You can give or sell it to foreigners in your town to eat. You’re a holy people.

Tithes

22“Make sure to present a tenth of everything you sow in the field each year. 23Eat it in the LORD’s presence where he designates—a tenth of your grain, new wine, olive oil, the firstborn in your herd and flock so you’ll learn to respect him always. 24If you live too far away to take the tenth itself, 25sell it and take the money where he designates. 26You and your family can spend it on whatever you want—cattle, sheep, wine, alcohol—and eat it in his presence and celebrate. 27Don’t neglect the Levites in your town. The Year for Canceling Debts

15:1“At the end of every seven years, cancel debts. 2Creditors are to let go of what they’ve loaned to their fellow Hebrews. Don’t exact it from them; the LORD has canceled the debt. 3You can exact it from a foreigner, but not from fellow citizens. 4There won’t be any poor among you because the LORD will bless you like he promised 5if you obey this commandment. 6Lend to other nations, but don’t borrow from them. You’ll rule other nations; they won’t rule you.

They may call out to the LORD, and it’ll be a sin on you. 10Give generously without regret so the LORD will bless what you undertake. 11You’ll always have poor people in your land. Release of Hebrew Slaves

12“If you buy Hebrew men or women, they’ll serve you six years and go free the seventh. 13When you set them free, don’t send them away with nothing. 14Supply them liberally from your flock, your threshing floor, your wine vat. Give to them in proportion to how the LORD has blessed you. 15Remember, you were a slave in Egypt, and he redeemed you. 16If a servant says he doesn’t want to leave, because he loves you and your household and gets along well with you, 17pierce his ear with an awl. He’ll be your servant permanently. Do the same thing with a maidservant. 18Don’t let it bother you to set servants free. They’ve given you six years with twice the service a hired hand gives. Sacrifice of Firstborn Male Animals

19“Consecrate to the LORD the male firstborn in your herd and flock. Passover Festival

16:1“In the month Abib, celebrate Passover to the LORD your God. That’s when he brought you out of Egypt at night. 2Sacrifice the Passover from the flock and the herd where he designates. 3For a week, only eat bread without yeast—the bread of suffering (you came out in a hurry)—so you’ll remember all your life when you left Egypt. 4For a week no yeast will be anywhere in any of your houses. None of the meat you sacrifice the first evening is to remain till morning. 5You can’t sacrifice the Passover anywhere except where the LORD designates for his name. 6Sacrifice it at sundown, which is when you left Egypt. 7Cook it and eat it where he designates. Festival of Weeks

Festival of Tabernacles

13“Celebrate the Festival of Booths for a week after you’ve gathered in the grain from your threshing floor and the wine from your vat. 14Celebrate at the festival—you, your son and daughter, male and female servants, the Levite, foreigner, orphan, and widow in your towns. 15Celebrate a festival to the LORD for a week where he designates. Judges Appointed

18“Appoint judges and officers in your towns by tribes. Judge the people with justice. 19Don’t distort justice. Be impartial. Don’t take bribes; they blind the wise and pervert the just. 20Pursue justice and justice only, so you can live and possess the land the LORD’s giving you.

Worshiping Other Gods

21“Don’t set up a wooden Asherah pole beside an altar you make for the LORD. 22Don’t set up sacred pillars. That’s something he despises.  	Deut 16:18-22

17:1“Don’t sacrifice an ox or sheep that has a blemish. The LORD detests that.

2-4“In any of your towns, if you hear about a man or woman that breaks the covenant by serving other gods or worshiping the sun, moon, or stars, verify that detestable thing thoroughly. 5Then take the person to your city gates and stone that man or woman to death. 6You need the testimony of two or three witnesses to execute anyone. The King

so he’ll learn to respect the LORD by doing what it says,

20so he won’t lord it over fellow citizens,
