37He left Asaph and his relatives at the Ark to serve continually as each day’s work required. 38He left Obed-edom with his 68 relatives and Hosah with the son of Jeduthun as gatekeepers. 39He left Zadok the priest and his relatives at the Tabernacle in the high place at Gibeon 40to offer burnt offerings every morning and evening, according to the Law the LORD commanded Israel. 41With them were Heman and Jeduthun and the rest that were designated by name to give thanks to the LORD because his love endures forever. 42With them were Heman and Jeduthun with trumpets and cymbals for the ones that sounded out loud, with instruments for the songs of God and the sons of Jeduthun for the gate. 43Then the people left for home and David went back to bless his household.     	     1 Ch 16:37-43

The LORD’s Covenant with David

17:1While David was living in his palace, he told Nathan the prophet, “I’m living in a cedar palace, but the LORD’s Ark is under curtains.”

2Nathan said, “Do what’s in your mind. God is with you.”

3That same night, the message from God came to him,

4“Go tell my servant David, ‘The LORD says, “You’re not to build me a temple. 5I haven’t lived in a temple since I brought Israel up. I’ve gone from tent to tent and place to place. 6In all the places where I’ve lived with Israel, have I asked any judge that I’ve commanded to shepherd my people why he hasn’t built me a cedar temple?”’ 7Tell David, ‘The LORD of Hosts says, “I took you out of the pasture from behind sheep and made you a leader over Israel. 8I’ve been with you wherever you’ve gone and removed your enemies from you. I’ll make you as famous as anyone that’s ever lived in the world. 9I’ll appoint you a place for my people, and plant them so they won’t have to move anymore. Sinful people won’t lay waste to them like they did before, 10including the time I put judges over them. I’ll subdue your enemies and build you a dynasty. 11When your life’s over and you’ve gone to your ancestors, I’ll set up one of your sons and secure his throne permanently. 12He’ll build me a temple. 13I’ll be his father, and he’ll be my son. I won’t take my enduring love away from him like I did with your predecessor. 14I’ll settle him in my house and kingdom permanently.”’”	  1 Ch 17:1-14

15Nathan told David everything in his vision.

David’s Prayer

16Then David went in and sat in the LORD’s presence,

“Who am I, LORD God, and what’s my family that you’ve brought me this far? 17It’s a small thing for you, but you’ve talked about my dynasty for a long time to come and regarded me by the standard for men of high degree. 18What more can I say about the honor you’ve put on me? You know me. 19For my sake and from your own heart, you’ve done these great things and made them known. 20Nobody’s like you; there’s no God besides you. From everything we’ve heard, 21what nation is like Israel? You went to redeem them out of Egypt to make a name for yourself with great and terrifying acts, in driving out nations ahead of your people. 22You made Israel your people permanently and became their God. 23Now make permanent your promise about me and my dynasty. 24Establish your name and make it great forever. 25-26It’s a good thing that you’ve revealed to me that you’ll build a dynasty for me. That’s encouraged me to pray to you. 27It has pleased you to bless my family so it will continue permanently. You’ve blessed it forever.”  	1 Ch 17:15-27

David’s Military Victories

18:1After that, David defeated the Philistines and took Gath and its surrounding towns. 2He defeated Moab and they brought tribute. 3He defeated Hadadezer, king of Zobah, as far as Hamath and secured his rule all the way to the Euphrates River. 4He took 1,000 chariots, 7,000 cavalry, and 20,000 foot soldiers. He hamstrung the chariot horses but reserved enough for 100 chariots.

5When the Arameans from Damascus came to help Hadadezer, David killed 22,000 of them. 6He put garrisons in Aram of Damascus, and the Arameans brought tribute. 7He took the gold shields that Hadadezer’s officers carried and brought them to Jerusalem. 8From Tibhath and Cun, towns of Hadadezer, he took a large amount of bronze, which Solomon used to make the bronze sea, pillars, and bronze utensils.	 1 Ch 18:1-8

9Tou/Toi, king of Hamath, heard that David had defeated Hadadezer’s whole army. 10He sent his son Hadoram to greet him and bless him for it. Hadoram brought all kinds of gold, silver, and bronze articles. 11David dedicated them to the LORD with the silver and gold he’d carried off from Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, Philistines, and Amalek.

12In addition, Abishai son of Zeruiah defeated 18,000 Edomites in the Valley of Salt. 13He put garrisons in Edom, and the Edomites served him. The LORD helped him wherever he went.

14David ruled Israel and administered justice and goodness for his people.

15Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army;

Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder;

16Zadok son of Ahitub and Abimelech son of Abiathar were priests;

Shavsha was secretary;

17Benaiah son of Jehoiada was captain of David’s bodyguard;

David’s sons were chiefs at his side.	1 Ch 18:9-17

David Defeats the Ammonites and Syrians

19:1After this, Nahash, king of the Ammonites, died and his son became king. 2David said, “I’ll be kind to Hanun because his father was kind to me.” He sent ambassadors to console him about his father. 3But the officials in Ammon told Hanun, “Do you think David is honoring your father by sending ambassadors to comfort you? Haven’t they come to spy out the land to overthrow it?” 4Hanun took David’s ambassadors and shaved them, cut off their cloaks as high as their hips, and sent them away. 5Some people came and told David about the men. He sent to meet them because they were humiliated. He told them to stay in Jericho till their beards grew back; then come home.

6When the Ammonites saw they’d been offensive to David, Hanun and the Ammonites sent 37¾ tons 1,000 talents of silver to hire chariots and cavalry from Mesopotamia, from Aram-maacah and Zobah. 7They hired 32,000 chariots, the king of Maacah, and his soldiers. They camped by Medeba. The Ammonites gathered from their towns and came to battle. 8When David heard it, he sent Joab and the whole army, the strongest soldiers. 9The Ammonites came out and drew up in battle formation at the entrance to the city. The kings that had come were by themselves in the field.      	1 Ch 19:1-9

10When Joab saw that the battle was set against him in front and behind, he selected elite soldiers and arrayed them against the Arameans. 11The rest he placed under his brother Abishai, and they arrayed themselves against the Ammonites. 12He said,

“If the Arameans are too strong for me, you help me. If the Ammonites are too strong for you, I’ll help you. 13Be strong; let’s show ourselves courageous for our people and the towns of our God. May the LORD do what seems good to him.”

14Joab and his troops engaged the Arameans, and they fled. 15When the Ammonites saw the Arameans flee, they retreated from Abishai into the city. Then Joab made a trip to Jerusalem.

16When the Arameans saw Israel had defeated them, they sent ambassadors to bring out the Arameans from the other side of the River with Shophach the commander of Hadadezer’s army leading them. 17When David heard it, he mustered Israel, crossed the Jordan, and came on them. He drew up in formation against them and they fought him. 18They fled, and he killed 7,000 charioteers and 40,000 foot soldiers, and put Shophach to death. 19When Hadadezer’s vassals saw Israel had defeated them, they surrendered and served David. The Arameans weren’t willing to help the Ammonites anymore.	1 Ch 19:10-19

David Defeats the Ammonites

20:1In the spring, when kings go to war, Joab led out the army and ravaged the country of the Ammonites and laid siege to Rabbah. David stayed in Jerusalem. Joab attacked Rabbah and overthrew it. 2Then David went to Rabbah and took the crown off their king’s head, and found that it weighed 75½ lbs a talent of gold, and was set with precious stones. They placed it on David’s head, and he brought out a really large amount of spoil from the city. 3He brought the people out, and cut them with saws, sharp instruments, and axes. He did that to all the Ammonite towns. Then he and the people came back to Jerusalem.

4About this time, war broke out with the Philistines at Gezer. Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Sippai, a descendant of the giants, and they were subdued. 5There was war with the Philistines again, and Elhanan son of Jair killed Lahmi brother of Goliath the Gittite, the shaft of whose spear was like a weaver’s beam. 6Another time there was war at Gath, where there was a huge man with six digits on each hand and foot. He had descended from the giants too. 7When he taunted Israel, Jonathan, son of David’s brother Shimea, killed him. 8Those three descended from the giants in Gath that David and his warriors killed. 	1 Ch 20:1-8

David’s Ill-Advised Census

21:1Satan stood up against Israel and tempted David to take a census. 2David told Joab and the commanders of the troops,

“Go count Israel from Dan to Beersheba and bring me the results so I can know how many there are.”

3Joab said, “May the LORD add to his people 100 times as many as they are! But my lord the king, aren’t they all serving you? Why do you want to know this? Why bring guilt on Israel?”

4But the king’s word prevailed. So Joab went all over Israel and came back to Jerusalem. 5He gave David the census number: 1,100,000 swordsmen in Israel and 470,000 in Judah. 6He didn’t count Levi and Benjamin because he abhorred the king’s command. 7God was displeased with this thing, so he struck Israel. 	1 Ch 21:1-7

8David said to God, “I’ve committed an awful sin. Please take it away. I’ve done something really foolish.”

9The LORD told Gad, David’s seer, 10“Tell David,

‘The LORD says 11to take 12either three years of famine, three months of being swept away by your enemies’ sword, or three days of the sword of the LORD when his angel destroys throughout Israel.’ What should I report to the One that sent me?” 	1 Ch 21:8-12

13David told Gad, “I’m in great distress. I’ll cast myself on the LORD’s mercy because it’s so great. Don’t let me fall into human hands.” 14The LORD sent a plague on Israel; 70,000 people died. 15He sent an angel to destroy Jerusalem; but as he was about to do it, he looked and was sad over the catastrophe. He told the destroying angel, “That’s enough; relax your hand.” The angel was standing by the threshing floor of Ornan/Araunah the Jebusite. 16David looked up and saw him standing between earth and sky with his sword held out over Jerusalem. David and the elders, covered with burlap, fell on their faces. 17He told God, “I’m the one that sinned. What have these sheep done? LORD my God, please plague me and my father’s family, not your people.” 	1 Ch 21:13-17

David Builds an Altar

18Then the angel of the LORD had Gad tell David to build an altar to the LORD on Ornan’s/Araunah’s threshing floor. 19David went up. 20Ornan/Araunah turned and saw the angel, and his four sons hid. He was threshing wheat. 21As David came to him, he left the threshing floor and prostrated himself. 22David told him, “Sell me this threshing floor so I can build an altar on it. Give it to me at full price so God will restrain the plague.”

23Ornan/Araunah said,

“Take it and do what seems good. I’ll give the oxen for burnt offerings, the threshing sledges for wood, the wheat for the grain offering—all of it.”

24But King David said, “I won’t take what’s yours for the LORD or offer a burnt offering that doesn’t cost me anything.” 25He paid him 15 lbs 600 shekels of gold for the site. 26He built an altar there and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. He called to the LORD, and he answered him with fire from the sky on the altar. 27The LORD told the angel to sheath his sword.

28When David saw that the LORD had answered him, he offered sacrifice there, 29because the Tabernacle and altar that Moses made in the countryside were at Gibeon. 30But David couldn’t go to it to ask God because the angel’s sword terrified him. 22:1David said, “This will be the Temple of the LORD God and the altar of burnt offering for Israel.” 		 1 Ch 21:18-22:1

David’s Preparations for the Temple

2David issued an order to gather the foreigners in Israel and set stonecutters to dress stones for God’s Temple. 3He provided large stores of iron for making nails for the doors in the gates and for clamps, more bronze than could be weighed, 4and cedar logs without number. The Sidonians and Tyrians brought him large supplies of cedar timber. 5He said,

“My son Solomon is young and inexperienced, and the LORD’s Temple will be magnificent, famous, and glorious all over the world. I’ll stockpile materials for it.”

David gathered lots of material for it before he died.	1 Ch 22:2-5

6Then he called Solomon and charged him to build a temple for the LORD God of Israel,

7“Son, I intended to build a temple for the LORD, 8but his message came to me, ‘You won’t build me a temple; you’ve shed so much blood and fought great wars. 9You’ll have a son that’s not a military figure. I’ll give him rest from his enemies everywhere. His name will be Solomon because I’ll give Israel ‘peace’ and quiet during his life. 10He’ll build a temple for me. He’ll be my son, and I’ll be his father. I’ll make his kingdom permanently secure.’ 11The LORD be with you so you can succeed at building it. 12May he give you discretion and intelligence, and give you charge over Israel so you can keep his Law. 13You’ll prosper if you observe carefully the statutes and ordinances he commanded Moses. Be strong and courageous; don’t be afraid or intimidated. 14I’ve taken great pains to stockpile materials: 3775 tons 100,000 talents of gold, 37,750 tons 1,000,000 talents of silver, bronze and iron past weighing, timber, and stone. You can add to that. 15You have lots of stonecutters, stonemasons, and carpenters skilled in all kinds of work. 16There’s no limit to the gold, silver, bronze, and iron. Get started. The LORD be with you.” 	1 Ch 22:6-16

17He directed Israel’s leaders to help Solomon,

18“Isn’t the LORD with you? Hasn’t he given you rest in every direction? He’s delivered to you the nations in the land, and it’s under control. 19Set your heart and soul to look to him. Build his sanctuary so you can bring the Ark and God’s holy articles into it.”	1 Ch 22:17-19

Solomon Asks for Wisdom

1:1Solomon secured himself in his kingdom; the LORD God was with him and made him great. 2He called together all Israel--the commanders of thousands and hundreds, the judges and every leader, the heads of families. 3He led the whole assembly went to the high place at Gibeon; God’s Tent of Meeting was there that Moses had made in the countryside. 4But David had brought the Ark up from Kiriath-jearim to the tent he’d made for it in Jerusalem. 5The bronze altar that Bezalel son of Uri son of Hur had made, was there in front of the Tabernacle. Solomon and the assembly went to it, 6and he offered 1,000 burnt offerings on it.  	2 Ch 1:1-6

7That night God appeared to him,

“Ask me what you want me to give you.”

8He said,

“You’ve dealt with my father David with great enduring love and made me king in his place. 9You’ve fulfilled your promise to him and made me king over a people as numerous as dust on the ground. 10Give me wisdom and knowledge so I can carry on my work for them. Who can rule such a great people as yours?”

11God said,

“Since that was in your mind and you haven’t asked for possessions, wealth, honor, a long life, or your enemies’ lives, 12I’ll give you wisdom and knowledge; and I’ll give you possessions, wealth, and honor like no other king ever had or will have.”

13He came back to Jerusalem and reigned over Israel.   	2 Ch 1:7-13

14Solomon amassed 1,400 chariots and 12,000 cavalry and stationed them in chariot cities and in Jerusalem. 15He made silver and gold as common as stone in Jerusalem, and cedars as common as sycamores in the western foothills. 16He imported horses from Egypt, and his traders bought them from Kue. 17They brought in chariots from Egypt for 15 lbs 600 shekels of silver apiece and horses for 3¾ lbs 150 shekels of silver each. They also exported them to kings of the Hittites and Aram.	2 Ch 2:14-17

Preparations for Building the Temple

2:1Solomon decided to build a temple for the LORD’s name and a royal palace for himself. 2He assigned 70,000 to transport materials, 80,000 to quarry stone in the mountains, and 3,600 to supervise them. 3He sent word to Hiram, king of Tyre,

“As you sent my father David cedars for his palace, do for me. 4I’m getting ready to build a temple for the LORD my God and dedicate it to him for burning fragrant incense and offering burnt offerings morning and evening on Sabbaths, new moons, and the LORD’s appointed festivals—items of worship required permanently in Israel. 5The temple I’m going to build will be great, because our God is greater than all other gods. 6But who can build him a temple? The sky, the highest heavens, can’t contain him; who am I to build him a temple, except for burning incense to him? 7Send me a man skilled at working in gold, silver, brass, and iron; in purple, crimson, and violet fabrics; a man that knows how to engrave and work with the skilled men I have in Judah and Jerusalem that my father provided. 8Send me cedar, cypress, and algum wood from Lebanon; your woodsmen know how to cut timber in Lebanon. My men will work with yours 9to prepare an abundance of it for the great, wonderful temple I’m going to build. 10I’ll give your woodsmen that cut the logs 220,000 bushels 20,000 kors of crushed wheat, 220,000 bushels 20,000 kors of barley, 189,000 gallons 20,000 baths of wine, and 189,000 gallons 20,000 baths of oil.”	 2 Ch 2:1-10

11Hiram wrote back,

“Since the LORD loves his people, he’s made you their king. 12Bless the LORD God of Israel that made earth and sky and gave King David a wise son endowed with discretion and intelligence, who will build a temple for the LORD and a royal palace for himself. 13I’m sending Huram-abi, an intelligent master craftsman, 14the son of a woman from Dan and a father from Tyre. He knows how to work in gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone, as well as in purple, violet, linen, and crimson fabrics. He knows how to do all kinds of engravings and carry out any design you assign him. He can work with your skilled men and those of my lord David. 15 Send us the wheat and barley, olive oil and wine you’ve offered. 16We’ll cut whatever timber you need and bring it to you on rafts by sea to Joppa so you can transport it up to Jerusalem.”

17Solomon counted the foreigners in Israel according to David’s census and found there were 153,600 of them. 18He appointed 80,000 to quarry stones in the mountains, 70,000 to transport materials, and 3,600 to supervise the workmen.	2 Ch 2:11-18

Solomon Builds the Temple

3:1Solomon started building the LORD’s Temple on Mount Moriah, where the Lord had appeared to David, the place David prepared on the threshing floor of Ornan/Araunah the Jebusite. 2He began construction on the second day, second month, fourth year of his reign.

3The foundation for God’s Temple was 30 x 90ft.

4The porch in front of it was 30ft wide and 180ft tall, overlaid with pure gold inside.

5He lined the Temple itself with cypress wood overlaid with fine gold and decorated with palm trees and chains;

6adorned the Temple with precious stones—the gold was from Parvaim;

7overlaid the Temple with gold—the beams, thresholds, walls, and doors—and carved cherubs on the walls;

8made the Holy of Holies—30ft square, equaling the width of the Temple—and overlaid it with 22 2/3 tons 600 talents of fine gold—9the spikes weighed 20 oz 50 shekels of gold;

overlaid the upper rooms with gold.	 2 Ch 3:1-9

10He made 2 sculpted cherubs in the Holy of Holies and overlaid them with gold. 11The combined wingspan of the cherubs was 30ft. The wing of one (7½ft) touched the wall of the Temple. The other wing (7½ft) touched the wing of the second cherub. 12The wing of the second cherub (7½ft) touched the opposite wall. The other wing (7½ft) was attached to the wing of the first cherub. 13They stood on their feet facing the nave.

14He made a curtain out of violet, purple, crimson, and fine linen, and worked cherubs on it;

15two pillars in front of the Temple 53ft tall, with 7½ft capitals on top of each one;

16chains in the inner sanctuary and on top of the pillars;

100 pomegranates and put them on the chains;

Solomon’s Prayer of Dedication

12-13Solomon had built a bronze platform 7½ x 7½ x 4½ft high beside the altar in the middle of the court. He stood on it, knelt, and spread out his hands toward heaven. 	2 Ch 6:1-13

14“LORD God of Israel, there’s no God like you in heaven or on earth. You keep covenant and show enduring love to everyone that follows you with all their heart. 15You’ve kept your promise to David. You’ve said it with your mouth and fulfilled it with your hand. 16Keep this promise too, ‘You’ll always have a descendant on Israel’s throne if they follow my Law like you have.’ 17Confirm that promise now.

18“But will you live with people on earth? The sky and highest heaven can’t contain you, much less this Temple I’ve built. 19Yet attend to my petition. 22“When someone sins against another and comes here to take an oath at your altar, 23then listen from heaven and judge them. Punish the sinful by bringing their way on their own head and justify the good by rewarding them according to their goodness. 	2 Ch 6:14-23

26“When there’s no rain because they’ve sinned against you and they pray toward this place, confess your name, and turn from their sin when you punish them, 27then listen from heaven and forgive your people. Teach them the good way to live and send rain on the land you’ve given them to inherit.	2 Ch 6:24-27

28“When there’s a famine in the country; disease, blight or mildew; locust or grasshopper; a sickness, or an enemy laying siege to our towns—29whatever petition your people make, each knowing their own suffering and pain and spreading their hands toward this Temple, 30then listen from where you live, forgive, and render to each as they’ve done—only you know everyone’s heart—31so they’ll respect you and follow your ways as long as they live in the country you’ve given their ancestors.

32“When foreigners come from a distant country because of your great name, your powerful hand and outstretched arm, and pray toward this Temple, 33then listen from where you live, and do everything they call to you for, so every nation will know you and respect you like your people do, and so they’ll know that the Temple I’ve built wears your name.

34“When your people go out to battle by whatever way you send them and they pray to you toward this city you’ve chosen and the Temple I’ve built, 35then listen from heaven and support them. 	2 Ch 6:28-35

36“When they sin against you (everybody sins), you’re angry with them, and deliver them to an enemy that takes them captive near or far, 37if they take it to heart, repent, and petition you, ‘We’ve sinned, we’ve committed iniquity, we’ve acted wickedly’; 38if they come back to you with all their heart and soul, and pray toward the land you’ve given their ancestors, the city you’ve chosen, the Temple I’ve built, 39then listen from where you live, support them, and forgive them.

40“Open your eyes and ears to answer the prayer I’ve offered here. 41Rise, LORD God, to your resting place, you and your powerful Ark. Cover your priests with salvation; may your holy people celebrate what’s good. 42Don’t turn away from your anointed one. Remember your enduring love for your servant David.”

2 Ch 6:36-42

The Dedication of the Temple

7:1When Solomon finished praying, fire came down from the sky and consumed the burnt offering and sacrifices, and the LORD’s glory filled the Temple. 2The priests couldn’t go in because of it. 3When the Israelites saw the fire and the LORD’s glory come down on the Temple, they bowed down on the pavement with their faces to the ground in worship and praised him, “He’s truly good; his love endures forever.”

4Then the king and the people sacrificed to the LORD 522,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep. That’s how he and the people dedicated God’s Temple. 6The priests and Levites stood at their positions with the musical instruments King David had made for praising the LORD—“his love endures forever”—whenever he gave praise by their means, while the priests on the other side blew trumpets, and Israel stood. 7Solomon consecrated the middle of the court in front of the LORD’s Temple, because that’s where he offered the burnt offerings and the fat of the peace offerings, and because the bronze altar he’d made couldn’t hold the burnt offering, grain offering, and fat.	 2 Ch 7:1-7

8Solomon and all Israel observed the festival for a week, a huge assembly from Lebo-hamath to the River of Egypt. 9They observed the dedication of the altar, kept the festival, and held a solemn assembly on the eighth day. 10The twenty-third day, seventh month, Solomon sent the people home, celebrating and happy over the LORD’s goodness to David, Solomon, and his people.

The LORD’s Response to Solomon

11Solomon finished the LORD’s Temple, the king’s palace, and everything he’d planned to do with them. 12Then the LORD appeared to him at night and said,

“I’ve heard your prayer, and I’ve chosen this place as a temple for sacrificing. 13If I shut up the sky so there’s no rain, or command locusts to devour the land, or send a plague among my people, 14and they humble themselves and pray, I’ll hear from heaven, forgive their sin, and restore their land. 15My eyes will be open and my ears attentive to prayers offered here. 16I’ve chosen and consecrated this Temple so my name will be here permanently. 17If yousg conduct yourself like your father and do everything I’ve commanded you and keep my statutes and ordinances, 18I’ll make your throne secure like I agreed with David to do, ‘You’ll always have a descendant on Israel’s throne if they follow my Law like you have.’

19“But if youpl leave my statutes and commandments and worship and serve other gods, 20I’ll uproot you from the country I’ve given you and throw aside this Temple I’ve consecrated to me. I’ll make it an object of mockery, a byword the world over. 21Everybody that goes by will be amazed at this Temple that had been so highly praised, ‘Why has the LORD done such a thing to this country and this Temple?’ 22People will answer, ‘They abandoned the LORD God who brought their ancestors out of Egypt. They adopted other gods, worshiped and served them.’”   	       2 Ch 7:8-22

Solomon’s Other Activities

8:1At the end of the 20 years it took Solomon to build the LORD’s Temple and his own palace, 2he rebuilt the towns Hiram had given him and settled Israelites in them. 3Then he captured Hamath-zobah 4and built Tadmor in the open country and storage cities in Hamath. 5He built Upper and Lower Beth-horon, fortified towns with walls, gates, and bars. 6He built Baalath, the storage cities he had, towns for his chariots and cavalry, and everything he delighted to build in Jerusalem, Lebanon, and the rest of the territory he ruled.

7The people left over from the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who weren’t Israelites 8the Israelites hadn’t destroyed, Solomon has made forced laborers ever since. 9He didn’t make slaves out of Israelites for his work. They were soldiers, chief captains, and commanders of his chariots and cavalry. 10Solomon had 250 chief officers that oversaw the people. 11Then he brought Pharaoh’s daughter up from The City of David to the palace he’d built for her, because he said, “My wife won’t live in David’s palace, because the places are holy where the LORD’s Ark has been.”	2 Ch 8:1-11

12Then Solomon offered burnt offerings on the altar he’d built in front of the vestibule. 13He followed the daily rule, offering them according to the commandment of Moses for Sabbaths, new moons, and the three annual festivals: The Festival of Unleavened Bread, The Festival of Weeks, and The Festival of Booths.

14He followed David’s ordinance and appointed the priestly divisions for their service: the Levites for their duties of praise and serving in the presence of the priests by the daily rule; the gatekeepers by their divisions at every gate. 15They kept his commandments to the priests and Levites about the treasuries.

16Solomon carried out his work from the day he laid the foundation of the LORD’s Temple till he finished it. 17Then he went to Ezion-geber and Eloth on the shore in Edom. 18By his own officers, Hiram sent him ships and sailors that knew the sea. They went with Solomon’s servants to Ophir and brought back 17 tons 450 talents of gold.	2 Ch 8:12-18

The Queen of Sheba Visits Solomon

9:1When the queen of Sheba heard about Solomon, she came to Jerusalem to test him with hard questions. She brought a large contingent of camels carrying spices, and lots of gold and precious stones. When she got there, she talked to him about everything on her mind. 2He answered her questions; there wasn’t anything he couldn’t explain to her. 3When she’d seen his wisdom, the palace he’d built, 4the food at his table, the seating of his officials, the attendance by his servers and their attire, his cupbearers and their attire, the stairway he used to go up to the LORD’s Temple, she was breathless,

5“The report was true that I heard in my country about your words and wisdom. 6But I didn’t believe it till I saw it. They didn’t tell me half of it. 7How fortunate your officers must feel, being around you continually and listening to your wisdom. 8Bless the LORD your God that delighted in you and set you on his throne. He loved Israel and established the nation permanently; that’s why he made you their king—to do justice and goodness.” 	2 Ch 9:1-8

9She gave him 4½ tons 120 talents of gold and a large amount of spices and precious stones. There’d never been spices like what she gave him. 10Then Hiram and Solomon’s crews brought gold from Ophir plus algum wood and precious stones. 11From the algum wood he made steps for the LORD’s Temple and the king’s palace as well as lyres and harps for the singers. Nobody in Judah had ever seen anything like them. 12King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba everything she asked for—more than what she’d brought him. Then she and her attendants went back to her country.	 2 Ch 9:9-12

Solomon’s Wealth and Spendor

13The weight of gold that came to Solomon each year was 25 tons 666 talents 14besides what traders and merchants brought, and besides the gold and silver the kings of Arabia and the governors of the country brought. 15King Solomon made 200 large shields of beaten gold, using 15 lbs 600 shekels of beaten gold on each one. 16He made 300 shields of beaten gold, using 300 gold shekels on each one. He put them in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon. 17He made a large throne out of ivory and overlaid it with pure gold. 18It had 6 steps leading up to it, a gold footstool attached to it, arms on each side of the seat, and 2 lions standing beside the arms. 1912 lions stood on opposite sides of the 6 steps. Nothing like it was ever made for any other kingdom. 20King Solomon’s drinking cups were made out of gold. The items for the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon were pure gold. Silver wasn’t considered valuable in his time. 21He had ships that went to Tarshish every three years with Hiram’s sailors, and brought back gold, silver, ivory, apes and peacocks.	 2 Ch 9:13-21

22King Solomon became greater than any other king anywhere in wealth and wisdom. 23Kings from all over the world wanted to be around him to hear the wisdom God put in him. 24Each one brought his gift: silver and gold articles, clothes, weapons, spices, horses, and mules—so much a year.

25Solomon had 4,000 stalls for horses and chariots and 12,000 cavalry. He stationed them in the chariot cities and with him in Jerusalem. 26He ruled the kings from the Euphrates River to the Philistine border and the border of Egypt. 27He made silver as common as stones in Jerusalem and made cedars as plentiful as sycamores in the western foothills. 28They brought horses for Solomon from Egypt and every country.

Summary of Solomon’s Reign

29The rest of the acts of Solomon, first to last, are recorded in The Chronicles of Nathan the Prophet, The Prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and The Visions of Iddo the Seer about Jeroboam son of Nebat. 30He ruled for 40 years in Jerusalem over all Israel. 31He died and they buried him in The City of David. His son Rehoboam reigned.	 2 Ch 9:22-31

The Northern Tribes Revolt

10:1Then Rehoboam went to Shechem, because Israel had come to Shechem to make him king. 2When Jeroboam heard about it, he came back. (He was in Egypt where he’d fled from Solomon.) 3They sent for him. When Jeroboam and all Israel came, they said to Rehoboam, 4“Your father made our yoke heavy. Lighten his hard service and the heavy yoke he put on us, and we’ll serve you.”

5“Come back in three days.”

The people left.

6He consulted the elders that had served his father Solomon, “How do you advise me to answer the people?”

7“If you’ll be kind to them, please them, and speak good words to them, they’ll serve you permanently.”

8But he disregarded their advice and consulted the young men he grew up with and served him. 9He asked them, “What’s your advice?”

10“Tell them, ‘My little finger is thicker than my father’s thighs! 11He loaded you with a heavy yoke; I’ll make it heavier. He disciplined you with whips; I’ll discipline you with scorpions.’”	2 Ch 10:1-11

12Jeroboam and the people came to Rehoboam on the third day like he’d directed them. 13The king answered them harshly and didn’t take the elders’ advice. 14“My father made your yoke heavy; I’ll make it heavier. My father disciplined you with whips; I’ll discipline you with scorpions.” 15He ignored the people, a turn of events the LORD allowed with the result that he would bring about his message through Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam.

16When Israel saw that the king didn’t listen to them, they answered,

“What part do we have with David?

What inheritance do we have in Jesse’s son?

Everybody, go home, Israel!”

Look after your own house, David!”

Israel left and went home. 17But Rehoboam ruled the Israelites in the towns in Judah. 18He sent Hadoram, who oversaw forced labor, and the Israelites stoned him to death. King Rehoboam hurried and got in his chariot and fled to Jerusalem. 19Israel has been in rebellion against David’s dynasty ever since.    	2 Ch 10:12-19

Shemaiah’s Prophecy

11:1When Rehoboam got to Jerusalem, he gathered 180,000 soldiers from Judah and Benjamin to fight Israel to restore the kingdom to himself. 2But a message from the LORD came to Shemaiah, the man of God,

3“Tell Rehoboam and all Israel in Judah and Benjamin, 4‘The LORD says, “Don’t fight your kin. Go back home. I’m going to let this happen.”’”

They listened to him and went back from attacking Jeroboam.

5-10Rehoboam lived in Jerusalem and built fortified towns for defense in Judah and Benjamin: Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa, Beth-zur, Soco, Adullam, Gath, Mareshah, Ziph, 9Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah, 10Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron. 11He reinforced the fortresses and put officers in them along with stores of food, olive oil, and wine. 12He put shields and spears in every city and reinforced them greatly. He held onto Judah and Benjamin. 	2 Ch 11:1-12

13The priests and Levites throughout Israel stood with him from all their districts. 14The Levites abandoned their pastures and property and came to Judah and Jerusalem, because Jeroboam and his sons had excluded them from serving as priests to the LORD. 15He set up his own priests for the high places, satyrs, and calves he’d made. 16People from all the tribes that set their hearts on looking to the LORD God of Israel, followed the priests and Levites to Jerusalem to sacrifice to the LORD God of their ancestors. 17They strengthened the kingdom of Judah and supported Rehoboam for three years; they followed the way of David and Solomon.

Rehoboam’s Family

18Then Rehoboam married Mahalath daughter of Jerimoth son of David and Abihail daughter of Jesse’s son Eliab. 19She bore him Jeush, Shemariah, and Zaham. 20After her, he married Absalom’s daughter Maacah. She bore him Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith. 21Rehoboam loved Maacah more than his other wives and concubines. He’d married 18 wives and 60 concubines and fathered 28 sons and 60 daughters. 22He appointed Abijah as leader among his brothers because he intended to make him king. 23He acted wisely and distributed some of his sons throughout Judah and Benjamin in the fortified towns, and gave them food in abundance, and sought many wives for them.	    2 Ch 11:13-23

Shishak [Shoshenq I] Invades Judah

12:1When Rehoboam’s kingdom got secure and strong, he and Israel turned away from the Law of the LORD. 2In his fifth year, because they weren’t faithful to the LORD, Shishak [Shoshenq I], king of Egypt, came up against Jerusalem 3with 1,200 chariots and 60,000 cavalry. The Lybians, Sukkites, and Nubians came with him without number. 4He captured the fortified towns in Judah and advanced to Jerusalem. 5Then Shemaiah the prophet came to Rehoboam and Judah’s officials that had fled to Jerusalem to escape Shishak, “The LORD says you’ve left him, so he’s left you to Shishak.” 6The officials of Israel and the king humbled themselves, “The LORD is good.”

7When the LORD saw that, he told Shemaiah,

“They’ve humbled themselves, so I won’t destroy them. I’ll grant them some measure of deliverance and not pour out my anger on Jerusalem by Shishak. 8But they’ll become his slaves so they’ll learn the difference between serving me and serving other countries.” 	2 Ch 12:1-8

9Shishak [Shoshenq I] came up against Jerusalem and took the treasures out of LORD’s Temple and the king’s palace. He took everything, including the gold shields Solomon had made. 10King Rehoboam made bronze shields to replace them and committed them to the commanders of the guard that guarded the king’s palace. 11As often as the king went into the LORD’s Temple, the guards would carry them and then bring them back to the guard room. 12When he humbled himself, the LORD turned his anger away, so he didn’t destroy him completely. Conditions in Judah were tolerable.

13King Rehoboam strengthened himself in Jerusalem. He was 41 when he began to rule, and he ruled for 17 years in the city where the LORD had chosen to identify with. Rehoboam’s mother was Naamah the Ammonitess. 14He did evil because he didn’t set his heart to look to the LORD. 15The acts of Rehoboam, first to last, are recorded in The Chronicles of Shemaiah the Prophet and The Chronicles of Iddo the Seer by genealogical enrollment. There was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam constantly. 16Rehoboam died and they buried him in The City of David, and his son Abijah became king.	     2 Ch 12:9-16

Abijah Rules Judah

13:1In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam, Abijah became king in Judah. 2He ruled for 3 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Micaiah, daughter of Uriel of Gibeah. War arose between Abijah and Jeroboam. 3Abijah entered the battle with 400,000 trained soldiers; Jeroboam drew up in battle formation against him with 800,000 trained soldiers.	 2 Ch 13:1-3

4Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim in the hill country of Ephraim and shouted,

“Jeroboam and all Israel, 5don’t you know that the LORD God of Israel gave the rule over Israel permanently to David and his descendants by a covenant of salt? 6Yet Jeroboam rebelled against him. 7Worthless men gathered around him, scoundrels that proved to be too strong for the son of Solomon when he was young and timid and couldn’t hold his own against them. 8So now you intend to resist the kingdom of the LORD by the descendants of David because you have a big army and the golden calves Jeroboam made as your gods. 9Haven’t you driven out the LORD’s priests, the descendants of Aaron and the Levites, and made your own priests like people in other countries? Whoever comes to consecrate himself with a young bull and seven rams, can become a priest for what aren’t gods. 10The LORD is our God. We haven’t left him. The descendants of Aaron are serving him as priests and the Levites are doing their work. 11Every morning they burn burnt offerings and fragrant incense to him. They set the showbread on the clean table, and the golden lampstand with its lamps is ready to light every evening, because we’re keeping the charge of the LORD our God. But you’ve left him. 12God is at our head and his priests with the signal bugles to sound the alarm against you, Israel. Don’t fight with the LORD God of your ancestors; you won’t prevail.”	 2 Ch 13:4-12

13But Jeroboam had set an ambush from the rear, so Israel lay in front of Judah and behind. 14When Judah turned around, Israel attacked them from the front and back. Israel cried out to the LORD, the priests blew the bugles, 15and Judah’s soldiers raised the battle cry. When they did, God routed Jeroboam and Israel in front of Abijah and Judah. 16When the Israelites fled, God delivered them to Judah. 17Abijah and his army defeated them with a massacre of 500,000 elite troops. 18Israel was subdued because Judah trusted in the LORD. 19Abijah chased Jeroboam and captured several towns: Bethel, Jeshanah, and Ephron with their villages. 20Jeroboam didn’t regain strength during Abijah’s reign. The LORD struck him, and he died.

21Abijah became more powerful and took 14 wives and became father of 22 sons and 16 daughters. 22The rest of the acts of Abijah, his ways and words, are recorded in The Account of the Prophet Iddo.	 2 Ch 13:13-22

14:1When Abijah died, they buried him in The City of David, and his son Asa became king. The country had peace for 10 years.

Asa Rules Judah

2Asa did what was good. 3He removed the foreign altars and high places, tore down the scared pillars, cut down the Asherah poles, 4and commanded Judah to look to the LORD God of their ancestors and to observe the Law and the commandments. 5He removed the high places and incense altars from the towns in Judah. 6He built fortified towns in Judah since the LORD had given the country rest. 7He said to Judah,

“Let’s build these towns and surround them with walls and towers, gates and bars. The country is still ours because we’ve sought the LORD, and he’s given us rest all around.”

They built and prospered. 8Asa had a standing army of 300,000 from Judah that carried spears and large shields and 280,000 from Benjamin that carried shields and handled bows—fearless soldiers.	2 Ch 14:1-8

9Now Zerah the Nubian came out against them at Mareshah with 1,000,000 men and 300 chariots. 10Asa went out to engage him. They drew up in battle formation in the Valley of Zaphathah at Mareshah. 11Asa called to the LORD,

“No one but you can help us in this battle of the weak against the strong. You’re our God. Help us against this army. Don’t let any mortal prevail against you.”

12The LORD routed the Nubians in front of Asa and Judah. 13Asa and the people chased them as far as Gerar. So many Nubians fell that they couldn’t recover. The LORD and his army shattered them. Judah carried away a lot of plunder. 14They destroyed the towns around Gerar because the dread of the LORD had fallen on them. They plundered them all, a lot of plunder. 15They also struck down the livestock owners and took away large numbers of sheep and camels. Then they went back to Jerusalem.	      2 Ch 14:9-15

Asa’s Reforms

15:1The Spirit of God came on Azariah son of Oded, 2and he went out to meet Asa,

“Listen, Asa, Judah, and Benjamin, the LORD is with you when you’re with him. If you look for him, he’ll let you find him. If you leave him, he’ll leave you. 3For a long time Israel was without the true God, without a teaching priest, without law. 4But in their distress they turned to the LORD and looked for him, and he let them find him. 5In those times, there wasn’t any peace to the ones who traveled; disturbances troubled the people in many countries. 6Nation crushed nation, city crushed city, because God distressed them with all kinds of problems. 7But you, be strong. Don’t lose courage; there’s reward for your work.”

8When Asa heard Azariah’s prophecy, he gathered the courage to remove the detestable idols from Judah and Benjamin and the towns he’d captured in the hill country of Ephraim. He restored the LORD’s altar that was in front of the vestibule. 9He gathered Judah, Benjamin, and people from Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon that lived with them; because many had defected to him from Israel when they saw the LORD was with him. 10They came together at Jerusalem in the third month of Asa’s fifteenth year. 11That day they sacrificed 700 oxen and 7,000 sheep from the spoils they’d brought. 12They entered into a covenant to look to the LORD God of their ancestors with all their heart and soul. 13Whoever wouldn’t look to him would be executed, man or woman, great or small. 14In addition, they shouted an oath to the LORD with trumpets and rams’ horns. 15Judah celebrated the oath, because they’d sworn with all their heart and sought him earnestly, and he let them find him. The LORD gave them rest in every direction.  2 Ch 15:1-15

16Asa even removed his mother Maacah from being queen mother, because she’d set up a detestable Asherah pole. Asa cut it down, pulverized it, and burned it at the Brook Kidron. 17He did not remove the high places from Israel, but his heart was blameless his whole life. 18He brought to God’s Temple his and his fathers’ dedicated things: silver, gold, and various items. 19There wasn’t any war till his thirty-fifth year.	 2 Ch 15:16-19

Asa’s Final Years

16:1In the thirty-sixth year of Asa’s reign, Baasha, king of Israel, came up against Judah and fortified Ramah to prevent anyone from going out or coming in to Asa. 2Asa brought out silver and gold from the treasuries of the LORD’s Temple and the king’s palace, and sent them to Benhadad, king of Aram, who lived in Damascus, and said, 3“Let’s make a treaty between us, like the one between our fathers. I’ve sent you silver and gold; go break your treaty with Baasha so he’ll withdraw from me.” 4Benhadad listened and sent his armies against the towns in Israel. They conquered Ijon, Dan, Abel-maim, and the store towns in Naphtali. 5When Baasha heard about it, he stopped fortifying Ramah. 6Then King Asa brought Judah, and they carried away the stones and timber from Ramah that Baasha had been using, and with them Asa fortified Geba and Mizpah. 	2 Ch 16:1-6

7At that time, Hanani the seer came to Asa,

“Because you’ve relied on the king of Aram instead of me, his army has escaped. 8Weren’t the Nubians and Lybians an immense army with lots of chariots and cavalry? Yet because you relied on the LORD, he delivered them to you. 9His eyes scan over the world so he can strongly support the ones whose hearts are completely his. You’ve acted foolishly in this. From now on you’ll have wars.”

10Asa was mad at the seer for saying that and put him in stocks in prison. At the same time, he perpetrated cruelties on some of the people.

11The acts of Asa, first to last, are recorded in The Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel. 12In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa got a serious infection in his feet; yet even in his disease he didn’t look to the LORD but to doctors. 13He died in the forty-first year of his reign. 14They buried him in a tomb he’d hewn out for himself in The City of David. They laid him on a bier he’d filled with various spices prepared by incense makers. They built a big fire in his honor.	2 Ch 16:7-14

Jehoshaphat Rules Judah

17:1His son Jehoshaphat became king and secured his position against Israel. 2He placed troops in Judah’s fortified towns and set garrisons in Judah and the towns in Ephraim his father had captured. 3The LORD was with him because he followed his ancestor David’s earlier days and didn’t look to the images of Baal. 4He sought his father’s God, followed his commandments, and didn’t do like Israel. 5The LORD secured the kingdom under him, Judah brought tributes to him, and he had great wealth and honor. 6He took pride in the ways of the LORD and removed again the high places and Asherah poles from Judah.

7In his third year, he sent his officials Benhail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethanel, and Micaiah to teach in the towns in Judah. 8He sent with them Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tobadonijah, who were Levites, and with them the priests Elishama and Jehoram. 9They taught the people throughout Judah, having the Book of the Law with them. 	2 Ch 17:1-9

10The kingdoms around Judah dreaded the LORD; so they didn’t start any wars with Jehoshaphat. 11Some Philistines brought him gifts and silver as tribute. The Arabians brought him 7,700 rams and 7,700 male goats. 12He grew greater and greater, and built fortresses and store towns in Judah. 13He had large supplies in the towns in Judah and trained soldiers in Jerusalem. 14This was their muster according to their families:

Judah had commanders of thousands; Adnah was the commander with 300,000 soldiers. 15Beside him was Johanan the commander with 280,000.

16Beside him was Amasiah son of Zichri, who volunteered for the LORD, with 200,000

trained soldiers.

17In Benjamin, Eliada a fearless soldier, had 200,000 armed with bow and shield.

18Beside him was Jehozabad with 180,000 equipped for war.

19Those served the king, not counting the ones he put in the fortified towns all around Judah.

2 Ch 17:10-19

Jehoshaphat and Ahab

18:1Jehoshaphat had great wealth and honor, and allied himself by marriage with Ahab. 2Some years later he went down to visit Ahab in Samaria. Ahab slaughtered lots of sheep and oxen for him and the people with him, and induced him to go up against Ramoth-gilead. 3He asked Jehoshaphat, “Will you go with me against Ramoth-gilead?”

He told him, “I’m like you, my people like yours. We’ll go with you into the battle.”

4In addition, he said, “First let’s ask for a message from the LORD.” 5He gathered the prophets, 400 men, and asked, “Should we attack Ramoth-gilead?” They said, “Go up. God will deliver it to you.”

6But Jehoshaphat asked, “Isn’t there still a prophet of the LORD here that we can ask?”

7Ahab told him, “There’s one, Micaiah son of Imla, but I despise the guy; he never prophesies anything good about me.”

But Jehoshaphat said, “Don’t say that.” 	2 Ch 18:1-7

8The king of Israel called an officer and said, “Quick, bring Micaiah, Imla’s son.”

Micaiah’s Prophecy Against Ahab

9The two kings were sitting on their thrones, arrayed in their robes, at the threshing floor by the entrance to the gate of Samaria, and the prophets were prophesying in front of them. 10Zedekiah son of Chenaanah made iron horns and said, “The LORD says you’ll gore the Arameans with these till they’re consumed.” 11The prophets kept prophesying, “Go up to Ramoth-gilead and prevail. The LORD will deliver it to you.”

12The messenger that went to summon Micaiah told him, “The prophets are all speaking favorably for the king; so please say what they’re saying.”

13“As sure as the LORD lives, I’ll say what my God says.” 	2 Ch 18:8-13

14When he came, the king said, “Should we attack Ramoth-gilead?”

“Go right on up there! Prevail! The LORD’s going deliver it to you for sure!!”

15The king said, “How many times do I have to demand that you not tell me anything but the truth in the LORD’s name?”

16So he said,

“I saw Israel scattered on the mountains

like sheep without a shepherd.

The LORD said,

‘They don’t have a master;

they need to go home in peace.’”

17Ahab said, “Didn’t I tell you he wouldn’t prophesy anything good about me?”

18Micaiah said,

“Listen to the LORD’s message. I saw him sitting on his throne, and the host of heaven was standing on his right and left. 19He said, ‘Who will lure Ahab into going up and falling at Ramoth-gilead?’

“One said one thing, another said another.

20“Then a spirit came forward and said, ‘I’ll do it.’

‘How?’

21‘I’ll be a deceiving spirit in his prophets.’

‘Go do it.’

22The LORD has put a deceiving spirit in your prophets and declared disaster on you.”	2 Ch 18:14-22

23Then Zedekiah son of Chenaanah came and hit Micaiah on the cheek and said, “How did the Spirit of the LORD leave me to speak to you?”

24“You’ll see when you go hide in an inner room.”

25The king said,

“Take Micaiah back to Amon, governor of the city, and to my son Joash. 26Tell them to put him in prison and feed him sparingly with bread and water till I come back safely.”

27Micaiah said, “If you come back safely, the LORD hasn’t spoken by me. You all need to listen.”	2 Ch 18:23-27

Micaiah’s Prophecy Against Ahab

28The king of Israel and Jehoshaphat went on up against Ramoth-gilead. 29Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, “I’ll disguise myself and go into battle, but you put on your robes.” The king disguised himself, and they went into battle. 30The king of Aram had told the captains of his chariots, “Don’t fight anybody great or small, just the king of Israel.” 31When the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, they shouted, “It’s the king of Israel!” They turned aside to attack him. But Jehoshaphat cried out, and the LORD helped him by diverting them away. 32When the captains saw it wasn’t Ahab, they quit chasing him. 33A man drew his bow at random and struck the king of Israel in a joint in the armor. He told the chariot driver, “Turn around, and get me out of the fight. I’m seriously wounded.” 34The battle raged that day, and the king of Israel propped himself up in his chariot in front of the Arameans till evening. He died at sundown.	2 Ch 18:28-34

Jehoshaphat Appoints Judges

19:1Jehoshaphat went back safely to his palace in Jerusalem. 2Jehu son of Hanani the seer went out to meet him and said,

“Should you help the sinful, love the ones that hate the LORD, and bring his wrath on you? 3But there’s some good in you: you’ve removed the Asherah poles from the country and set your heart to look to God.”

4Jehoshaphat lived in Jerusalem, circulated again among the people from Beersheba to the hill country of Ephraim, and brought them back to the LORD God of their ancestors. 5He appointed judges in each fortified city in Judah,

6“Consider what you’re doing. You’re not just judging for people but for the LORD that’s with you. 7Respect him; he won’t take part in sin, partiality, or bribery.”           	2 Ch 19:1-7

8In Jerusalem, Jehoshaphat appointed Levites, priests, and heads of families to judge disputes,

9“Do this in respect for the LORD, faithfully and wholeheartedly. 10Whenever a dispute comes to you from your relatives that live in their towns, between blood and blood, between law and commandment, statutes and ordinances, warn them so they won’t be guilty to the LORD and wrath won’t come on you or them. 11Amariah the chief priest will manage everything that has to do with the LORD. Zebadiah son of Ishmael, ruler of Judah, will manage everything that has to do with the king. The Levites will be officers in your presence. Act resolutely; the LORD be with the godly.” 	2 Ch 19:8-11

Jehoshaphat Defeats Moab and Ammon

20:1After that, the Moabites, Ammonites, and some Meunites came to attack Jehoshaphat. 2Some people brought him a report, “A large army is coming out of Edom from the other side of the sea. They’re in Hazazon-tamar (En-gedi).” 3He was afraid, set himself to look to the LORD, and declared a fast throughout Judah. 4Judah gathered from all the towns to look to the LORD for help.	2 Ch 20:1-4

5Jehoshaphat stood in the assembly of Judah and Jerusalem, in the LORD’s Temple in front of the new court,

6“LORD our ancestors’ God, aren’t you God in the sky? Don’t you rule every nation? You have such power and strength that nobody can stand against you. 7Didn’t you drive out the people in this land, and give it to the descendants of Abraham your friend forever? 8They’ve lived in it, built a sanctuary there for your name, and said, 9‘Should misfortune come on us—the sword, judgment, disease, or famine—we’ll present ourselves at this Temple (because your name is here), and call out to you in our distress. You’ll hear us and deliver us. 10You didn’t let Israel invade the Ammonites, Moabites, or Mount Seir when they came out of Egypt. (They turned aside and didn’t destroy them.) 11Now they’re rewarding us by coming to drive us out of the possession you gave us. 12Our God, won’t you judge them? We’re powerless in the face of such a big army. We don’t know what to do but look to you for help.”  	2 Ch 20:5-12

13All Judah was standing before the LORD with their infants, wives, and children.

14Then in the assembly, the Spirit of the LORD came on Jahaziel son of Zechariah (son of Benaiah son of Jeiel son of Mattaniah the Levite, descendant of Asaph).

15“Listen, Judah, people in Jerusalem, King Jehoshaphat. The LORD says, ‘Don’t be afraid or intimidated by that big army. The battle is not yours but mine. 16Go down against them tomorrow. They’ll come up by the ascent of Ziz. You’ll find them at the end of the valley east of the Wilderness of Jeruel. 17You won’t need to fight in this battle. Take your positions. Stand and watch my salvation for you.’ Don’t be afraid or intimidated. Go out to face them tomorrow; the LORD’s with you.”

18Jehoshaphat bowed to the ground, and Judah and the people in Jerusalem fell down in worship to the LORD. 19The Levites from the Kohathites and Korahites stood up to give loud praise to the LORD God of Israel.	2 Ch 20:13-19

20They got up early the next morning and went out to the Wilderness of Tekoa. As they went, Jehoshaphat stood and said, “Judah and Jerusalem, trust the LORD and you’ll be safe. Trust his prophets and you’ll succeed.” 21When he’d advised the people, he appointed the ones that sang and praised the LORD in holy attire to go out ahead of the army, “Thank the LORD, because his love endures forever.” 22When they began singing and praising, he set ambushes against the Ammonites, Moabites, and Mount Seir; and they were routed. 23The Ammonites and Moabites attacked the people from Mount Seir and destroyed them completely. When they’d finished that, they helped destroy one another.

24When Judah came to the watchtower over the countryside, they looked toward the army. Corpses were lying everywhere; nobody had escaped. 25When Jehoshaphat and his people came to take their spoil, they found lots of equipment, clothes, and valuable things, more than they could carry. They gathered spoil for three days, there was so much of it. 26On the fourth day, they met in the Valley of Beracah to “bless” the LORD. That’s still its name. 27Everyonem in Judah and Jerusalem came back happy with Jehoshaphat in the lead, because the LORD made them celebrate over their enemies. 28They came to Jerusalem to the Temple with harps, lyres, and trumpets. 29All the kingdoms dreaded God when they heard that he had fought Israel’s enemies. 30Jehoshaphat’s kingdom had peace because his God gave him rest in every direction.             	2 Ch 20:20-30

Summary of Jehoshaphat’s Reign

31Jehoshaphat was 35 when he became king and ruled Judah in Jerusalem for 25 years. His mother was Azubah daughter of Shilhi. 32He followed the way of his father Asa. He did what was good, 33but he didn’t take away the high places. The people hadn’t yet directed their hearts to their ancestors’ God. 34The rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, first to last, are recorded in The Chronicles of Jehu son of Hanani and The Book of the Kings of Israel.

35After that, Jehoshaphat allied himself with Ahaziah, king of Israel. That was a bad decision. 36He did it to build ships in Ezion-geber for going to Tarshish. 37Then Eliezer son of Dodavahu from Mareshah prophesied against him, “Because you’ve allied yourself with Ahaziah, the LORD has destroyed what you’ve built.”	2 Ch 20:31-37

Jehoram Rules Judah

21:1Jehoshaphat died, and they buried him in The City of David. His son Jehoram became king. 2His brothers were Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariyahu, Michael, and Shephatiah. 3Their father had given them many gifts of silver, gold, and other precious things along with fortified towns in Judah. But he gave the kingdom to Jehoram, his firstborn.

4When Jehoram had taken over the kingdom and made himself secure, he killed his brothers with the sword and some of the rulers too. 5He was 32 when he became king and ruled for 8 years in Jerusalem. 6He followed the ways of Israel’s kings like Ahab did. (His wife was Ahab’s daughter.) He did evil, 7but because of his covenant with David, the LORD wouldn’t destroy David’s house. He’d promised to give him and his descendants a lamp permanently.

2 Ch 21:1-7

8During his reign Edom revolted and set up its own king. 9So Jehoram crossed over with his commanders and all his chariots. He got up at night and struck down the Edomites and the commanders of the chariots that were surrounding him. 10But Edom is still independent from Judah.

Libnah revolted at the same time because Jehoram had left the LORD God of his ancestors. 11Besides, he made high places in the mountains in Judah, and led the people in Jerusalem to carry on religious prostitution.

12Elijah the prophet sent him a letter:

“The LORD, God of your ancestor David, says, ‘You’ve not followed the ways of Jehoshaphat your father and Asa king of Judah. 13You’ve followed the kings of Israel and made Judah and Israel carry on religious prostitution like Ahab’s house did. You’ve even killed your own brothers, who were better than you. 14I’m going to strike your people, your sons, your wives, and everything you own with catastrophe. 15You’ll suffer with a severe intestinal disease till your bowels come out.’”	2 Ch 21:8-15

16Then the LORD stirred up the Philistines and Arabs that bordered the Nubians. 17They invaded Judah and carried away everything in the king’s palace, including his sons and wives. He didn’t have any son left except Jehoahaz, the youngest.

18In addition, the LORD struck him with an incurable disease. 19In two years, his bowels came out, and he died in severe pain. His people built no fire for him like they did for his ancestors. 20He died with nobody’s regret. They buried him in The City of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.	2 Ch 21:16-20

Ahaziah Rules Judah

22:1Then the people in Jerusalem made Ahaziah/Jehoahaz, his youngest son, king. The band of men that came with the Arabs to the camp had killed the older sons. 2Ahaziah was 22 and ruled for 1 year in Jerusalem. His mother was Athaliah, granddaughter of Omri. 3To his destruction, he also followed Ahab’s practices because his mother gave him bad advice. 4He sinned in 5going with Jehoram son of Ahab to fight Hazael, king of Aram, at Ramoth-gilead. But the Arameans wounded Joram/Jehoram. 6He came back to heal in Jezreel from his wounds at Ramah. Ahaziah son of Joram/Jehoram king of Judah went down to see Joram/Jehoram in Jezreel because he was wounded.	 2 Ch 22:1-6

7The destruction of Ahaziah was from God for going to Joram/Jehoram. He went out with Jehoram against Jehu son of Nimshi that the LORD had anointed to eliminate Ahab’s family. 8When Jehu was executing judgment on that family, he found Judah’s officials and the sons of Ahaziah’s brothers serving Ahaziah and killed them. 9His men also looked for Ahaziah and caught him hiding in Samaria. They brought him to Jehu, put him to death, and buried him; because they said, “He is the son of Jehoshaphat, who sought the LORD with all his heart.” There wasn’t anybody from Ahaziah’s family capable of ruling the kingdom.

Queen Athaliah Rules Judah

10When his mother Athaliah saw he was dead, she killed the royal offspring in Judah. 11But Jehoshabeath, King Joram/Jehoram’s daughter, stole Ahaziah’s son Joash from among the king’s sons—who were being murdered—and placed him and his nurse in a bedroom. Jehoshabeath, wife of Jehoiada the priest and Ahaziah’s sister, hid him so Athaliah couldn’t kill him. 12They hid him in God’s Temple for 6 years while Athaliah ruled the country. 	2 Ch 22:7-12

Revolt Against Athaliah

23:1In the seventh year, Jehoiada summoned the courage to make a pact with the commanders of hundreds: Azariah son of Joram/Jeroham, Ishmael son of Johanan, Azariah son of Obed, Maaseiah son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat son of Zichri. 2They gathered to Jerusalem the Levites from the towns in Judah and the heads of families. 3When the assembly made a pact with the king in God’s Temple, Jehoiada told them,

“The king’s son will reign like the LORD has said regarding David’s descendants. 4A third of you, priests and Levites that come in on the Sabbath, will be gatekeepers. 5A third will be at the king’s palace, and a third at the Foundation Gate. The people will be in the courts of the Temple. 6Don’t let anybody go into the Temple except the priests and servicing Levites. They can go in because they’re holy. Have the people keep the charge of the LORD. 7The Levites will surround the king with weapons in hand. Kill whoever comes into the Temple. Be with the king when he comes in and goes out.”

8The Levites and Judah did what he said. Each one brought his men that were to come in on the Sabbath with the ones that were to go out on the Sabbath, because Jehoiada didn’t dismiss any of the divisions. 9Jehoiada gave the commanders of hundreds King David’s spears and large and small shields that were in the Temple. 10He stationed the men around the king from the south side of the Temple to the north, near the altar. 11Then they brought out the king’s son, put the crown on him, gave him the Testimony, and declared him king. Jehoiada and his sons anointed him and said, “Long live the king!”	2 Ch 23:1-11

The Death of Athaliah

12When Athaliah heard people running and praising the king, she came into the Temple. 13She saw the king standing by his pillar at the entrance, and the commanders and trumpeters beside him. The common people were celebrating and blowing trumpets. The singers with their musical instruments were leading the praise. She tore her clothes, “Treason! Treason!” 14Jehoiada brought out the commanders over the army and told them, “Bring her out between the ranks and put to death with a sword anybody that tries to rescue her.” The priests said, “Don’t do it in the Temple.” 15They seized her, and when she got to the entrance of the Horse Gate of the king’s palace, they put her to death.	 2 Ch 23:12-15

Jehoiadah’s Reforms

16Jehoiada made a covenant with the people and the king that they’d be the LORD’s people. 17The people tore down Baal’s temple, broke his altars and images into pieces, and killed Mattan his priest by the altars. 18He placed the officers of the Temple under the Levitical priests that David had assigned over the Temple, as written in the Law of Moses—with celebration and singing according to David’s order. 19He stationed gatekeepers for the Temple so nobody ceremonially unclean could go in. 20He took the commanders of hundreds, the nobles, rulers of the people, and common people, and brought the king down from the LORD’s Temple through the upper gate to the king’s palace and placed him on the throne. 21So the people celebrated, and the city grew quiet because they’d put Athaliah to death with a sword. 	2 Ch 23:16-21

Joash Repairs the Temple

24:1Joash was 7 when he became king and ruled for 40 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Zibiah from Beersheba. 2He did what was good all the time Jehoiada was alive. 3Jehoiada took two wives for him, and he became the father of sons and daughters.

4After that, Joash decided to restore the LORD’s Temple. 5He gathered the priests and Levites, and said, “Go out to the towns in Judah and collect money to repair your God’s Temple annually; do it right away.” But the Levites didn’t act right away. 6He summoned Jehoiada the chief priest, “Why haven’t you required the Levites to bring in from Judah and Jerusalem the tax Moses laid on Israel for the Tent of Testimony?” 7The sons of Athaliah had broken into God’s Temple and used the holy things for the images of Baal.	2 Ch 24:1-7

8The king had them make a chest to set outside by the gate into the Temple. 9They made a proclamation in Judah and Jerusalem to bring to the LORD the tax Moses had levied in the desert. 10The officers and common people celebrated and brought in their levies and dropped them in the chest till they’d finished. 11Whenever the Levites saw there was a lot in the chest, they‘d bring it to the king’s officer, and his secretary and the chief priest’s officer would empty it and take it back to its place. They did that daily and collected a lot of money. 12The king and Jehoiada gave it to the ones that serviced the Temple. They hired masons, carpenters, and artisans in iron and bronze to repair the Temple, 13and the work progressed. They restored it to its specifications and reinforced it. 14When they finished, they brought the rest of the money to the king and Jehoiada. They made it into utensils for the Temple, for its service, the burnt offering, gold and silver pans and utensils. They offered burnt offerings continually all the time Jehoiada was alive. 	2 Ch 24:8-14

15Jehoiada died at the good old age of 130. 16They buried him in The City of David among the kings because he’d done well in Israel for God and his Temple.

Jehoiadah’s Reforms Reversed

17But after Jehoiada’s death, the officials of Judah came and bowed to the king, and he listened to them. 18They abandoned the Temple of the LORD God and worshiped Asherah poles and idols. So wrath came on Judah and Jerusalem. 19He sent prophets to bring them back to him, but they wouldn’t listen. 20Then God’s Spirit of God came on Zechariah son of Jehoiada the priest. He stood above the people and said, “God says, ‘Why do you sin against the LORD’s commands and not prosper? Because you’ve left him, he’s left you.’” 21They plotted against him, and at the king’s command stoned him to death in the Temple court; 22so Joash the king didn’t remember the kindness Zechariah’s father Jehoiada had shown him; he murdered his son. As he died, he said, “May the LORD see and repay you!”          	2 Ch 24:15-22

The End of Joash’s Reign

23At the turn of the year, the Aramean army came up against him. They came to Judah and Jerusalem, killed the people’s officials, and sent their spoil to the king in Damascus. 24Though the Arameans came with a small army, the LORD delivered a large army to them because they’d left him. They carried out judgment on Joash.

25They left him seriously wounded. When they’d gone, his own officials plotted against him for murdering Jehoiada’s son. They assassinated him in his bed and buried him in The City of David, but not in the tombs of the kings. 26The ones that plotted against him were Zabad son of Shimeath the Ammonitess and Jehozabad son of Shimrith the Moabitess. 27The Commentary on the Book of the King gives accounts about his sons, the many oracles against him, and the restoration of God’s Temple. His son Amaziah became king.	    2 Ch 24:23-27

Amaziah Rules Judah

25:1Amaziah was 25 and ruled for 29 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jehoaddan of Jerusalem. 2He did what was good, but not with all his heart. 3As soon as his kingdom was firmly in hand, he executed the officials that had assassinated his father. 4He didn’t put their children to death, like the LORD commanded in the Law of Moses: “Don’t execute parents for offspring or offspring for parents. Execute each person for that person’s sin.”

5Amaziah gathered Judah and appointed them according to their families under commanders of thousands and hundreds throughout Judah and Benjamin. He took a census of men 20 and older and found 300,000 elite men, fit for war and handling spear and shield. 6He hired 100,000 trained soldiers out of Israel for 7550 lbs 100 talents of silver. 7But a man of God came to him and said,

“Don’t let Israel’s army go with you; the LORD is not with Israel or Ephraim. 8Even if you go strong into the battle, God will still make you stumble in front of the enemy. He has power to help or hinder.”

9Amaziah said, “But what will we do for the 7550 lbs 100 talents of silver I’ve given Israel’s troops?”

The man of God answered, “The LORD has a lot more to give you than that.”

10Amaziah dismissed the troops from Ephraim, and they went home disgruntled. 	2 Ch 25:1-10

11Amaziah gathered his courage, led his people to the Valley of Salt, and struck down 10,000 people from Seir. 12Judah also captured 10,000 alive and brought them to the top of the cliff. They threw them down to their death. 13But Israel’s troops that Amaziah sent back, raided the towns in Judah between Beth-horon and Samaria, struck down 3,000 of them, and plundered a lot of spoil.

14After Amaziah came from slaying the Edomites, he brought the gods from Seir. He set them up as gods, bowed to them, and burned incense to them. 15The LORD’s anger burned against him. He sent him a prophet, “Why seek gods that haven’t delivered their own people from you?”

2 Ch 25:11-15

16As he was talking to him, the king said, “Did we appoint you a royal advisor? Shut up! Why get struck down?”

The prophet stopped and said, “God has planned to destroy you because you’ve done that and ignored my advice.”

17Amaziah took counsel and sent to Joash (son of Jehoahaz son of Jehu, king of Israel), “Come. Let’s face each other.”

18Joash sent back to him,

“A thistle in Lebanon sent to a cedar in Lebanon, ‘Give your daughter to my son in marriage.’ But a wild animal in Lebanon passed by and tramped down the thistle. 19You said, ‘I’ve defeated Edom.’ You’ve become proud. Stay home. Why stir up trouble to make yourself and Judah fall?” 	2 Ch 25:16-19

20But Amaziah ignored him because it fit with the LORD’s plan to deliver them to Joash because they’d looked to Edom’s gods. 21Joash king of Israel went up and faced Amaziah at Beth-shemesh in Judah. 22He defeated Judah, and they fled to their tents. 23Joash captured Amaziah at Beth-shemesh and took him to Jerusalem. He tore down the wall from the Gate of Ephraim to the Corner Gate, 600ft. 24He took all the gold and silver, the items in God’s Temple with Obed-edom, the treasures of the king’s palace, and hostages too, and went back to Samaria.

25Amaziah lived 15 years after the death of Joash son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel. 26The rest of the acts of Amaziah, first to last, are recorded in The Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel. 27From the time Amaziah turned away from following the LORD, they plotted against him in Jerusalem. He fled to Lachish, but they sent assassins after him and killed him. 28They brought him back on horses and buried him with his ancestors in The City of Davidms.           2 Ch 25:20-28

Uzziah Rules Judah

26:1The people in Judah took Uzziah/Azariah at 16 and made him king after his father Amaziah. 2He built Eloth and restored it to Judah, 3and ruled for 52 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jechiliah of Jerusalem. 4He did what was good like everything good his father Amaziah had done. 5He continued to look to God in the time of Zechariah, who had understanding through the vision of God. As long as he sought the LORD, God caused him to flourish.	      									       2 Ch 26:1-5

6He went out and fought the Philistines, and tore down the walls of Gath, Jabneh, and Ashdod. He built towns around Ashdod among the Philistines. 7God helped him against the Philistines, the Arabians in Gur-baal, and the Meunites. 8The Ammonites paid him tribute, and his reputation extended to the border of Egypt, because he became very strong. 9In addition, he built towers in Jerusalem at the Corner Gate and the Valley Gate at the Angle, and fortified them. 10He built towers in the countryside and hewed out many cisterns, because he had lots of livestock in the western foothills and in the plains. He had farmers and vinedressers in the hill country and fertile fields because he loved the soil. 11Uzziah had an army ready for battle, which entered combat by divisions, according to the number of their muster, prepared by Jeiel the secretary and Maaseiah the official under the direction of Hananiah, one of the king’s officers. 12The number of family leaders over trained soldiers was 2,600. 13They directed an elite army of 307,500 that could wage war with great power against the king’s enemies. 14For the whole army, Uzziah/Azariah prepared shields, spears, helmets, body armor, bows, and sling stones. 15In Jerusalem he constructed engines of war invented by skilled men, and put them on the towers and the corners, to shoot arrows and catapult large stones. His reputation spread because he was marvelously helped until he became strong.	     2 Ch 26:6-15

16But when he became strong, his pride led him to act corruptly. He became unfaithful by going into the LORD’s Temple and burning incense on the incense altar. 17Azariah the priest came in after him with 80 of the priests, brave men, 18to oppose him,

“You’re not supposed to burn incense. That’s for the priests to do, consecrated descendants of Aaron. Get out of the sanctuary. You’ve been unfaithful and won’t have any honor from the LORD God.”

19But Uzziah/Azariah, with a censer in hand for burning incense, was mad. While he ranted at the priests, leprosy broke out on his forehead beside the altar of incense. 20Azariah and the priests saw it and hurried him out of there. He hurried to get out himself because the LORD had struck him. 21For the rest of his life, he lived as a leper in a house separate from the Temple. His son Jotham managed the king’s palace and judged the people. 22The rest of the acts of Uzziah/Azariah, first to last, the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz has recorded. 23Uzziah died, and they buried him in a burial field the kings owned, because he was a leper. His son Jotham became king.	2 Ch 26:16-23

Jotham Rules Judah

27:1Jotham was 25 and ruled for 16 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jerushah daughter of Zadok. 2He did what was good like his father, but he didn’t go into the Temple. The people kept acting corruptly. 3He built the upper gate of the LORD’s Temple and built extensively the wall of Ophel. 4He built towns in the hill country of Judah, and fortresses and towers on the wooded hills. 5He fought the Ammonites and prevailed; for three years they paid him 7550 lbs 100 talents of silver, 110,000 bushels 10,000 kors of wheat, and 110,000 bushels 10,000 kors of barley a year. 6He became powerful because he ordered his ways in the LORD his God. 7The rest of the acts of Jotham, including his wars, are recorded in The Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah. [8] 9He died, and they buried him in The City of David. His son Ahaz became king.           2 Ch 27:1-9

Ahaz Rules Judah

28:1Ahaz was 20 and ruled for 16 years in Jerusalem. He didn’t do what was good like David did. 2He followed the kings of Israel, made molten images for the worshipping Baal, 3burned incense in the Valley of (Ben)Hinnom, and burned his sons like the nations the LORD had driven out. 4He sacrificed and burned incense on the high places on the hills under every green tree.

5The LORD delivered him to the king of Aram. They defeated Ahaz and took a large number of captives to Damascus.
