1We sat by the rivers in Babylon

and cried when we remembered Zion.

2We hung our harps on its willows.

3Our captors required us to sing there;

our tormentors demanded happy songs,

“Sing us a song from Zion.”	Ps 137:1-3

4How can we sing about the LORD in a foreign land?

5If I forget you, Jerusalem,

may my right hand wither.

6May my tongue stick to the roof of my mouth

if I don’t remember you,

if I don’t regard Jerusalem

above my greatest joy.

7Remember, LORD, against the Edomites

the day of Jerusalem, when they said to the Babylonians,

“Tear it down, tear it down to its foundation.”

8Young woman of Babylon, you devastated one,

how happy will be the one that repays you

with what you did to us.

9How happy will the one be that grabs your infants

and dashes them against the rocks!	Ps 137:4-9

Psalm 138

A Psalm of David

1I thank you with all my heart

and sing your praises in front of the mighty.

2I bow toward your holy Temple

and thank you for your enduring love and faithfulness,

because you’ve guaranteed your promises

with the honor your name has.

3You answered me when I called out to you

and made me bold with strength.	Ps 138:1-3

4Kings will thank you, LORD,

when they hear what you say.

5They’ll sing about your ways

because your honor is so great.

6Though you’re high above us,

you care about the lowly;

but you recognize the proud from a long way off.

7Though I’m in trouble, you’ll protect me

and reach out against my enemies to save me.

8You’ll accomplish the purposes you have for me;

your love endures forever, LORD.

Don’t abandon the ones you’ve created.	Ps 138:4-8

Psalm 139

For the Choir Director. A Psalm of David

1LORD, you’ve known me and examined me.

2You know when I sit down and when I get up;

from a long way off you know what I’m thinking.

3You search out my traveling and my resting;

you’re well acquainted with my ways.

4Before I speak,

you know what I’m going to say.

5You’ve protected me front and back

and laid your hand over me.

6Knowledge like that is too amazing for me;

it’s beyond me; I can’t imagine it.	Ps 139:1-6

7Where can I go from your Spirit?

Where can I go to get away from you?

8If I go up to the sky, you’re there;

if I make my bed in Sheol, you’re there.

9If I take the wings of morning

and live by the most distant part of the ocean,

10even there you’ll lead me and support me.

11If I say, “Let darkness cover me,

and the light around me become night,”

12the dark’s not dark to you;

the night’s as bright as day.	Ps 139:7-12

13You formed my inner parts

and knit me together in my mother’s womb.

14Thank you; the way you’ve made me

is awesome and wonderful.

What you do is marvelous;

I know that for sure.

15My frame wasn’t hidden from you

when I was being made in secret,

intricately put together deep in the earth.

16You saw my unshaped substance;

you wrote in your scroll

the length of life you appointed for me

before there was any of it.	Ps 139:13-16

17How precious your thoughts are to me!

How vast their number is!

18If I could count them, they’d outnumber the grains of sand.

When I wake up, I’m still with you.

19Oh that you’d slay the sinful, God.

(Go away from me, you murderers!)

20Your enemies say awful things about you;

they use your name as a byword.

21Don’t I hate those who hate you?

Don’t I despise the ones that oppose you?

22I have total disdain for them;

they’re my enemies.

23Examine me, God, and know my heart;

test me and see how anxious my thoughts are.

24See if there’s anything offensive in me

and lead me in the everlasting way.	Ps 139:17-24

Psalm 140

For the Choir Director. A Psalm of David

1LORD, rescue me from sinful people

protect me from violent men,

2that plot evil things in their minds,

and constantly stir up conflict.

3They have pointed tongues like a snake;

viper’s venom lies behind their lips.

4LORD, protect me from sinful people;

Protect me from violent men,

that try to trip me.

5The arrogant hide traps for me;

with cords they spread a net beside the road

and set snares for me.	Ps 140:1-5

6I said to the LORD, “You’re my God;

listen to my petitions.

7GOD the Lord, my strong deliverer,

you’ve protected my head in battle.

8Don’t let sinful people do whatever they please;

don’t further their evil intentions.

9“Make the schemes they talk about

come down on their own heads.

10Let burning coals fall on them;

throw them into the fire,

into deep pits they can’t climb out of.

11Don’t let slanderers get a foothold in the earth;

have misfortune hunt down violent people quickly.”

12I know you’ll champion the cause of the suffering

and render justice for the poor.

13The godly will thank you

and live in your presence.	Ps 140:6-13

Psalm 141

A Psalm of David

1LORD, I’m calling on you; come quick;

hear me out.

2Consider my prayer as incense

and the raising of my hands as an evening offering.

3Guard my mouth;

watch over my lips.

4Incline my heart away from anything evil,

from practicing sinful things with sinners.	Ps 141:1-4

5Let a godly person strike me or rebuke me graciously;

that would be ointment for my head;

Don’t let me refuse it.

I still pray constantly against the deeds of sinners.

6When their leaders are thrown over the cliffs;

they’ll learn that the LORD’s word is true.

7“Like someone plowing up rocks,

our bones have been scattered at the mouth of Sheol.”

8I look to you, Lord GOD,

and take refuge in you; don’t leave me with no defense.

9Keep me from the jaws of the trap they’ve set for me,

from sinners’ snares;

10may they stumble into their own nets

while I go on by safely.	Ps 141:5-10

Psalm 142

A Maskil of David when he was in the cave

A Prayer

1I cry out to the LORD

and petition him;

2I pour out my complaint to him

and tell him my troubles.

3When I feel overwhelmed,

he knows the route I should take;

they’ve hidden traps for me

on every path I walk.

4I look in every direction,

but nobody notices me.

There’s no escape for me;

nobody cares if I live.	Ps 142:1-4

5I’m calling out to you, LORD;

“You’re my refuge,

my portion among the living.

6Listen to my outcry

because I’m in desperate need;

deliver me from my persecutors;

they’re just too strong.

7Bring me out of prison

so I can thank you;

the godly gather around me

because you’ve been so good to me.”	Ps 142:5-7

Psalm 143

A Psalm of David

1Hear my prayer, LORD;

listen to my petition;

in your faithfulness and goodness, come to my relief.

2Don’t put me on trial

because, compared to you, nobody’s good.

3My enemy has chased me,

crushed me on the ground,

and made me sit in the dark like people long dead.

4So I feel overwhelmed,

and my heart is empty.

5I remember the old days;

I ponder everything you’ve done

and think about what you’ve made.

6I reach out for you,

thirsty for you like parched ground.	Ps 143:1-6

7Answer me right away, LORD;

my spirit is failing; don’t hide from me,

or I’ll get like those destined for the Pit.

8Let me hear about your enduring love every morning

because I put my trust in you;

show me where to walk

because I’m lifting myself up to you.

9Deliver me from my enemies;

you’re my refuge.

10Teach me how to do your will

because you’re my God;

let your good Spirit lead me on level ground.

11In defense of your honor, LORD, protect me;

in your goodness, take me away from trouble;

12in your enduring love, slay my enemies;

destroy the ones that abuse me,

because I’m your servant.	Ps 143:7-12

Psalm 144

A Psalm of David

1Bless the LORD, my Rock,

who trains my hands for war,

my fingers for battle.

2He’s my enduring love and fortress,

my stronghold and deliverer,

my shield and refuge,

who subdues nations.

3LORD, what are we that you give us any thought

or care about us?

4We’re like a breath;

our lifetime is like a passing shadow.	Ps 144:1-4

5Lower the sky, LORD, and come down;

touch the mountains and make them smoke.

6Throw your lightning bolts and scatter my enemies;

shoot your arrows and rout them.

7Reach down from on high

and rescue me from deep water,

from aliens 8that lie,

whose right hand deceives.

9I’ll sing you a new song, God;

I’ll sing praise to you on a ten-string harp.

10You deliver kings

and rescued David from the cruel sword.

11Deliver me from aliens that lie,

whose right hand deceives.	Ps 144:5-11

12Make our sons in their youth like grown-up plants

and our daughters like corner pillars in a palace.

13Fill our granaries with every kind of crop;

have our flocks bear thousands—tens of thousands—in our pastures.

14Have our cattle deliver without miscarriage or failure to bear;

make it so there’s no danger in our streets.

15How happy people are that have such blessings;

how blessed they are that have the LORD as their God! Ps 144:12-15

Psalm 145

A Psalm of Praise. by David

1I’ll praise you highly, my God and king,

and bless you forever.

2I’ll bless you every day

and praise you from now on.

3You’re great and deserve great praise;

you have a greatness we have no way to measure.

4One generation will praise your works to the next

and tell about the powerful things you’ve done.

5They’ll think about your majestic glory and splendor

and about your amazing acts.

6People will talk about the power evident in your awesome deeds

and tell how great you are.

7They’ll overflow with the fame of your abundant goodness

and loudly sing about your godliness.	Ps 145:1-7

8The LORD is gracious and merciful,

slow to get angry and great in enduring love.

9He’s good to everyone;

his mercy spreads out across his whole creation.

10Everything he’s made will thank him;

his holy people will bless him.

11They’ll speak of the honor his kingdom has

and talk about his power

12to make known his powerful deeds

and the glorious majesty of his kingdom.

13His kingdom lasts forever;

his dominion continues across all generations.	Ps 145:8-13

14The LORD catches the ones that fall down

and straightens up those who are bent over.

15Everyone looks to him for help,

and he gives them their food as needed.

16He meets the needs of every living thing.

17The LORD shows his goodness in everything he does,

his kindness in every deed.

18He’s near to those who call on him,

that call on him sincerely.

19He provides for the people who respect him;

he hears their call and saves them.

20He protects those who love him,

but destroys the sinful.

21I’ll speak praise to the LORD;

everyone will bless him forever. 	Ps 145:14-21

Psalm 146

1Praise the LORD, my soul!

2I’ll praise my God as long as I live

and sing praises to him as long as I’m here.

3Don’t rely on rulers,

mortals, who can’t help.

4They quit breathing and go back into the ground;

their plans come to an end at the same time.

5How blessed they are that have Jacob’s God to help them,

whose hope lies in the LORD

6that made earth and sky,

the ocean and everything in them,

that’s dependable forever,

7who renders justice to the oppressed,

who feeds the hungry

and sets the prisoners free.	Ps 146:1-7

8He gives sight to the blind,

lifts up the burdened,

and loves the godly.

9He protects foreigners

and supports widows and the fatherless,

but thwarts the sinful.

10The LORD will reign forever,

your God, Zion, to all generations.

Hallelujah!	Ps 146:8-10

Psalm 147

1Hallelujah!

It’s good to sing praises to our God;

praising him is fitting because he’s gracious.

2The LORD builds up Jerusalem

and gathers the outcasts in Israel.

3He heals the brokenhearted

and bandages up their wounds.

4He counts the stars

and calls them each by name.

5Our Lord is great and has great power,

and understanding without limit.

6He supports the abused

and takes sinners down to the ground.	Ps 147:1-6

7Sing thanksgiving to the LORD;

sing praise to our God with a lyre.

8He covers the sky with clouds,

provides rain for the ground,

and makes grass grow on the hills.

9He gives animals their food

and feeds the young ravens when they caw.

10He doesn’t delight in the strength of horses

or take pleasure in human might.

11The LORD favors those who respect him,

who place their hopes in his enduring love.	Ps 147:7-11

12Praise the LORD, Jerusalem;

praise your God, Zion.

13He’s reinforced the bars on your gates

and blessed those who reside in you.

14He brings peace to your borders

and satisfies you with the finest wheat.

15He issues his command to the world,

and his message travels swiftly.

16He sends snow like wool

and scatters frost like ashes.

17He makes it hail;

who can stand his freezing cold?

18He speaks and it melts;

he makes wind blow and water flow.

19He declares his message to Jacob,

his statutes and ordinances to Israel.

20He hasn’t dealt this way with any other nation;

they haven’t known his ordinances.

Hallelujah!	Ps 147:12-20

Psalm 148

1Hallelujah!

Praise the LORD from heaven;

praise him in the sky.

2Praise him, all his hosts of angels.

3Praise him, sun and moon

and shining stars.

4Praise him, highest heaven,

and water vapor in the sky.

5Let them praise the LORD

because he commanded and they came to be.

6He established them forever

by a decree that won’t expire.	Ps 148:1-6

7Praise the LORD from earth,

you sea monsters and all the great deep,

8fire and hail, snow and clouds,

stormy wind fulfilling his command,

9mountains and hills,

fruit trees and cedars,

10wild animals and livestock,

crawling things and flying birds,

11kings of the earth and all the nations,

officials and judges

12young men and virgins,

old men and children.

13Praise the LORD

because he alone is to be esteemed;

his honor towers higher than earth and sky.

14He makes his people strong

and establishes praise for his holy nation,

for Israel that’s near him.

Hallelujah!	Ps 148:7-14

Psalm 149

1Hallelujah!

Sing the LORD a new song;

praise him in the assembly of his holy people.

2Be happy in your Maker, Israel;

celebrate your King, people of Zion.

3Praise him with dancing;

sing praises with tambourines and lyres,

4because the LORD delights in you

and graces harassed people with deliverance.	Ps 149:1-4

5Holy people, celebrate in glory;

sing for joy on your couches.

6Have the high praises of God in your voices

and two-edged swords in your hands

7to carry out vengeance on nations

and punishment on peoples,

8to bind kings with chains

and nobles with iron restraints,

9to carry out prescribed judgment on them.

That’s an honor for all his holy people.

10Hallelujah!	Ps 149:5-10

Psalm 150

1Hallelujah!

Praise God in his sanctuary;

praise him in his heavenly expanse.

2Praise him for his powerful deeds

in proportion to his greatness.

3Praise him with trumpet, harp, and lyre.

4Praise him with tambourines and dancing,

with stringed instruments and flutes.

5Praise him with cymbals,

with loud crashing cymbals.

6Everything that breathes, praise the LORD.

Hallelujah!  	Ps 150:1-6

PROVERBS

1:1Proverbs of Solomon Son of David, King of Israel

2for knowing wisdom and instruction,

for understanding words that give insight,

3for receiving instruction in smart living,

goodness, justice, and equity;

4for giving prudence to the simple,

and knowledge and discretion to the young;

5for increasing learning in the wise

and gaining skill at understanding;

6for understanding proverbs and wise sayings,

riddles and profound speech.	Prov 1:1-6

7Respect for the LORD is the first thing about being wise;

foolish people despise wisdom and instruction.

8Listen, son, to your father’s instruction;

don’t leave your mother’s teaching;

9they’ll be a crown for your head

and a garland for your neck.	Prov 1:7-9

10Son, if sinners tempt you, don’t give in to them.

11If they say, “Come on,

let’s lie in wait to shed blood

and ambush innocent people for fun.

12Let’s swallow them alive and whole like Sheol,

like people that go down to the Pit.

13We’ll get precious wealth

and fill our houses with plunder.

14Throw in your lot with us,

and we’ll share the take”—

15don’t go with them;

stay off that road.

16They hurry to do harm;

they run to shed blood.	Prov 1:10-16

17There’s no point in spreading a net

while the bird’s watching.

18Sinners lie in wait for their own blood;

they ambush their own lives.

19That’s how it is with people that profit from violence;

it steals their own lives.	Prov 1:17-19

20Wisdom shouts in the street;

it raises its voice in the marketplace.

21It cries out from the top of the wall

and says at the city gate:

22“How long, simpletons, will you like being simpletons,

and you scoffers delight in scoffing,

and you foolish people hate knowledge?

23Pay attention when I correct you;

I’ll pour out my spirit on you

and tell you what you need to know.

24I called and you wouldn’t listen;

I held out my hand, and you paid no attention.

25You ignored my advice;

you didn’t want me to correct you.

26So I’ll laugh at your misfortune

and mock you when panic strikes,

27when what you dread comes like a tornado,

when distress come crashing down on you. 	Prov 1:20-27

28Then you’ll call out to me, and I won’t answer;

you’ll look for me, but not find me

29because you disregarded knowledge

and chose not to respect the LORD.

30You wouldn’t accept my advice;

you despised being corrected;

31so you’ll eat the fruit of how you lived

founder on your own schemes.

32The waywardness of simpleminded people gets them killed;

the complacency of fools destroys them.

33But the ones that listen to me, live securely;

they’re at ease without dreading misfortune.”	Prov 1:28-33

2:1Son, if you accept what I say

and value my commandments,

2if you’re attentive to wisdom

and inclined to understanding,

3if you cry out for insight

and call out for comprehension,

4if you look for it like silver

and search for it like treasure—

5then you’ll understand the importance of reverence for the LORD

and find out what it means to know God.	Prov 2:1-5

6The LORD gives wisdom;

knowledge and insight come from him.

7He stores up wisdom for godly people

and shields those who maintain integrity

8and guard justice.

He preserves his saints.

9Then you’ll understand goodness and justice,

equity and every proper course of action.

10Wisdom will come into your heart,

and knowledge will be pleasant to you.	Prov 2:6-10

11Discretion will come to you;

knowledge will watch over you

12to deliver you from the evil way,

from people that say perverse things,

13who leave the paths of godliness

to walk in the dark,

14who enjoy sinning

and revel in its perversity,

15whose paths are crooked,

whose ways are treacherous;

16to deliver you from immoral women,

from the seductive woman

17that leaves the husband of her youth

and forgets her covenant with God,

18whose house lies on the road to death,

whose footprints lead to the dead.

19No man that enters her house ever comes back;

they don’t reach the paths that lead to life.	Prov 2:11-19

20Follow the road good people take;

keep to the paths they follow,

21because the godly will live in the land;

the blameless will stay here.

22But sinners will be removed from the land;

the treacherous will be uprooted from their country.	Prov 2:20-22

3:1Son, don’t forget what I’ve taught you;

take my commandments to heart;

2they’ll add peace and length to your life.

3Don’t let kindness and truth slip away from you;

tie them around your neck;

write them on your heart.

4That way you’ll find blessing

and have a good reputation with God and people.

5Trust in the LORD with all your heart;

don’t rely on your own perception.

6Acknowledge him in everything you do,

and he’ll make straight paths for you to follow.

7Don’t get the idea that you’re smart;

respect the LORD and turn your back on sin.

8It will heal your body and refresh your very bones.	Prov 3:1-8

9Honor the LORD with your substance,

the firstfruits of your crops.

10Your barns will be full;

your vats will overflow with new wine.	Prov 3:9-10

11Son, don’t reject the LORD’s discipline

or give up when he corrects you;

12he corrects the ones he cares about,

like a father that disciplines a son he delights in.

13They are blessed who find wisdom,

that gain insight.

14It’s more profitable than silver;

it brings greater gains than fine gold.

15It’s more precious than jewels;

nothing you desire can compare with it.

16Its left hand holds wealth and honor;

long life is in its right hand.

17Its ways are pleasant;

its paths are peaceful.

18It’s a life-giving tree for people that pick its fruit;

everybody that holds onto it is happy.	Prov 3:11-18

19The LORD founded the earth with wisdom

and established the heavens with understanding;

20he broke up the depths with his knowledge

and caused dew to settle from the sky.	Prov 3:19-20

21Son, keep sound wisdom and discretion nearby;

don’t let them out of your sight.

22They’ll refresh your soul

and adorn your neck.

23You’ll walk along your road

surefooted without stumbling.

24When you lie down, you won’t feel afraid;

when you go to bed, your sleep will be sweet.

25Don’t be afraid of sudden panic

or the ruin that sinful people may bring,

26because you’ll have confidence with the LORD;

he’ll keep your foot out of the snare.	Prov 3:21-26

27Don’t withhold good from people that need it

when you can give it.

28Don’t tell them,

“Come back tomorrow, and you can have it.”

29Don’t devise misfortune against the one

that’s living safely beside you.

30Don’t be difficult with people

if they’ve done you no wrong.

31Don’t envy the violent

or choose to do what they do.

32The LORD detests crooked people,

but he’s close to godly ones.

33He puts a curse on the house of the sinful,

but blesses the homes of the righteous.

34He scoffs at scoffers,

but is gracious to the humble.

35The wise receive honor;

the foolish get disgrace.	Prov 3:27-35

4:1Listen to my instruction, children;

pay attention and learn.

2I’ll give you helpful guidance;

don’t abandon it.

3When I was my father’s son,

my mother’s tender, only boy,

4he taught me,

“Hold fast to what I say;

keep my commandments and live.

5Gain wisdom! Get insight!

Don’t forget it or leave it.

6Keep it with you, and it’ll protect you;

love it, and it’ll watch over you.

7This is the main thing about wisdom: get it;

whatever else you get, get that.

8Value it highly, and it’ll elevate you;

it will bring you honor if you embrace it.

9It will put a beautiful wreath on your head

and present you with a splendid crown.”	Prov 4:1-9

10Accept what I’m telling you, son,

and you’ll live a long time.

11I’ve directed you in the way of wisdom

and led you in godly paths.

12When you walk, you won’t be hampered;

when you run, you won’t stumble.

13Latch hold of instruction and don’t let go;

guard it, and it will determine your destiny.	Prov 4:10-13

14Don’t follow the road that sinners travel

or walk the path of perverse people.

15Avoid it; don’t pass by it;

turn and go the other way.

16They can’t sleep unless they mistreat someone;

they lose sleep unless they can trip somebody up.

17They eat the bread of wickedness,

and drink the wine of violence.

18But the path of goodness is like dawn’s early light;

it shines brighter and brighter till it’s fully day.

19The way of sinners is like darkness;

they don’t know what they’re stumbling over.	Prov 4:14-19

20Pay attention to me, son;

listen to what I’m telling you;

21don’t let it out of your sight;

keep it inside you.

22It gives life to those who find it

and health to their whole body.

23Watch over your heart diligently,

because the springs of life flow out of it.

24Put away a deceitful mouth;

put devious lips far from you.

25Look straight ahead;

fix your gaze in front of you.

26Keep your eye on the path you’re walking,

and all your ways will be safe.

27Don’t stray from them;

go the other way from sin.	Prov 4:20-27

5:1Pay attention to my wisdom, son;

listen to what I understand

2so you can use discretion

and express knowledge.

3An immoral woman’s lips drip honey;

her speech is more soothing than oil;

4but in the end she’s as bitter as wormwood,

as sharp as a two-edged sword.

5Her feet go down to death;

her steps lead to Sheol.

6She doesn’t ponder the path of life;

she wanders without realizing it.	Prov 5:1-6

7Listen to me, sons;

don’t turn aside from what I’m telling you.

8Stay away from her;

don’t go near her house,

9so you won’t be giving your vigor to others

and your years to someone cruel;

10so a stranger won’t be filled with your strength

and the fruit of your act go to an alien;

11and you groan at the end of life

because you misused your body;

12and you say, “I hated instruction!

my heart despised being corrected!

13I didn’t listen to my teachers

or pay attention to my instructors!

14I’ve come to the point of total ruin

and have to face public disgrace.”	Prov 5:7-14

15Drink water from your own cistern,

fresh water from your own well.

16Should your spring be spilled

like water running down the street?

17Let it be for yours alone,

not for a stranger too.	Prov 5:15-17

18Let your fountain be blessed;

be happy with the wife of your youth.

19Like a lovely deer, a graceful doe,

be satisfied with her breasts;

be stimulated by her love.

20Son, why be stimulated by an immoral woman?

why embrace the bosom of a stranger?

21The LORD watches everyone

to see which direction they’re going.

22Their own iniquities capture the wicked;

they get caught in the web of their own sins.

23They die from ignorance

and get lost over foolishness. 	Prov 5:18-23

6:1Son, if you sign for your neighbor

or give a pledge for a stranger,

2if you get snared by a promise you’ve made

or caught by what you’ve said,

3do this to deliver yourself:

since you’re at his disposal,

humble yourself and plead with him

to take away your obligation.

4Don’t sleep or slumber;

5deliver yourself like a gazelle from a hunter,

like a bird from a fowler.	Prov 6:1-5

6Go observe ants, lazy guy;

watch what they do and wise up.

7Though they don’t have a chief, an officer, or ruler,

8they prepare their food in the summer;

at harvest time they gather provisions for winter.

9How long will you lie around?

When will you get up from napping?

10“A little sleep, a little slumber,

a little folding of the hands to rest”—

11your poverty will come on you like a bandit;

your need will attack you like an armed man. 	Prov 6:6-11

12A worthless, wicked man is one

that goes around lying,

13that winks with his eye,

signals with his feet,

gestures with his fingers,

14that plots in his mind

and constantly stirs up conflict.

15Tragedy will come crashing down on him;

all at once he’ll be crushed beyond recovery.	Prov 6:11-15

16Six things the LORD despises;

no, make that seven that disgust him:

17arrogant eyes,

lying tongues,

blood-shedding hands,

18plotting hearts,

feet in a hurry to do harm,

19witnesses who perjure themselves

and people that stir up conflict between friends.	Prov 6:16-19

20Son, keep your father’s commands;

don’t leave your mother’s teachings.

21Bind them next to your heart;

hang them around your neck.

22They’ll guide you when you walk,

watch over you while you sleep,

and advise you when you wake up.

23A commandment is a lamp;

teaching is a light;

corrections that discipline lead to life.	Prov 6:20-23

24They keep your eyes off an immoral woman,

a loose woman with smooth talk.

25Don’t desire her beauty

or let her catch your attention with her eyes.

26A prostitute leaves a man with little to eat;

an immoral woman stalks his very life.

27Can a man carry fire in his arms

and not singe his clothes?

28Can he walk on hot coals

and not burn his feet?

29Can a man go to his neighbor’s wife

and not suffer for it?	Prov 6:24-29

30People don’t despise a thief

that steals because he’s hungry;

31but when he’s caught, he still needs to repay it seven times over

even if he has to sell everything in his house to make it right.

32A man that commits adultery lacks good judgment;

he’s looking to destroy himself.

33He’ll find wounds and disgrace

and shame he can’t erase.

34Jealousy makes a husband furious;

he won’t restrain his revenge.

35He won’t accept ransom

or be content with your gifts.	Prov 6:30-35

7:1Take my advice, son;

treasure up my commandments inside you.

2Keep my commands so you can have a life;

guard my teachings like the pupil in your eye.

3Tie them on your fingers;

write them on your heart.

4Call wisdom your sister and insight your friend,

5so they can keep you away from the adulteress

that flatters with her words.	Prov 7:1-5

6At the window of my house

I looked out through the lattice

7and saw among the naïve

a young man with no sense.

8He was going down the street near her corner

on the way to her house,

9in the evening at dusk.

During the night after dark,

10a woman comes to meet him,

dressed like a prostitute, coy at heart.

11She’s loud and rebellious, not content to stay home—

12now in the streets, now in the squares,

lurking at every corner.	Prov 7:6-12

13She grabs him and kisses him,

and says to him with a brazen face,

14“It was time for me to offer peace offerings;

I paid my vows today.

15So I’ve come out to meet you,

to look for you eagerly, and I found you.

16I’ve decorated my couch with covers,

with colored linens from Egypt.

17I’ve sprinkled my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.

18Come on, let’s drink our fill of love till morning;

let’s delight ourselves with love.

19My husband’s gone on a long trip;

20he’s taken a moneybag with him

and won’t be back till full moon.”	Prov 7:13-20

21She entices him with persuasion,

And seduces him with flattery.

22Finally he follows her like a bull to slaughter,

like a stag heading for a trap.

23An arrow pierces his liver;

like a bird swooping to a snare,

he doesn’t realize it will cost him his life.	Prov 7:21-23

24So pay attention to what I’m saying, sons.

25Don’t let your heart turn to its own ways

or stray into its own paths;

26doing that has thrown down so many victims

and slain them.

27Her house lies on the road to Sheol,

that descends to the den of death.	Prov 7:24-27

8:1Wisdom calls out,

and intelligence raises its voice.

2It takes its stand on high places

where footpaths meet.

3It shouts at the city gates:

4“I’m calling out to you;

my voice is aimed at everyone.

5Learn prudence, simple ones;

gain wisdom, foolish people.

6Listen, so I can tell you nobler things,

important things come from me.	Prov 8:1-6

7I tell the truth

because I detest sinfulness.

8Everything I say is good;

there’s nothing devious in it.

9What I say makes sense to anyone that has insight;

it’s right to those who learn.

10Take instruction rather than silver;

accept knowledge instead of gold

11because wisdom is worth more than jewels;

nothing you want compares with it.	Prov 8:7-11

12“I, wisdom, and good judgment live together;

I discover knowledge and discretion.

13Respecting the LORD means hating sin,

pride and arrogance,

corrupt behavior and perverse speech.

14I offer advice about wise living

and provide insight and strength.

15Kings reign by me,

and rulers decree justice.

16Officials and nobles govern by me

as does everyone that judges justly.

17I love the ones that love me,

that diligently search me out.

18I have wealth and honor to offer,

lasting riches and goodness.

19My fruit has more value than pure gold;

my yield outperforms the finest silver.

20I walk in the way of goodness,

on the paths of justice,

21to endow with wealth the ones that love me.		Prov 8:12-21

22“The LORD created me at the very beginning,

before anything else he did in ancient times.

23I was in place from everlasting,

from the beginning of time on earth.

24I came before there were any oceans

or any springs abounded with water,

25before the mountains were born

or any hills existed,

26before he made soil and fields

and dust on the ground.	Prov 8:22-26

27I was there when he put the heavens in place

and drew the horizons around the ocean;

28when he set the sky above

and established the fountains in the deep;

29when he laid shorelines for the seas

so water couldn’t cross their boundaries;

when he marked out the foundations for the earth.

30I stood beside him like a general contractor,

serving as his daily delight,

celebrating with him,

31rejoicing in the world he was making,

delighting in humankind.	Prov 8:27-31

32“So now, my children, listen to me

because I bless those who keep my ways.

33Obey instruction in order to be wise;

don’t neglect it.

34Blessed are those who pay attention to what I say,

who watch at my gates each day

and wait at my doorpost.

35The ones that find me find life

and gain the LORD’s blessing.

36But those who miss out on me hurt themselves;

the ones that hate me love death.”	Prov 8:32-36

9:1Wisdom has built her house;

she’s carved its seven columns.

2She’s done her butchering, mixed her wine,

and set her table.

3She’s sent her maids

to call out from the heights of the city:

4“Whoever is naïve, turn in here!”

She says to those who lack good judgment,

5“Come in and eat my food

drink the wine I’ve mixed.

6Abandon your foolish ways and start having a life;

conduct yourself with good judgment.”	Prov 9:1-6

7If you correct a scoffer, you’ll be abused;

if you reprove sinners, you’ll get insulted.

8So don’t bother reproving scoffers; they’ll hate you;

reprove the wise, and they’ll love you.

9Instruct the wise, and they’ll be wiser still;

teach the good, and they’ll be better yet.

10Respect for the LORD is basic to wisdom;

knowing the Holy One clarifies your thinking.

11It’ll multiply your days

and add years to your life.

12If you’re wise, you’re wise for yourself;

if you scoff at wisdom, it’ll be to your detriment.	Prov 9:7-12

13A foolish woman is loud;

she’s naïve and ignorant.

14She sits in the doorway of her house

or takes a seat on the high places in town.

15She calls out to those who are going by,

who are following straight paths:

16“Whoever is naïve, turn in here,”

she claims to those who don’t know any better.

17“Stolen water is refreshing;

bread eaten in secret tastes good.”

18But they don’t know that the dead are there,

that her guests lie in Sheol.	Prov 9:13-18

10:1Proverbs of Solomon

A wise son makes a happy father,

but a foolish one grieves his mother.

2Ill-gotten gain doesn’t gain you anything,

but goodness delivers you from death.

3The LORD won’t let good people go hungry;

he thwarts what the wicked want.

4A lazy hand makes for poverty;

a diligent one produces wealth.

5They who gather crops in the summer are smart;

those who sleep at harvest time are shameful.

6Blessings come to the good,

but the sinful harbor violent intentions.	Prov 10:1-6

7Good people leave blessed memories behind,

but sinful people’s names rot away.

8The wise in heart accept commands,

but babbling fools come to ruin.

9If you live with integrity, you’ll live with confidence;

but people soon find out if you’re crooked.

10The one that winks causes trouble;

babbling fools come to ruin.

11Good people’s words are life-giving fountains;

what sinners harbor discord.

12Hatred stirs up conflict,

but love atones for all sins.

13Wisdom comes from people that have insight;

but a rod is for the back of fools.

14The wise store up knowledge,

but ruin is at hand for foolish people.		Prov 10:7-14

15For the rich, wealth is a fortress;

for the poor, poverty is their ruin.

16Life is good people’s pay;

punishment is bad people’s payback.

17Listening to instruction puts you on the route to life;

abandoning correction gets you lost.

18Hiding hatred makes you a liar;

spreading slander makes you a fool.

19Talking too much makes you likely to sin;

so be wise and limit what you say.

20The words of good people are like fine silver;

what sinners say isn’t worth repeating.	Prov 10:15-20

21What good people say feeds many;

foolish people starve to death from ignorance.

22The LORD’s blessing makes you rich,

and he doesn’t add sorrow to it.

23Sin is fun for fools;

so is wisdom for the wise.

24What sinners fear tends to happen;

what good people want they tend to receive.

25After a windstorm passes, sinners have been blown away;

but the godly have a firm foundation.

26To those who hire them,

lazy people irritate like vinegar on teeth

and smoke in the eyes.				Prov 10:21-26

27Respecting the LORD lengthens your life;

sinfulness cuts it short.

28Good people’s hopes result in happiness,

but the expectations of the sinful fade away.

29The LORD’s way is your fortress if you’re godly,

but it destroys sinners.

30Good people won’t be displaced,

but the sinful will be expelled from their land.

31The mouth of good people overflows with wisdom,

but the perverse tongue of the wicked will be cut off.

32Good people say what’s acceptable,

but the sinful say perverse things.	Prov 10:27-32

11:1The LORD detests a false balance;

he delights in accurate weights.

2Dishonor follows pride,

but wisdom lies with the humble.

3The integrity of the wise gives them direction;

the dishonesty of treacherous people destroys them.

4Wealth won’t help you when judgment comes,

but goodness delivers you from death.

5Goodness smooths the way for the blameless,

but the sinful collapse under the weight of their own sin.

6Their goodness delivers the godly;

their greed snares deceivers.	Prov 11:1-6

7When sinners die, their aspirations die as well;

hope perishes with the godless.

8Good people leave trouble behind,

but sinners head right for it.

9The godless destroy their neighbors with their mouths,

but knowledge lets the righteous escape.

10A city celebrates when things go well for the godly;

there’s also happy shouting over the demise of the sinful.

11The godly are a blessing that builds up a city;

the mouths of sinners tear it down.

12Belittling your neighbor doesn’t help anybody;

be silent and just let it rest.

13Gossips go around telling secrets;

reliable people keep private matters private.

14Without wise leaders a nation falls;

victory comes from having many advisors.	Prov 11:7-14

15Standing good for a stranger’s debt

means you’re likely to pay it;

avoid guaranteeing it and stay safe.

16A gracious woman earns respect;

a violent man just gets rich.

17Kindness repays you;

cruelty destroys you.

18Sinners get rich by deception;

people that sow goodness make a legitimate living.

19Steadfast goodness promotes life;

chasing after evil gets you killed.

20The LORD detests the perverse in heart;

he delights in those blameless in their living.

21Sinful people will certainly suffer for it,

but the children of the just will be rescued.

22A beautiful woman with no discretion

is like a gold ring in a pig’s snout.	Prov 11:15-22

23The godly look forward to good things;

the sinful are simply waiting for wrath.

24Give liberally and grow richer;

withhold what you should give

and be in need.

25The generous prosper;

those who refresh other people will be refreshed.

26People curse the one that hoards grain

but bless the one that sells it to people that need it.

27Whoever seeks the good finds favor,

and trouble comes to the one that’s looking for it.

28People that rely on their wealth will fall;

but the godly will flourish like green leaves.	Prov 11:23-28

29Bring trouble on your family,

and you’ll inherit the wind;

the foolish serve the wise.

30Good people become a tree of life,

the wise win friends.

31If the righteous are rewarded on earth,

how much more godless sinners!	Prov 11:29-31

12:1Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge;

whoever hates to be corrected stays ignorant.

2The LORD gives grace to the good,

but condemns those who concoct evil.

3Sinfulness brings instability,

but godliness grows deep roots.

4A good wife is her husband’s crown,

but one that embarrasses him is like cancer in his bones.

5You can trust the thinking of the righteous,

but the advice of sinners is treacherous.

6The words of sinners are like a murderous ambush,

but the words of the godly rescue people.	Prov 12:1-6

7The sinful are overthrown and disappear,

but the godly stand firm.

8People are commended for using good sense;

people with perverted minds are despised.

9The humble who work as servants are better off

than those who honor themselves and go hungry.

10Good people care about their animals’ life;

sinful people are cruel to everything.

11Plow your ground and you’ll have plenty to eat;

chasing after fantasies shows poor judgment.

12Sinners are jealous of each other’s plunder,

but the goodly produce their own things.	Prov 12:7-12

13Their own words trap sinful people;

good people avoid trouble like that.

14Good people gain satisfaction

from the effects of their words;

their actions also return to reward them.

15Fools think their way is the right way;

but the wise are willing to listen.

16Fools fly off the handle when insulted,

but the prudent stay calm.

17Honest witnesses tell the truth;

false ones just make up something.

18Cutting remarks spoken rashly thrust like daggers,

but wise words heal wounds.	Prov 12:13-18

19A truthful tongue lasts a lifetime,

but lying lips don’t endure.

20Deceit lies in hearts that lay plots,

but advisors of peace have joy.

21Harm tends not to fall on good people;

sinners are always in trouble.

22The LORD detests liars

but delights in reliable people.

23Prudent people hold back telling how much they know;

foolish people talk too much.

24The diligent rule;

the lazy end up enslaved.	Prov 12:19-24

25Anxiety weighs people down;

an encouraging word raises them up.

26Godly people serve as guides for their friends;

sinful ones get them lost.

27Lazy people don’t achieve their goals;

diligent ones gain precious possessions.

28Life lies along the road good people follow;

there’s no death there.	Prov 12:25-28

13:1Wise children accept their father’s discipline,

but scoffers don’t pay attention to correction.

2From the influence of your words,

people respond willingly;

but treacherous people want to force things through.

3Be careful what you say, and you’ll save yourself;

talk too much, and you’ll do yourself in.

4Lazy people want but don’t get;

the diligent have a rich supply.

5Good people hate lies,

but sinners act disgracefully.

6Goodness protects the blameless;

sinfulness undermines the sinful.	Prov 13:1-6

7One person acts rich but is poor;

another pretends to be poor but is wealthy.

8The rich can pay a ransom to save their lives,

but the poor don’t get kidnapped for ransom.

9The light of the godly shines bright,

but the lamp of the sinful flickers out.

10Insolence causes division;

accepting advice brings wisdom.

11Easy wealth soon dwindles away;

what we work for increases.

12Hope delayed makes a heart sick,

but a longing fulfilled is a tree of life.	Prov 13:7-12

13Instruction destroys people that hate it;

a commandment rewards those who respect it.

14Wise teaching is your fountain of life

for avoiding the snares of death.

15Good sense leads to blessing,

but a treacherous mind creates hardship.

16Prudent people act with insight;

fools flaunt their foolishness.

17An unreliable messenger stumbles into trouble,

but a faithful envoy can bring detente.

18We risk poverty and shame by neglecting self-discipline;

honor comes to us if we value correction.	Prov 13:13-18

19Seeing dreams come true is pleasant to the soul,

but fools hate to quit sinning.

20When you live with the wise you become wise;

companions of fools will suffer with them.

21Misfortune follows sinners,

but prosperity rewards the righteous.

22Good people leave an inheritance for their grandchildren;

sinners lay up wealth for the godly.

23Even fallow ground yields enough to feed the poor,

but injustice sweeps it all away.

24Those who spare the rod don’t love their children;

if you care about them, you’ll discipline them.

25Good people have enough to satisfy their appetite,

but a sinner’s stomach never feels full.	Prov 13:19-25

14:1A wise woman builds up her home;

a foolish one tears it down with her own hands.

2We show respect for the LORD by pursuing godliness;

being crooked in our ways means we don’t respect him.

3The tongues of fools become a rod for their back;

the lips of the wise save them.

4A manger stays clean where there are no oxen,

but abundant crops come in by their strength.

5A truthful witness tells no lies;

a false one lies with every breath.

6Scoffers look for wisdom but don’t find it;

knowledge comes easy for insightful people. 	Prov 14:1-6

7Stay away from foolish people;

you won’t learn anything from them.

8Prudent people know where they’re going,

but fools mislead themselves.

9Fools make fun of guilt,

but the godly favor the guiltless.

10The heart knows its bitterness;

no one else can share its joy.

11The house of the sinful faces demolition,

but the tent of the godly stands steady.

12There is a way that seems right,

but it leads to death.	Prov 14:7-12

13Laughter can hide a heavy heart;

joy can give way to grief.

14Perverse people get a fill of their own ways;

good people get satisfaction from theirs.

15Simpleminded people believe anything,

the prudent watch where they step.

16The wise take caution and get away from sin,

but fools are arrogant and reckless.

17Short-tempered people do foolish things;

people despise people that scheme.

18The naïve inherit foolishness,

but the prudent wear knowledge like a crown.	Prov 14:13-18

19Evil bows to good;

sinners will bow at the gates of the godly.

20Even neighbors dislike the poor,

but lots of people like the rich.

21Whoever despises another commits sin,

but those gracious to the poor find happiness.

22Won’t they take a loss that devise evil?

Those who devise good receive kindness and truth.

23There’s profit in work;

mere talk produces poverty.

24The wise wear their wealth like a crown;

the foolish dress in their own foolishness.	Prov 14:19-24

25A truthful witness saves lives,

but a false witness is a traitor.

26Those who respect the LORD feel confident;

their children have a reliable refuge.

27Respecting the LORD provides a fountain of life

so people can avoid the snares of death.

28A growing population speaks well for a king;

what’s the point of a prince without subjects?

29Wise people control their temper;

short-tempered people show their lack of good sense.

30A peaceful heart makes a healthy body,

but jealousy is like cancer of the bone.	Prov 14:25-30

31People that oppress the poor insult their Maker;

those who are gracious to them honor him.

32Sinful people get crushed by the disasters

they bring on themselves,

but the righteous have a refuge when they die.

33Wisdom rests in intelligent people,

but it’s not evident among fools.

34Goodness raises the quality of a nation;

sin’s a disgrace to any people.

35A king favors a servant that acts wisely,

but he lashes out at one that disgraces him.	Prov 14:31-35

15:1A gentle answer deflects anger;

harsh words make tempers flare.

2The wise dispense knowledge;

fools expound foolishness.

3The LORD sees everything;

he watches the evil and the good.

4Gentle words are a tree of life,

but perverse talk breaks people’s spirit.

5Fools reject their father’s discipline,

but those attentive to correction become prudent.

6There’s wealth in the house of the godly,

but the earnings of the sinful bring trouble.	Prov 15:1-6

7The lips of the wise give good advice;

the hearts of fools have nothing to offer.

8The LORD detests the sacrifices of sinners,

but delights in the prayers of the righteous.

9He detests the way of the wicked,

but loves people who pursue goodness.

10Those who abandon the way incur harsh discipline;

those who reject discipline die.

11Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the LORD;

how much more our hearts!

12Scoffers don’t like people that rebuke them;

so they stay away from the wise.	Prov 15:7-12

13A cheerful heart makes a happy face,

but a sad heart breaks the spirit.

14The mind of the wise is hungry for insight,

but the mouth of fools feeds on foolishness.

15Negative people have nothing but bad days,

but with a happy heart they enjoy a continual feast.

16It’s better to have a little with reverence for the LORD

than to have a lot with turmoil attached.

17A plate of vegetables with someone you love tastes better

than a roast from a grain-fed cow with someone you don’t like.

18Hot-tempered people stir up quarrels,

but controlling anger calms contentions. 	Prov 15:13-18

19Briers overgrow lazy people’s paths,

but the upright travel on an open road.

20Wise children make a happy father;

foolish ones despise their mother.

21Foolishness is fun for the foolish,

but the wise walk on a straight path.

22Without advice plans go awry,

but with many advisors they succeed.

23Everyone enjoys giving a good answer,

and a timely word delights those who hear it!

24The path of the wise leads upward

away from Sheol below.	Prov 15:19-24

25The LORD tears down the house of the proud

but protects the widow’s home.

26The LORD detests evil plans

but delights in pure words.

27Those greedy for gain bring trouble home;

those who refuse bribes live in peace.

28The godly think before they speak;

sinners blurt out evil without thinking.

29The LORD stands far away from the sinful,

but he listens to the prayers decent people offer.

30A cheerful look makes the heart happy;

good news refreshes us deep inside.	Prov 15:25-30

31If you listen to constructive correction,

you’ll live among the wise.

32If you ignore instruction, you only hurt yourself;

by heeding correction, you gain insight.

33Respecting the LORD teaches wisdom;

humility comes before honor.	Prov 15:31-33

16:1We have intentions,

but the LORD provides the proper course of action.

2Our ways may seem pure to us,

but the LORD weighs our motives.

3Commit your work to the LORD,

and you’ll succeed.

4The LORD has a purpose for everything,

even for sinners in troubled times.

5The LORD detests arrogant people

and makes sure they’re punished.

6Loyalty and faithfulness atone for sin;

respecting the LORD avoids evil.	Prov 16:1-6

7When we please the LORD,

he even makes our enemies live in peace with us.

8A little with goodness is better

than a lot with dishonesty.

9You can make your plans,

but the LORD directs the steps you’ll take.

10A king needs to make inspired decisions;

he can’t afford to err in his judgments.

11The LORD requires accurate scales and balances;

he sets the standard for every weight in the bag.

12An evil king is especially detestable;

a throne needs to be based on goodness.	Prov 16:7-12

13Godly words delight a king;

he loves people that tell the truth.

14A king’s anger is a death sentence;

the wise will appease it.

15There’s life in a king’s countenance;

his blessing is like clouds that bring spring rain.

16Getting wisdom is better than getting gold!

Choose insight over silver.

17The road of the upright leads away from evil;

those who watch where they’re going preserve their life.

18Pride goes before destruction,

and an arrogant spirit before a fall.	Prov 16:13-18

19Better to nurture a humble spirit

than share plunder with the proud.

20By attending to the LORD’S word, we find what’s good;

he blesses us who trust in him.

21The wise in heart we consider insightful;

their pleasant words seem more persuasive.

22Wisdom is a fountain of life to the wise,

but foolishness disciplines fools.

23The wise think carefully about what they say,

which adds power to their comments.

24Pleasant words are like honeycomb,

sweet to the soul and healthy for the body.	Prov 16:19-24

25There’s a way that seems right,

but it leads to death.

26The workers’ appetite works for them

because their hunger drives them on.

27Worthless people plot evil;

what they say is like a scorching fire.

28Perverse persons spread conflict;

slanderers alienate friends.

29Violent people tempt their friends

and lead them off in the wrong direction.

30Those who wink devise perverse things;

they who purse their lips bring about evil.	Prov 16:25-30

31A gray head is a crown of honor

gained by a good life.

32Those who are slow to lose their temper

are stronger than the powerful;

the ones that rule their spirit

are better than troops that capture a city.

33We cast lots in the lap,

but the LORD determines how they fall.	Prov 16:31-33

17:1A dry morsel eaten in peace tastes better

than a feast in a house full of conflict.

2A wise servant will rule a shameful son

and share in the inheritance among brothers.

3Fire refines silver and a furnace purifies gold,

but the LORD assays the heart.

4Wrongdoers pay attention to gossip;

liars latch onto slander.

5People that mock the poor insult their Maker;

those who rejoice over their misfortune will get their just due.

6Grandchildren are the crown of old age;

parents are the pride of their children.	Prov 17:1-6

7Fine speech doesn’t fit with being a fool;

much less is lying appropriate for leaders.

8A bribe is a lucky charm in its owner’s sight;

whoever uses it prospers!

9Forgiving fosters love,

but dwelling on faults alienates friends.

10A rebuke penetrates deeper into thoughtful people

than 100 blows affect a fool.

11Rebellious people are looking for trouble;

so a cruel messenger will confront them.

12Facing a bear robbed of her cubs

is safer than confronting a fool for his folly.	Prov 17:7-12

13Misfortune never leaves the house of anyone

that repays a good deed with a bad one.

14Starting an argument is like opening a floodgate;

so stop a quarrel before it starts.

15Acquitting the guilty and condemning the innocent

are equally detestable to the LORD.

16Why spend money on educating fools

when they don’t care about learning?

17A friend loves despite the circumstance;

adversity forges friendship.

18It’s not good judgment

to guarantee another person’s debt.	Prov 17:13-18

19Loving sin amounts to loving conflict;

trusting in tall walls invites invasion.

20A crooked heart doesn’t prosper;

a lying tongue calls for retaliation.

21The parents of a fool feel discouraged;

there’s no joy in life for the father of a fool.

22A happy heart is good medicine;

a broken spirit weakens health.

23Sinners accept secret bribes

to pervert the course of justice.

24Sensible people find wisdom nearby;

25Foolish children are a grief to their father

26It’s wrong to punish the godly for their godliness

or flog noble people for being noble.

27Wise people speak with restraint;

Prov 17:25-28

18:1Unfriendly people pursue selfish ends;

2Fools don’t delight in learning,

3When sinners come, contempt comes with them;

4Wise thoughts are deep water;

5Don’t cater to bad people

or deprive the good of justice.

6Fools’ lips instigate conflict;

7The mouths of fools bring about their ruin;

8Rumors are like delicious morsels;

they just work their way down inside you!

9People that aren’t productive

are relatives of those who destroy.

10The LORD’s name is a strong tower;

11The wealth of the rich is their fortified city;

12Pride goes before destruction;

13Popping off an answer before listening to the question

14The human spirit can survive a sick body,

but who can endure a broken spirit?

15The wise search for knowledge;

the prudent acquire it.

16Generosity opens doors

and connects you with important people.

17The first to argue a case in court

18Casting lots ends contentions;

it settles disputes between powerful contenders.	Prov 18:13-18

19Winning back an offended brother

is harder than conquering a fortified city;

20What the mouth says satisfies the inner self;

what the lips express brings satisfaction.

21The tongue wields the power of life and death;

those who love it will reap its consequences.

22A man that finds a wife finds something good

and obtains the LORD’s blessing.

23The poor ask for help;

the rich answer roughly.

24Someone with lots of “friends” may come to ruin,

but there’s a friend that sticks closer than a brother.	Prov 18:19-24

19:1The honest poor are better off

than dishonest fools.

2It’s not good to not know;

enthusiasm doesn’t compensate for ignorance.

3When people’s foolishness brings them to ruin,

4Wealth draws lots of friends

5False witnesses will get their just due;

6Many ask for generous people’s blessing;

7Relatives of the poor despise them,

and their friends leave!

Appealing to them won’t bring them back.

8People that gain wisdom care about themselves;

they prosper who cherish understanding.

9False witnesses won’t go unpunished;

liars perish.

10Living in luxury isn’t fitting for a fool,

much less for a slave to rule over princes.

11Discretion gives you control over anger;

12A king’s anger is like a lion’s roar;

his blessing falls like dew on grass.	Prov 19:7-12

13A foolish child destroys a father;

a nagging wife is like constant dripping.

14Houses and wealth people inherit from parents,

but a prudent wife comes from the LORD.

15Laziness lulls people to sleep;

16Those who keep the commandments keep their life;

people that are careless about their way will lose it.

17Those gracious to the poor lend to the LORD;

he’ll reward them for the good they do.

18Discipline your children while there’s hope

so you won’t ruin their lives.	Prov 19:13-18

19Let angry people suffer the consequences;

bail them out, and you’ll have it to do again.

20Listen to advice and respond to discipline

21People make their plans,

but the LORD’s counsel is what prevails.

22Loyalty makes everyone better;

poor people are better at it than liars.

23Respecting the LORD leads to life;

you can sleep in peace without worrying about misfortune.

24Lazy people stick their fingers in the plate,

but they don’t even bring the food to their mouth.	 Prov 19:19-24

25Punish scoffers so the simpleminded can learn prudence;

26Children that mistreat their parents

are an embarrassment and a public disgrace.

27If you stop paying attention to discipline, child,

you’ll never learn what you need to know.

28A worthless witness makes mockery of justice;

a sinful mouth eats sin.

29Penalties are designed for scoffers,

and scourging for the backs of fools.	Prov 19:25-29

20:1Wine is a mocker, beer is a brawler;

whoever errs in them is not wise.

2A king’s anger is like a lion’s growl;

stirring it up forfeits your life.

3Staying away from conflict honors you;

4Anyone too lazy to plow

5A purpose in your heart is like deep water,

6Many claim to be loyal,

7How blessed the children are

whose parents carry themselves with integrity.

8A king on a just throne

9Who can say, “I’ve cleansed my heart;

I’m pure from sin”?

10The LORD detests false weights and measures.

11Even kids mark themselves by what they do

12The hearing ear and seeing eye—

the LORD made them both.	Prov 20:7-12

13Don’t love sleep too much; you’ll end up poor;

keep your eyes open, and you’ll have enough to eat.

14“It’s no good,” buyers say;

but when the seller’s gone, they brag about the bargain.

15Gold and precious stones abound,

but knowledge has more value.

16Take his cloak who signs for a stranger;

hold him in pledge for foreigners.

17Bread gained by deceit tastes sweet,

but afterward it feels like gravel in your mouth.

18Make plans in consultation with the other players;

19Gossips tell secrets;

so don’t associate with people that talk too much.

20Curse father and mother,

and your lamp will go out when it gets dark.

21Inheritance gained too early in life

22Don’t say, “I’ll get even with him”;

23The LORD detests false weights;

dishonest scales don’t please him.

24The LORD orders our steps;

so how can we fully understand our way?	Prov 20:19-24

25You set a trap for yourself by making a rash vow to God

26A wise king winnows sinners

and drives the threshing wheel over them.

27The human spirit is the LORD’s lamp;

it searches out the inner self.

28Loyalty and truth keep a king in office;

he holds onto his throne by goodness.

29A young man’s strength is his glory;

an old man’s glory is his gray hair.

30Punishment cleanses evil away;

discipline purifies the heart.	Prov 20:25-30

21:1A king’s heart in the LORD’s hand

is like a stream he can direct where he wants.

2Your own way seems right to you,

but the LORD weighs your heart.

3The LORD wants goodness and justice

more than sacrifice.

4Arrogant eyes and a proud heart

5Diligent planning gives you an advantage;

6Getting rich by lying is a dissipating vapor

7Sinful people’s violence sweeps them away

8A guilty person’s road is full of curves,

but the conduct of the pure makes a straight path.

9It’s better to live in the corner of a housetop

than inside the house with a contentious woman.

10Evil people desire evil

11Punishing scoffers makes them wise;

12Good people watch out for the sinful

13If you shut out the cry from the poor,

you’ll cry out yourself and not be heard.

14A secret gift calms anger;

a present turns it away.

15Good people enjoy carrying out justice;

16If you stray from understanding,

you’ll end up among the dead.

17People that love pleasure become poor;

18Sinners are ransoms for the righteous;

the unfaithful replace the good.	Prov 21:13-18

19It’s better to live in the desert

20Precious treasure and oil are in the houses of the wise,

21Pursue goodness and loyalty,

22The wise scale the walls of the powerful

and bring down the fortress they trust in.

23Watch your mouth and guard your tongue,

and you’ll stay out of trouble.

24“Scoffers” is the name for proud, haughty people

25Lazy people’s desires end up killing them

26The greedy never get enough

27God despises sinners’ sacrifices,

28False witnesses perish,

but good listeners testify forever.

29Sinners bluff,

but the godly think before they act.

30No wisdom, insight, or counsel

can prevail against the LORD.

31A horse is trained for battle,

but victory comes from the LORD.	Prov 21:25-31

22:1A good name means more than great wealth;

being blessed is better than having silver and gold.

2The rich and the poor have this in common:

the LORD made them both.

3Prudent people see evil and avoid it;

but the simpleminded rush on ahead and suffer for it.

4Wealth, honor, and life are rewards

5Briers and snares lie along the path of perverse people;

6Train up children in the way they should go;

and when they’re older, they won’t stray from it.	Prov 22:1-6

7The rich rule the poor;

8Those who sow sin reap disaster,

and their fury won’t subdue the opposition.

9Generous people will be blessed

10Get rid of scoffers, and contention leaves too;

11The one that loves a pure heart

12The LORD preserves knowledge

and overthrows what unreliable people say.	Prov 22:7-12

13Lazy people claim, “There’s a lion outside;

I’ll surely get killed in the streets!”

14An immoral woman’s mouth is a deep pit;

15Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a kid,

16Those who oppress the poor to get ahead—

Prov 22:13-16

17Listen to the wise

and apply your mind to my instruction;

18it will be pleasant if you retain it

so you’re ready to pass it on.

19I’m teaching you today

so you’ll trust in the LORD.

20Haven’t I written helpful things

about advice and knowledge,

21to make you sure of the truth

so you can report correctly to the one that sent you?

22Don’t rob the poor, who can’t resist,

or try to crush them in court;

23the LORD will argue their case

and sentence to death those who’ve robbed them.	Prov 22:17-23

24Don’t associate with people prone to anger

or go around with hotheaded types;

and entangle yourself in a net.

26Don’t give pledges or sign for debts.

27If you can’t pay,

why let someone take your bed from under you?

28Don’t remove the ancient boundary markers

that your ancestors have set.

29Do you see people skilled at their work?

They’ll serve kings, not just ordinary people.	Prov 22:24-29

23:1When you’re dining with a ruler,

3Don’t crave very many of his delicacies;

4Don’t wear yourself out trying to get wealthy;

5When you stare at wealth, it disappears;

6Don’t eat with stingy people

or crave their delicacies;

8You’ll vomit the morsel you’ve eaten

and waste your compliments.

9Don’t speak where fools can hear you;

10Don’t move an ancient boundary marker

11because their Rescuer is powerful;

12Apply your heart to instruction

and your ears to knowledge.	Prov 23:6-12

13Don’t withhold discipline from your children;

14Use a switch on them

and deliver their souls from Sheol.

15Son, if your heart’s wise, mine will be glad;

17Don’t envy sinners;

always live in reverence for the LORD.

18There most certainly is a future;

19Listen and be wise;

direct your heart on the right course.	Prov 23:13-19

20Don’t pal around with heavy drinkers or big eaters;

21drunks and gluttons end up poor,

and laziness will dress them in rags.

22Listen to your father;

don’t look down on your mother when she’s old.

23Buy truth and don’t sell it;

24Parents delight in well-behaved children;

25Make father happy;

26Give me your heart, son;

27A prostitute is a deep pit;

28She lurks around like a robber

and makes men unfaithful.	 Prov 23:26-28

29Who has misfortune? Who is sad?

Who has to cope with conflict?

Who complains?

Who is wounded for no reason?

Whose eyes are bloodshot?

30Those who linger long over wine,

31Don’t gaze at wine when it’s red,

when it sparkles in the cup,

when it goes down smoothly.

32Afterward it strikes like a serpent;

it bites like a viper.

33You’ll have hallucinations

and say crazy stuff.

34You’re like somebody asleep, bobbing on the ocean

or swaying on the rigging of a ship.

35“They strike me, but it doesn’t hurt;

they beat me, but I don’t feel it.

When I wake up,

I’ll want another drink.”	Prov 23:29-35

24:1Don’t envy bad people

or want to be around them;

2their minds devise violence;

their lips stir up trouble.

3Wisdom builds a house;

intelligence establishes a home;

4knowledge fills its rooms with precious, pleasant wealth.

5The wise are strong;

knowledge increases their strength;

6they wage war with effective strategy;

they win the victory because of their many advisors.

7Wisdom is out of the reach of fools;

they have nothing to say in the city gate.

8People call them schemers who plot misfortune;

9devising foolishness is sin;

scoffing is detestable.	Prov 24:1-9

10If adversity makes you weak,

11Rescue those unjustly sentenced to death;

Doesn’t he know you that keeps your soul?

Won’t he render to you what you deserve?

13Son, eat honey; it’s good;

14Understand that wisdom is like that to your soul;

and your hope won’t fade away.	Prov 24:10-14

15Don’t lie in wait at godly people’s house, you wicked;

16Good people fall seven times and get up again;

17Don’t be glad when your enemies stumble

18The LORD won’t be pleased;

he’ll turn his anger away from them.

19Don’t worry about sinners or envy them;

21Son, revere the LORD, respect the king,

and don’t associate with unstable people;

22their disaster will rise up unexpectedly,

and ruin you with them.

23These are sayings of the wise:

Showing partiality in judgment is unjust.

24Anyone that tells sinners they’re good,

25But those who rebuke sinners will receive delight;

blessing will come to them.

26Giving an honest answer is like a kiss on the lips.	Prov 24:21-26

27Finish your work in the field first;

28Don’t testify against someone for no reason

29Don’t say, “I’ll do to him what he’s done to me;

I’ll render to him his deeds in return.”

30I went past a lazy person’s field,

past the vineyard of someone without common sense.

31Thistles had taken it over;

nettles covered the ground;

its walls were broken down.

32I thought about what I saw;

I looked and learned:

33“A little sleep, a little slumber,

a little folding of the hands to rest.”

34Your poverty will descend on you like a raider;

your need will attack you like an armed robber.	Prov 24:27-34

25:1

More of Solomon’s Proverbs That the Men of Hezekiah,

King of Judah, Transcribed

2It’s God’s privilege not to reveal things

it’s a king’s responsibility to figure them out.

3A king’s mind is as unsearchable

as the sky is high and the earth is deep.

4Remove the dross from silver,

and a silversmith can make something out of it.

5Keep corrupt advisors away from a king,

and goodness will make his throne secure.	Prov 25:1-5

6Don’t claim a privileged position in a king’s presence

or put yourself in a place designated for nobles.

7It’s better to be told to come up higher

than to be put down lower

in the presence of a prince.

What you’ve seen

8don’t rush to court over;

what will you do at the end of the trial

if the one you accuse puts you to shame?

9When you’re arguing with your neighbor,

don’t betray another person’s confidence;

10people may find out and accuse you of gossiping,

and you won’t regain your good reputation.	Prov 25:6-10

11Words fitly spoken in the proper place

are like golden apples in a silver setting.

12A wise correction to an attentive ear

is like a gold earring or jewelry.

13An employer’s reliable messenger

refreshes like cold snow at harvest time.

14People that brag falsely about what they’ll do

are like clouds and wind without rain.

15Patience can persuade a prince;

a soft tongue can break a bone.

16Have you found honey?

Don’t eat too much of it and make yourself sick.

17Don’t visit your friends too often;

they’ll get tired of you.

18Someone that slanders

is like a club, a sword, a sharp arrow.	Prov 25:11-18

19Depending on undependable people in hard times

is like chewing with a broken tooth

or walking on a sprained ankle.

20Singing to a heavy heart

is like removing your coat on a cold day

or pouring vinegar on lye.

21If your enemies are hungry, feed them;

if they’re thirsty, give them a drink;

22you’ll be dumping hot coals on their head,

and the LORD will reward you.	Prov 25:19-22

23A north wind brings rain;

a back-biting tongue brings angry looks.

24It’s better to live in the corner of a housetop

than inside a house with a contentious woman.

25Good news from a distant land

is like cool water to a weary soul.

26Good people that cave in to sinful people

are like trampled springs and polluted wells.

27Don’t eat too much honey;

don’t seek your own honor.

28Someone that’s out of control

is like an unwalled city; it’s open to attack.	Prov 25:23-28

26:1Like snow in summer and rain at harvest,

honor is out of place on a fool.

2Like a flitting sparrow, like a fluttering swallow,

an undeserved curse doesn’t land on its intended victim.

3A whip is for a horse,

a bridle is for a donkey,

a rod is for the back of a fool.

4Don’t answer fools’ arguments;

you’ll dignify them with a response.

5Answer fools’ arguments;

otherwise, they’ll think they’ve won.

6Trusting a fool to deliver a message

is like cutting off your feet or drinking poison. 	Prov 26:1-6

7A proverb in the mouth of a fool

is like legs hanging from the lame.

8Honoring a fool

is as dangerous as putting a stone in a sling.

9A proverb in the mouth of a fool

is like a thorn in the hand of a drunk.

10Whoever hires a fool or passerby

is like an archer that shoots at random.

11A fool that repeats his folly

is like a dog that returns to its vomit.

12There’s more hope for fools

than for people that think they’re smart.	Prov 26:7-12

13Lazy people claim there’s a lion in the road!

There’s surely a lion in the public square!

14Like a door swinging on its hinges,

15Lazy people stick their fingers in the plate

but they don’t even bring the food to their mouth.

16Lazy people think they’re smarter

than seven wise advisors.

17A passerby that meddles in other people’s conflict

is like someone taking a dog by the ears.	Prov 26:13-17

18-19Someone that lies

and says, “Just kidding,”

is as dangerous as a maniac

that’s shooting flaming arrows.

20For lack of wood a fire goes out;

where there’s no gossip, quarreling dies down.

21Contentious people spark conflict

like charcoal on hot embers or wood on fire.

22Rumors are like delicious morsels;

they work their way down deep inside you!

23Warm lips and a base heart

are like silver glaze on a clay pot.	Prov 26:18-23

24People disguise disdain with words
