THE LAMENTATIONS OF JEREMIAH

Jerusalem Deserted

1:1How lonely the city sits that used to bustle with people!

She’s like a widow that was once great among the nations!

The princess among the provinces has become a slave!

2She cries bitterly at night; tears are on her cheeks.

Nobody among her lovers is there to comfort her.

Her friends have betrayed her

and become her enemies.

3Judah has gone into exile in suffering and hard servitude;

she’s spread out among the nations now;

with no resting place.

Her pursuers have caught up with her in the middle of her distress.

4The roads to Zion are in mourning

because nobody attends the appointed festivals.

Her gates are desolate, her priests groan,

her virgins suffer, and she suffers bitterly herself.	Lam 1:1-4

5Her adversaries have become her masters; her enemies prosper.

The LORD has made her suffer for her many sins.

Her children have gone away captive to the foe.

6The majesty is gone from Zion;

her officials are like bucks that can’t find pasture;

they’ve fled away weak before their pursuers.

7In her time of suffering and homelessness,

Jerusalem remembers her treasured things from before;

when her people fell to her adversaries and nobody helped her,

the enemies gloated over her and mocked her downfall.

8Jerusalem sinned grievously, so she’s become filthy.

Everybody that honored her before despises her now,

because they’ve seen her nakedness;

she groans and turns away.	Lam 1:5-8

9Her uncleanness was in her skirts;

she didn’t give any thought to her doom;

so she’s fallen terribly with no comforter.

10The foe has reached out for her treasured things;

she has watched the nations invade her sanctuary,

people you commanded not to enter your community.

11The people are groaning as they look for bread;

they’ve given their treasured things for food to stay alive;

“Look, LORD, I’m despised.

12Is it nothing to you that go by?

Look and see if there’s any pain like my pain

that was severely dealt out to me,

that the LORD inflicted in his fierce anger.	Lam 1:9-12

13He sent fire from on high into my bones, and it descended on them.

He spread a net for my feet and turned me back;

he left me desolate and faint all day long.

14He has tied my sins together into a yoke around my neck;

he has made my strength fail,

and turned me over to those I can’t withstand.

15The Lord has rejected the strong men that are with me;

he has called an appointed time against me to crush my young men;

like a winepress he has trodden down the young virgin Judah.

16I weep for those things; my eyes run down with tears

because there’s no comforter near to restore my soul.

My children are desolate because the enemy has prevailed.”	Lam 1:13-16

17Zion holds out her hands, but there’s no one to comfort her;

the LORD has commanded against Jacob

that his neighbors would be his enemies;

Jerusalem has become something filthy in their minds.

18“The LORD is good; I’ve rebelled against his command;

listen now, all you nations, and look at my pain;

my virgins and young men have gone into captivity.

19I called to my lovers, but they deceived me;

my priests and elders perished in the city

as they looked for food to stay alive.

20Look, LORD, because I’m in distress; my soul is in turmoil.

My heart’s upset because I’ve been rebellious.

The sword bereaves in the street; it’s like death in the house.	Lam 1:17-20

21They’ve heard that I’m groaning with nobody to comfort me.

My enemies have heard about my trouble;

they’re glad you’ve done it.

Bring the time you’ve promised,

and let them be like me.

22Pay attention to their sinfulness,,

and deal with them like you’ve dealt with me for my sins.

I groan a lot, and my heart is faint.”	Lam 1:21-22

Destruction for Sin

2:1How the Lord in his anger has covered Zion under a cloud!

He has thrown down Israel’s splendor from heaven to earth;

he hasn’t remembered his footstool in his wrath.

2Without mercy the Lord has swallowed up the residents in Jacob.

In his anger he has thrown down Judah’s fortresses

and leveled the kingdom and its officials to the ground in dishonor.

3In his fury he has cut down Israel’s power

and stopped restraining the enemy.

He has burned like a fire in Jacob

and consumed it everywhere.

4He has bent his bow like an enemy;

he has set his right hand like an adversary

and killed everybody we took pride in.

He has poured out his anger like fire in the tent of Zion.	Lam 2:1-4

5The Lord has become like an enemy;

he has swallowed up Israel,

laid its palaces in ruins,

destroyed its fortresses,

and multiplied mourning and groaning in Judah.

6He’s violently treated his Tabernacle like a garden shed

and laid in ruins his appointed meeting place.

The LORD has stricken from memory

the appointed festivals and Sabbaths in Zion,

and deposed king and priest in his angry indignation.

7The Lord has rejected his altar, disowned his sanctuary,

and delivered to the enemy the walls of its palaces.

A clamor was raised in the LORD’s Temple

like that of an appointed festival day.

8The LORD decided to destroy the wall around Zion.

He stretched out a line

and didn’t restrain his destroying.

He made rampart and wall mourn;

they’ve broken down together.	Lam 2:5-8

9Its gates have sunk into the ground;

he has ruined and broken its bars

and scattered its king and officials among the nations.

There’s no law anymore;

prophets don’t have visions from the LORD.

10The elders of Zion sit silent on the ground;

they’ve thrown dust on their heads

and wrapped themselves in burlap.

The virgins of Jerusalem have bowed their heads to the ground.

11My eyes are worn out from crying;

my spirit is in turmoil;

my heart is poured out on the ground

because my people have been destroyed;

the little ones and babies pass out in the street.

12They ask their mothers, “Where is the bread and wine?”

as they faint like wounded men in the city streets,

as their life dies out on their mother’s chest.	Lam 2:9-12

13What can I say for you?

What can I compare you to, young woman in Jerusalem?

What can I liken you to, as I comfort you, young virgin in Zion?

Your ruin is as wide as the sea; who can restore you?

14Your prophets have deceived you with false visions;

they haven’t exposed your iniquity to restore you from sin;

they’ve seen false, misleading oracles for you.

15Everybody that goes by claps their hands at you;

they gasp and shake their heads at Jerusalem,

“Is this the city they used to say was ‘perfectly beautiful,

a delight to the whole world’?”

16Your enemies mock you;

they scoff and snarl,

and shout, “We’ve swallowed you up!

That’s what we’ve been waiting for;

at last it’s here to see.”	Lam 2:13-16

17The LORD has accomplished his purpose

and carried out the threat he ordained long ago.

He has destroyed without pity

and enabled your enemies to celebrate over you

and increased the power of your adversaries.

18Their heart appealed to the Lord,

“Resident of Zion, let your tears run down like a river day and night;

don’t give yourself any relief or let your eyes rest.

19Get up, cry out loud at the beginning of the night watches;

pour your heart out like water to the Lord;

lift your hands up to him for the life of your little ones

who are faint from hunger at the end of every street.”

20See, LORD, look! Who else have you ever dealt with this way?

Should women eat their offspring, little babies born healthy?

Should prophet and priest be killed in your sanctuary?	Lam 2:17-20

21Young and old lie on the ground in the streets;

my virgins and young men have fallen by the sword.

You’ve slain them in your anger,

slaughtered them without mercy.

22You invited terrors on every side of me as to an appointed festival.

Nobody escaped or survived your anger.

My enemy destroyed the ones I cared for and raised.	Lam 2:21-22

Hope in the LORD’s Faithfulness

3:1I have seen suffering

under the rod God used in his anger.

2He has driven me out and made me walk in the dark;

3he has turned his hand against me repeatedly all day.

4He made my skin and body waste away,

and broke my bones.	Lam 3:1-4

5He besieged me with bitterness and hardship.

6He made me live in dark places

like the dead from long ago.

7He walled me in so I couldn’t escape

and put heavy chains on me.

8Even when I call for help,

he shuts out my prayer.	Lam 3:5-8

9He has blocked my road with hewn stones

and made my paths crooked.

10He’s like a bear lying in wait for me,

like a lion in unexpected places.

11He dragged me off the road, tore me to pieces;

and made me desolate.

12He bent his bow and made me a target for his arrow;	Lam 3:9-12

13he shot deep into me the arrows from his quiver.

14I’m a laughingstock to my people,

mocked in musical ditties all day.

15He filled me with bitterness

and made me drink wormwood.

16He cracked my teeth with gravel

and made me grovel in the dust.	Lam 3:13-16

17I’ve been set apart from peace

and forget what happiness is like.

18So I say, “My strength is gone,

and so is my hope in the LORD.”

19Remember my suffering and homelessness.

20I certainly remember

and am humbled within.	Lam 3:17-20

21I recall this and have hope from it:

22The LORD’s love never stops coming;

his mercies don’t end.

23His faithfulness is great;

it’s renewed every morning.

24I say to myself, “The LORD is my portion;

so I have hope in him.”	Lam 3:21-24

25The LORD is good to those who depend on him,

people that look for him.

26They do well to wait silently for his salvation.

27It’s good for people to bear the yoke when they’re young,

28to sit alone in silence, since God has laid it on them,

29to put their mouth in the dust—maybe there’s hope,

30to turn their cheek to their abuser,

to be filled with disgrace;

31because the LORD won’t reject forever.	Lam 3:25-31

32If he causes grief, he’ll have mercy

according to his enduring love;

33because he doesn’t willingly hurt people or grieve them.

34-36God doesn’t approve

of crushing every prisoner in the land under his feet,

of depriving people of justice in the presence of the Most High,

of defrauding people in his lawsuit.

37Who is there that speaks and it happens

unless the Lord has commanded it?

38Don’t both good and bad come from the Most High?	Lam 3:32-38

39Why should we complain in light of our sins?

40Let’s examine our ways and return to the LORD.

41Let’s lift up our heart and hands toward God in heaven;

42we’ve sinned and rebelled; you haven’t pardoned us.

43You’ve covered yourself with anger and chased us;

you’ve slain without pity.

44You’ve wrapped yourself in a cloud

so no prayer can get to you.	Lam 3:39-44

45You’ve made us residue and refuse among the nations.

46Our enemies rail out against us.

47Panic and pitfall descend on us, devastation and destruction.

48My eyes run with streams of tears

because my people are being destroyed.

49My eyes will keep pouring out

50till the LORD looks down from heaven and sees.

51My eyes bring pain to my soul

because of all the residents in my city.

52For no reason my enemies hunted me down like a bird;

53they’ve silenced me in the pit, and put a stone over me;

54water closed over my head; I said, “I’m lost.”

55I called to you, LORD, from down in the pit.	Lam 3:45-55

56You heard my plea

and didn’t hide from my prayer for relief, my call for help.

57You came and said, “Don’t be afraid!”

58Lord, you pled my case and redeemed my life.

59LORD, you’ve seen my oppression; judge my case.

60You’ve seen their revenge, their schemes against me.

61You’ve heard their taunts.

62My assailants’ whispers aim at me all day.

63Look at their sitting and rising;

I’m what they mock in their song.

64Pay them back, LORD, according to what they’ve done;

65harden their heart so your curse will fall on them.

66Chase them in anger and destroy them from under the sky!	Lam 3:56-66

The LORD’s Anger Satisfied

4:1How the gold has tarnished; how pure gold has changed!

The holy stones lie scattered at the beginning of every street.

2The precious sons of Zion, worth their weight in gold,

are treated like clay pots that potters make!

3Even jackals nurse their young,

but my people have become cruel like wild ostriches.

4The infant’s tongue sticks to the roof of its mouth for thirst;

little ones beg for bread, but nobody gives them any.

5People that used to eat delicacies sit desolate in the streets;

the ones brought up in purple lie on ash heaps.

6The iniquity of my people is worse than the sin of Sodom,

which was overthrown without hands in one moment.

7Zion’s Nazirites were purer than snow, whiter than milk,

healthier looking than corals, like polished lapis lazuli.	Lam 4:1-7

8Now they’re darker than soot, not recognizable in the streets;

their skin is shriveled on their bones, withered like wood.

9Those killed with the sword are happier than those slain by hunger;

they pine away, stricken for lack of crops in the field.

10Merciful women boiled their own children;

they became their food because my people were being destroyed.

11The LORD has accomplished his wrath,

poured out his hot anger,

and sparked a fire in Zion that has consumed its foundations.

12The kings and inhabitants of the region

didn’t believe enemies could get in the gates of Jerusalem. 	Lam 4:8-12

13Because of its prophets’ sins and its priests’ iniquities—

who shed the blood of good people in it—

14they wandered in the streets, blind and defiled with blood

so nobody would even touch their clothes.

15They shouted at them, “Get away! Unclean! Don’t touch!”

So they fled and wandered.

People in the nations said, “They can’t stay here anymore.”

16The LORD has scattered them;

he won’t continue to care especially about them;

they didn’t honor the priests or bless the elders.	Lam 4:13-16

17Our eyes failed us; looking for help was useless;

we certainly watched for a nation that couldn’t save.

18People dogged our steps so we couldn’t walk in the streets;

our end came near, our days failed, we were through.	Lam 4:17-18

19Our pursuers were faster than eagles in the sky;

they chased us on the mountains and ambushed us in the desert.

20Our very breath, the LORD’s anointed, was captured in their pits;

we’d said about him, “In his shadow we’ll live among the nations.”

21Celebrate and be happy, Edom that lives in Uz;

the cup will come around to you as well; you’ll be drunk and naked.

22The punishment for your sinfulness is finished, Zion;

he won’t exile you any longer.

But he’ll punish your iniquity, Edom;

he’ll expose your sins!	Lam 4:19-22

Prayer for Restoration

5:1LORD, remember what’s happened to us;

look at our disgrace!

2Our inheritance has been turned over to foreigners,

and our houses belong to aliens.

3We’ve become orphans without fathers;

our mothers are like widows.

4We have to pay for drinking water and buy wood.

5Our drivers put yokes on our necks;

we’re worn out; we can’t get any rest.	Lam 5:1-5

6We’ve submitted to Egypt and Assyria to get enough bread.

7Our fathers sinned, and they’re gone,

but we have to suffer for their sins.

8Slaves rule us; nobody can deliver us from them.

9We risk our lives just getting bread

because of the sword in the open country.

10Our skin is hot like an oven,

because of the burning heat of famine.

11They rape the women in Zion

and the virgins in the towns in Judah.	Lam 5:6-11

12They hang up officials by their hands

and show no respect for old men.

13Young men work at the grinding mill

and stagger under loads of wood.

14Elders are gone from the city gate,

young men have quit their music.

15The joy in our hearts is gone;

our dancing has turned into mourning.

16The crown has fallen from our head;

misfortune awaits us because we’ve sinned!

17Our heart is faint because of it;

our eyes are weak.

18Jackals prowl in desolate Zion.	Lam 5:12-18

19LORD, you rule forever;

your throne goes on for endless generations.

20Why don’t you keep us in mind forever?

21Restore us to yourself, LORD, so we can be restored;

renew our days as of old,

22unless you’ve completely rejected us

and are really angry with us.	Lam 5:19-22

EZEKIEL

A Vision of Living Beings and

the Glory of the LORD

1:1The fifth day, fourth month, thirtieth year, I was by the Chebar River with the exiles. The sky opened up, and I saw a vision of God. (2The fifth month, fifth year of Jehoiachin’s exile, 3God’s message came to Ezekiel, and God’s hand came on him.) 4A strong north wind was blowing, and a large cloud with a bright glow around it flashed constantly with lightning. In the cloud was something like glowing metal 5and four figures like living beings with human forms. 6Each one had four faces and four wings. 7They had straight legs, and their feet resembled calf hooves that shined like polished bronze. 8There were hands under their wings, 9and the wings of all four touched each other. Their faces didn’t turn as they moved straight forward. 10Each one had the faces of a man, an eagle, a lion on the right, and a bull on the left. 11Their wings spread out above them, two wings touching the wings of the next living beings and two covering their bodies. 12They went straight forward wherever the spirit went, without turning as they went. 13Among the beings were what looked like burning coals, like torches moving back and forth. The fire burned bright, and lightning kept flashing out of it. 14The living beings darted back and forth like bolts of lightning.	Ezek 1:1-14

15A wheel appeared on the ground beside each living being. 16The wheels looked like glowing chrysolite built with a wheel inside a wheel. 17When they moved in any of the four directions, they moved without turning. 18Their rims were tall with eyes all the way around.            19-20When the living beings left the ground or moved, the wheels moved with them. The spirit of the living beings was in the wheels. [21]

22A bright expanse glowed like crystal above them. 23Under it their wings stretched out toward one another, and two wings covered the sides of their bodies. 24Their wings sounded like rushing water, like the Almighty, like war, like an army camp. When they stood still, they lowered their wings, 25and a voice spoke from the expanse above them.	Ezek 1:15-25

26High above the expanse was a throne the color of lapis lazuli; the One sitting on it resembled a man. 27From the waist up, he glowed like metal on fire; from the waist down, he resembled fire. The radiance around him was 28like a rainbow on a rainy day. This scene looked like the glory of the LORD. When I saw it, I fell on my face and heard a voice, 	     Ezek 1:26-28

2:1“Son of man, stand up so I can talk to you!” 2When the Spirit stood me up, 3he said,

“I’m sending you to the Israelites, a rebellious people. They and their ancestors have been sinning against me to this day. 4Tell those impudent, stubborn children, ‘The Lord GOD says.’ 5Whether they listen or not, they’ll know a prophet’s been there. 6Don’t be afraid of them or intimidated by what they say, though you’re surrounded by briars and thorns and sitting on scorpions. 7Tell them what I’ve said whether they listen or not.      	Ezek 2:1-7

8“Don’t be like that rebellious house. Eat what I’m giving you.” 9A hand held out a scroll to me. 10When he unrolled it for me, I could see writing on both sides—lamentations, mourning, and misfortune. 3:1“Eat this scroll and go speak to Israel.” 2So I opened my mouth, and he fed it to me. 3It tasted sweet like honey.	Ezek 2:8-3:3

[4] 5-6“I’m not sending you to people that speak a hard foreign language you can’t understand. I’m sending you to people that should listen; 7but they won’t listen to you, because they won’t listen to me. The whole house is stubborn. 8I’ve made your face and forehead as hard as theirs, 9like corundum, harder than flint. So don’t be afraid of them or be intimidated by them though they’re rebellious people. 10Listen closely and take everything to heart that I tell you. 11Go to your people in exile and tell them, ‘The Lord GOD says,’ whether they listen or not.”

12The Spirit picked me up, and I heard a loud rumbling sound behind me, “Bless the LORD in his place.” 13I was hearing the wings of the living beings that touched one another and had the wheels beside them. 14The Spirit took me away; I felt bitter and angry, and the LORD’s hand weighed heavy on me. 15I went to the exiles by the Chebar River at Tel-abib and sat there with them for a week, feeling overwhelmed.	Ezek 3:4-15

A Watchman for Israel

16A week later a message came from the LORD:

17“Son of man, I’ve appointed you to be a watchman for Israel. Whenever you hear something from me, warn them. 18When I tell sinful people they’re going to die, and you don’t warn them so they can live, they’ll die in their sin, but I’ll hold you responsible for it. 19If you’ve warned them, and they don’t change, they’ll die in their sin, but you’ve delivered yourself. 20On the other hand, when good people start sinning and I block them, they’ll die. Since you didn’t warn them, they’ll die in their sin. I won’t consider the good they’d done, but I’ll hold you responsible for their death. 21But if you’ve warned them and they quit sinning, they’ll live because they listened, and you’ll deliver yourself.”

Ezek 3:16-21

22The LORD put hand on me there and said, “Get up and go out to the plain, and I’ll talk to you.” 23The glory of the LORD was there, glory like I’d seen by the Chebar River; I fell on my face. 24The Spirit came into me and stood me up, and said,

“Go shut yourself up in your house. 25They’ll tie you up with ropes so you can’t go out among them. 26I’ll make your tongue stick to the roof of your mouth so you can’t talk. You won’t be able to rebuke them because they’re a rebellious house. 27But when I speak to you and you tell them, ‘The Lord GOD says,’ the ones that listen will listen; the ones that won’t, won’t. They’re a rebellious house.         	    Ezek 3:22-27

Siege of Jerusalem Symbolized

4:1“Now, son of man, take a tablet and etch Jerusalem on it. 2Lay a siege against it with a siege wall and ramp, pitch camps, and position battering rams all around it. 3Then set up an iron plate as a wall between you and the city. Face it and press the siege against it. It’s an omen for Israel.

4“Lie down on your left side, and I’ll lay Israel’s punishment on you. You’ll bear their punishment for the number of days you lie on it. 5Lie like that one day for each of the 390 years they’ve sinned. 6When you’ve finished, lie down on your right side, and bear Judah’s sin. I’ve assigned you 40 days, one for each year. 7Then you’ll face the siege of Jerusalem with your arm bared, and prophesy against it. 8I’ve tied you up with ropes so you can’t turn from one side to the other till you’ve finished the days of your siege.	Ezek 4:1-8

9“Take wheat, barley, beans, lentils, millet, and spelt; put them in one container and bake bread. Eat it for the 390 days you’re lying on your side. 10Once a day eat 8 oz 20 shekels of food 11and drink a quart ⅙ hin of water. 12Eat it like a barley cake after you’ve baked it in front of them over human feces. 13That’s how the Israelites will eat their bread unclean among the nations where I’ll banish them.”

14But I said, “Lord GOD, since I was a kid, I’ve never defiled myself by eating ceremonially unclean meat, anything that died, anything an animal had torn in pieces.”

15He said, “I’ll give you cow manure instead of human feces to bake your bread. 16I’m going to break the staff of bread in Jerusalem. They’ll ration bread by weight with fear and water by measure in alarm. 17Bread and water will be scarce; people will look at one another in dismay and waste away in their sin.”

Ezek 4:9-17

5:1“Son of man, take a sharp sword and shave off your hair and beard. Divide up the hair on a scales. 2Burn a third of it in the center of the city when the siege is over. Strike a third of it with a sword all around the city. Scatter another third of it in the wind, because I’m going to chase my people with a drawn sword. 3Attach a few to the hem of your robe. 4Throw a few in the fire. They’ll spread from the fire to the whole House of Israel.  5I’ve set Jerusalem in the center of the nations. 6It rebelled against my ordinances and statutes more than those other nations did.” 	Ezek 5:1-6

7So the Lord GOD says, “I’m against you; there’s more turmoil in you than in the nations around you. You haven’t followed my statutes or observed my ordinances or even [LXX] the ordinances of surrounding nations. 8I’ll carry out judgments on you for the nations to see. 9Because of your detestable deeds, I’ll do to you what I’ve never done before or will ever do again. 10Fathers will eat their own sons and sons will eat their fathers. My condemnations will scatter your remnant in every direction. 11As I live, I’ll withdraw from you because you’ve defiled my sanctuary with your detestable idols and carved images. I won’t pity or spare. 12A third of you will die by disease and starvation, a third will fall by the sword, a third I’ll scatter in every direction from the drawn sword.	      Ezek 5:7-12

13“That’s how I’ll vent my fury on you. You’ll know I’ve said it. 14I’ll make a wasteland out of you among the nations, something everyone that passes by will consider a disgrace, 15a taunt, a warning, something they’ll abhor when I carry out condemnations on you in anger and rebuke. 16When I send you the deadly arrows of famine meant for your foes, I’ll intensify it to break your staff of bread. 17Wild animals will bereave you of your children. Disease, sword, and bloodshed will surge through you. I’ve said so.”     	 Ezek 5:13-17

A Prophecy Against the Mountains of Israel

6:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, face Israel’s mountains and prophesy, 3‘Listen to the Lord GOD’s message to the mountains and hills, ravines and valleys: “I’m going to bring a sword against you and destroy your high places. 4Your altars will be demolished and your incense altars smashed. You’ll fall slain in front of your idols, 5and I’ll scatter your bones around your altars. 6Everywhere you live, towns will be waste, high places desolate, idols broken, incense altars cut down, and the religious objects you’ve made, destroyed. 7You’ll know I’m the LORD.

8“But I’ll leave a few of you. You’ll abhor yourselves for those detestable deeds. 10You’ll know I’m the LORD, that I meant it when I said I’d inflict you with this disaster.”’	  Ezek 6:1-10

11“The Lord GOD says, ‘Clap your hands, stomp your feet, say, “This has happened because of Israel’s abominations. It will fall by sword, famine, and disease! 12The one that’s far off will die by the disease. The one that’s nearby will fall by the sword. The one that’s left and besieged will starve to death.” That’s how I’ll vent my fury on you. 13Your slain will lie among your idols, around your altars, on every tall hill and mountaintop, under every green tree and leafy terebinth tree—where you offered a soothing aroma to your idols. 14The land will be more desolate than the desert toward Diblah. That’s how you’ll know I’m the LORD.’”         	   Ezek 6:11-14

The End Has Come

7:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, the Lord GOD says to Israel, ‘The end is coming on the four corners of your land. 3I’ll judge you by your ways, direct my anger at you, and bring your detestable things against you. 4I won’t pity or spare when I bring on you the consequences of your deeds with the detestable things you’ve used.’ 5A disaster—a unique disaster—is coming! 6The end is here! It has awakened against you! 7You’re doomed, resident in the land—confusion instead of happy shouting on the mountains. [8] 9You’ll know that I the LORD am striking you.

10“The rod has budded, arrogance has blossomed, 11violence has grown into a rod of sinfulness. Nothing will remain of their multitude, their wealth, or anything outstanding that they have. 12The buyer shouldn’t celebrate, the seller shouldn’t mourn, because anger is aimed at their abundance. 13The seller won’t regain what he sold as long as they’re both alive, because the vision about their affluence won’t fade away. Because of his sin, neither will live. 	  Ezek 7:1-13

14“They’ve blown the bugle and everything’s ready, but nobody is going to battle because I’m angry with their whole population. 15The sword’s outside; famine and disease are inside. The ones out in the country will die by the sword; famine and disease will kill the ones in the city. 16Even when survivors escape, they’ll be on the mountains like pigeons from the valley, mourning over his sinfulness. 17Hands will hang limp; knees will be like water. 18They’ll put on burlap and shudder. Their faces will blush; their heads will be bald. 19They’ll toss their silver into the streets and abhor their gold. Their silver and gold won’t be able to deliver them from the LORD’s anger. They won’t satisfy their hunger with it because that’s what made them stumble. 20The beautiful jewels they were so proud of, they used for making detestable idols; so I’ll turn their wealth into something detestable to them. 21I’ll give them to foreigners as plunder, to the sinful as spoil; and they’ll defile them. 22I’ll look the other way while invaders profane my precious land. Robbers will go in and defile it 23and make it desolate.

Ezek 7:14-23a

“The land’s filled with bloody crimes; the city’s full of violence. 24So I’ll bring the worst of the nations to take over their houses. I’ll put an end to their proud strength and profane their holy places. 25When anguish comes, they’ll look for peace, but there won’t be any, 26just disaster on top of disaster, rumor on top of rumor. They’ll find no vision from a prophet; the law will be lost from the priest and counsel from the elders. 27The king will mourn; the prince will put on rags; the people’s hands will tremble. 8:1The fifth day, sixth month, sixth year, I was sitting in my house with Judah’s elders sitting in front of me, and the hand of the Lord GOD came down on me. 2I saw what looked like a man. From the waist down, he looked like fire; from the waist up, he looked like bright glowing metal. 3He reached out with a hand and took hold of my hair. The Spirit lifted me up between earth and sky, and took me in a vision to Jerusalem, to the entrance of the north gate of the inner court, to the seat of the idol that provokes jealousy. 4The glory of Israel’s God was there—like what I’d seen in the plain.

5He said, “Son of man, look north.” North of the altar gate at the entrance, I saw this idol that made God jealous. 6“Do you see the detestable things Israel is doing here to keep me out of my own sanctuary? But you’ll see still more detestable things.”  	   Ezek 8:1-6

7Then he took me to the entrance to the court and showed me a hole in the wall. 8“Dig through the wall.” I dug through it and found an entrance. 9“Go in and see what awful, detestable things they’re doing.” 10I went in and saw the shape of every crawling thing, every animal and detestable thing along with Israel’s idols carved all around the wall. 11Seventy elders of Israel were standing in front of them with Jaazaniah son of Shaphan. Each one was holding a censer, and the fragrance of the incense was rising in a cloud.

12“See what Israel’s elders are doing in the dark in the room of carved images? They’re saying, ‘The LORD’s not watching us; he’s abandoned the land.’ 13You’ll see still more detestable things they’re doing.”          	   Ezek 8:7-13

17“See that? Isn’t it enough for Judah to do those detestable things, that they’ve filled the land with violence and provoked me time and again? They’re putting a twig up their nose. 18I’ll deal in anger. I won’t pity or spare. Though they call out loudly, I’ll ignore them.”	  Ezek 8:14-18

9:1He shouted, “Executioners, come here with your weapons.” 2Six men, each holding a shattering weapon, came from the direction of the upper gate, which faces north. One of them was wearing linen with a scribe’s inkhorn on his hip. They went in and stood beside the bronze altar.

The LORD’s Glory Leaves the Temple

10:1Then in the expanse above the cherubs, I saw something like a sapphire stone shaped like a throne. 2He spoke to the man dressed in linen, “Go between the turning wheels under the cherubs and fill your hands with coals. Scatter them over the city.” I watched him go in.

6When he told the man in linen to take fire from between the turning wheels, he went in and stood beside a wheel. 7A cherub reached out to the fire between the cherubs, took some coals, and put them in the man’s hand. 15The cherubs rose up—the living beings I’d seen by the Chebar River. 16When they moved, the wheels went beside them. You’ve followed the ordinances of the nations around you.”’”

17“Yet your people say, ‘The Lord’s way is not right,’ when it’s their own way that’s not right. 18When good people turn from their goodness, they’ll die because now they’re practicing sin. 19When sinful people turn from their sinfulness, they’ll live because they’re practicing goodness. 20Yet you say, ‘The Lord’s way is not right.’ House of Israel, I’ll judge each of you by your own ways.” 				Ezek 33:17-20

The ones in strongholds and caves will die from disease. 28I’ll make the land desolate; pride about its power will stop. Israel’s mountains will be so desolate nobody can get through them. 29They’ll know I’m the LORD when I make the land desolate because of their disgusting deeds.’  	Ezek 33:21-29

30“Son of man, your fellow citizens talk about you by the walls and in their doorways, ‘Come on, let’s hear a message from the LORD.’ 31They come and sit with you like my people, but they do the lustful things they talk about and set their hearts on making money. 32As far as they’re concerned, you’re someone with a beautiful voice that plays an instrument well and sings love songs. They hear what you’re saying, but they don’t do it. 33So when what you say does happen—as it surely will—they’ll know a prophet was among them.”  	  Ezek 33:30-33

I’ve said so.  				Ezek 34:17-24

25“I’ll make a peace treaty with them and get rid of dangerous animals so they can be safe in the countryside and sleep in the woods. 26I’ll make them and the places around my mountain a blessing. and you’ll be desolate.

5In your endless enmity, you delivered Israel to the sword at the time of its catastrophe, its final punishment. 6So as I live, I’ll deliver you to bloodshed. Since you haven’t despised bloodshed, it’ll pursue you. 7I’ll make Mount Seir a waste and slay everyone that tries to escape or return there. 8I’ll fill its mountains with the dead. They’ll fall in its hills, valleys, and ravines. 9I’ll make it a permanent wasteland and its towns uninhabited. It will know I’m the LORD.	  Ezek 35:1-9

10“Mount Seir has said, ‘I’m going to take over those two lands and make them mine’—though the LORD was there. 11So as I live,” the Lord GOD says, “I’ll deal with you in proportion to the anger, envy, and hate you’ve shown them. I’ll make myself known among them when I condemn you. 12You’ll know that I’ve heard your contempt for the mountains in Israel, ‘They’re desolate; they’ve been given to us to devour.’ 13I’ve heard you speak arrogantly against me over and over. 14While the whole world celebrates, I’ll make you desolate. 15As you celebrated Israel’s desolation, you’ll be desolate, Mount Seir and all Edom. You’ll know I’m the LORD.”   	Ezek 35:10-15

Prophecy to the Mountains of Israel

36:1“Son of man, prophesy to the mountains of Israel, ‘Listen to 2what the Lord GOD says, “Your enemy has ridiculed you, ‘Ha!’ and ‘The everlasting mountains are ours now!’” 3So prophesy, ‘For good reason other nations made you desolate and crushed you from every direction, took possession of you, and mocked and whispered.’” 4So, mountains of Israel, listen to the message from the Lord GOD to the mountains and hills, ravines and valleys, desolate wastes and abandoned towns that have become prey and objects of derision. 5In my burning jealousy, I’ve spoken against those nations, particularly Edom that took over my land with wholehearted joy and scornful attitude. I’ve sworn to drive it out to become prey. 6So prophesy to Israel’s mountains and hills, ravines and valleys, ‘I’ve spoken in my anger because you’ve had to endure the insults from other nations. 7I swear they will endure insults.’” 	Ezek 36:1-7

8“But you, mountains of Israel, will grow branches and bear fruit for my people because they’ll be coming back soon. 9I’ll return to you, and you’ll be cultivated and planted. 10People will multiply in Israel to live in the towns and rebuild the places in ruins. 11People and animals will reproduce in you. I’ll make you lived-in like before and treat you better than at first. So you’ll know I’m the LORD. 12My people carry on their lives in you and own you. You’ll become their inheritance and never again bereave them of children.” 13The Lord GOD says, “Other nations tell you, ‘You’ve devoured your people and bereaved them of children,’ 14but you won’t do that anymore. 15I won’t let you listen to their insults anymore. 22“So, tell Israel, ‘It’s not so much for your sake that I’m about to act; it’s in regard to my holy name that you’ve profaned where you’ve gone. 23I’ll vindicate the holiness of my great name. Then the nations will know I’m the LORD.”	   								    	   	   Ezek 36:16-23

You’ll be my people, and I’ll be your God. 29I’ll save you from your uncleanness, send you abundant crops of grain, and keep famine away from you. 30I’ll multiply fruit on your trees and produce in the fields. 31You’ll remember your sinful ways and deeds, and abhor yourselves. 32Understand that I’m not doing this because you deserve it. Be ashamed of yourselves, Israel!” 	Ezek 36:24-32

A Valley of Dry Bones

37:1-2The LORD’s hand was on me. He took me out in spirit and put me down in a valley full of dry bones, 2and had me walk around among them.

3“Son of man, can these bones come alive?”

“Lord GOD, you know.”

4“Prophesy over them, ‘Dry bones, listen to the LORD. 5I’ll put breath in you so you can come to life. 6I’ll put sinews on you, make flesh grow back, and cover you with skin. You’ll know I’m the LORD.’”

7As I prophesied, there was a rattling sound, and the bones came together, bone to bone. 8I saw sinews on them, flesh grew, and skin covered them; but they weren’t breathing. Ezek 37:1-8

9He told me to prophesy to their breath, “The Lord GOD says to come from the four winds and breathe on these slain so they can come to life.”

10So I prophesied and breath came into them, they came to life, and stood up, a big army.

11Then he said,

“Son of man, these bones are the whole House of Israel. They’re saying, ‘Our bones are dried up. Our hope is gone. We’re completely cut off.’ 12So prophesy that the Lord GOD says, ‘I’ll open your graves and resurrect you, and take you to Israel. 13You’ll know I’m the LORD when 14I’ve put my breath in you, you’ve come to life, and I’ve put you in your own land.’” 	Ezek 37:9-14

Daniel Taken to Babylon

1:1In the third year of Jehoiakim’s reign in Judah, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, laid siege to Jerusalem. 2The LORD delivered Jehoiakim to him, along with articles from God’s Temple. He took them to the temple of his god in the land of Shinar/Babylonia and put them in the treasury. 3He ordered Ashpenaz, his chief eunuch, to bring in some of the Israelites, including members of the royal family and the nobles, 4young men with no defects, good looking, intelligent, educated men that could serve in the king’s court. He had him teach them the language and literature of the Babylonians, 5and allotted them a daily ration of the royal food and the wine he drank. He assigned them three years of education; then they were to enter his personal service. 6Among them were Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah from the tribe of Judah. 7The chief eunuch renamed them: Daniel was Belteshazzar, Hananiah was Shadrach, Mishael was Meshach, and Azariah was Abed-nego.	Dan 1:1-7

8But Daniel made up his mind not to defile himself with the king’s wine and royal food, and asked the chief eunuch to let him not defile himself. 9God had given the chief eunuch respect and affection for Daniel, 10but he told him,

“The king specified what you should eat and drink. I’m afraid my lord would see that you weren’t as healthy as the other youths your age. You’d put my life in danger from him.”

11Daniel told the steward that the chief eunuch had appointed to oversee them,

12“Test us for ten days. Let us have vegetables and water. 13Then look at us and the youths that eat the king’s food, and deal with us by what you see.”

14He agreed and tested them for ten days. 15After ten days he could see that they looked better and were healthier than the ones who ate the king’s food. 16So the steward took away their wine and royal food and fed them vegetables.	 Dan 1:8-16

17God gave these four youths an aptitude for learning and skill in every branch of literature and wisdom. Daniel understood visions and dreams. 18At the end of the time the king had specified, the chief eunuch brought them in. 19The king talked to them, and none of them impressed him like Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah; so they entered the king’s service. 20In every matter of wisdom and understanding he asked them about, he found them ten times more capable than the magicians and enchanters in his whole empire. 21Daniel continued till the first year of King Cyrus. 	Dan 1:17-21

Nebuchadnezzar’s Dream

2:1In the second year of Nebuchadnezzar’s reign, haunting dreams kept him awake. 2He gave orders to call in the magicians, conjurers, sorcerers, and astrologers to tell him what he’d dreamed. When they came in, 3he told them, “I had a dream, and I’m disturbed about what it means.”

4The astrologers said in Aramaic, “Long live the King! Tell us the dream, and we’ll tell you what it means.”

5“I’m giving an unalterable command. If you don’t tell me what I dreamed and its meaning, I’ll have you torn limb from limb, and make your houses trash piles. 6But if you tell me, I’ll reward you with gifts and high honor. So tell me the dream and its interpretation.”

7“Tell us the dream, and we’ll tell you what it means.”

8“You’re stalling because you can see I’ve given an unalterable command. 9If you don’t tell me the dream, there’s only one decree for you. You’ve conspired to lie and say bogus things till I change my mind. Tell me what I dreamed so I know you can tell me what it means.”

10“Nobody can do that. No great king or ruler has ever asked such a thing from any magician, conjurer, or astrologer. 11What you’re demanding is not possible. Nobody but the gods can tell you that, and they don’t live in mortal flesh.”

12At this, the king was furious and gave orders to destroy the wise men in Babylon. 13The decree went out to execute them, and they started looking for Daniel and his friends to kill them.

God Gives Daniel the Dream’s Interpretation

14With prudence and discretion Daniel answered Arioch, captain of the king’s bodyguard, who’d gone out to execute the wise men, 15“Why is the king’s decree so urgent?” Arioch told him what had happened. 16So Daniel went in and asked the king for some time so he could tell him the interpretation. 17He went home and informed his three friends about the matter 18so they could ask for mercy from the God of heaven about that mystery, so Daniel and his friends wouldn’t die with the rest of the wise men in Babylon. 19The mystery came to Daniel in a vision during the night, and he blessed the God of heaven:

because of his wisdom and power.

removes kings and appoints them.

and the knowledgeable their insight.

he knows what’s in the dark,

because you’ve given me wisdom and authority.

27Daniel said,

36“That’s what you dreamed. The Handwriting on the Wall

5:1King Belshazzar held a huge feast for 1,000 of his nobles and drank wine with them. 2While he was tasting the wine, he sent for the gold and silver items his predecessor Nebuchadnezzar had taken out of the Temple in Jerusalem. 3The king, his nobles, wives, and concubines drank out of them, 4and praised their idols made out of gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone.

5All of a sudden, the fingers of a man’s hand appeared and started writing on the plaster wall across from the lampstand. The king could see the back of the hand as it wrote. 6His face grew pale with terror, his hip joints went slack, his knees knocked. 7He shouted for his conjurers, astrologers, and fortunetellers. He told the wise men in Babylon, “Anybody that can read this inscription and tell me what it means will dress in purple, wear a gold chain around his neck, and be third in the empire.” 8His wise men came in, but they couldn’t read it or explain what it meant. 9He was scared, his face grew more pale, and his nobles were baffled.	 Dan 5:1-9

In your predecessor’s time, he showed enlightenment, insight, and wisdom like the gods have. King Nebuchadnezzar appointed him chief of magicians, conjurers, astrologers, and fortunetellers. 12That was because this Daniel—that the king named Belteshazzar—had a special spirit, knowledge, insight, interpretation of dreams, explanation of enigmas, and solving of difficult problems. Daniel in the Lions’ Den

6:1King Darius thought it good to appoint 120 satraps to oversee the empire. 2He put three commissioners over them. (Daniel was one of them.) The satraps would report to them, and they would protect the king’s interests. 3Daniel soon distinguished himself among the satraps and other commissioners because he had exceptional ability. The king planned to appoint him over the whole empire. 4Then the commissioners and satraps tried to find some grounds for accusing him of mismanaging government affairs, but they couldn’t find any evidence of corruption. He was dependable, and they couldn’t find him negligent. 5They said, “We won’t find any grounds for accusing him unless it’s in connection with the Law of his god.”     	Dan 6:1-5

6They went to the king together and said,

“Long live King Darius! 7The commissioners, prefects and satraps, high officials and governors have agreed that you should enforce a statute that anybody who asks for anything from any mortal or god but you for 30 days will be thrown in the lions’ den. 8Now, establish the injunction and sign the document so it can’t be revoked—like the law of the Medes and Persians.”

9So Darius signed the injunction.

10When Daniel found out he’d signed it, he went home. In his roof room with windows open toward Jerusalem, he continued to kneel three times a day, praying and giving thanks before his God. 11Those men came to his house together and found him making petition to his God; 12so they went to the king, “Didn’t you sign an injunction that anybody who asks anything from any mortal or god besides you for 30 days would be thrown into the lions’ den?”

He said, “It’s true; the law of the Medes and Persians can’t be revoked.”

13They answered, “Daniel, an exile from Judah, is not honoring your injunction. He keeps praying to his God three times a day.”	  Dan 6:6-13

14When the king heard it, he was deeply distressed and tried all day to figure out some way to rescue Daniel. 15Then those men came back and said, “You know, O King, it’s the law of the Medes and Persians that no injunction or statute the king makes can be revoked.”

16So he gave the order, and Daniel was brought in and thrown into the lions’ den. He told Daniel, “The God you constantly serve will deliver you himself.” 17They brought a stone and laid it over the mouth of the den. The king sealed it with his signet ring and his nobles’ signet rings so nothing could be changed. 18He spent the night in his palace fasting. No entertainment was brought to him, and he couldn’t sleep.	 Dan 6:14-18

19He got up at dawn and hurried to the lions’ den. 20Worried, he called out, “Daniel, servant of the living God, has the God you constantly serve, delivered you from the lions?”

21Daniel said,

“Long live the King! 22My God sent his angel and shut their mouths. They haven’t hurt me because he considered me innocent. I haven’t committed any crime against you either.”

23The king was really relieved and had him brought up out of the den. They didn’t find any injury on him because he’d trusted in his God. 24The king ordered the men to be brought who had maliciously accused Daniel, and threw them, their children, and wives into the den. They hadn’t hit the den floor before the lions pounced on them and crushed their bones.

Dan 6:19-24

25Then Darius wrote to the peoples, nations, and language groups in the empire:

“Peace and prosperity!

26I decree that in all my kingdom, people tremble in fear before Daniel’s God.

He’s the living God that endures forever;

his kingdom will never be destroyed;

his rule will never end.

27He delivers and rescues, and performs signs and wonders

on earth and in the sky—

28So Daniel enjoyed success during the regency of Darius and the reign of Cyrus the Persian.

He’ll distribute plunder, booty, and possessions among them. He’ll plot against fortresses, but only for a while. 25He’ll stir up his courage against the king of the South with a large army. So the king of the South will mobilize a very big army, but he won’t stand because there’ll be plots against him. 26The members of his own household will cause his downfall. His army will be swept away, and many will be slain. 27Both kings will be intent on evil and lie to each other at the conference table; but to no avail because the end will come at the appointed time.

28The king of the South will head for home with considerable substance. On the way, he’ll set himself against the people of the holy covenant, and do a lot of damage before going on back to his own land.	Dan 11:20-28

29“At the appointed time, he’ll invade the South again, but this time it won’t turn out like before. 30Ships from Kittim will attack him. He’ll retreat and take his out anger on the people of the holy covenant. So he’ll come and listen to the ones that forsake the holy covenant. 31His army will defile the Temple fortress, forbid the daily burnt offering, and set up the abomination that makes desolate. 32By flattery he’ll turn to godlessness those who’ve violated the covenant, but the people that know their God will stay strong and resist him. 33Wise leaders among the people will instruct many, though they’ll fall by flame and sword, be captured and robbed. 34They’ll receive little help, and many who do join them won’t be sincere. 35Some of the wise will fall victim to persecution as a means of refining and cleansing them, making them pure till the time of the end, because the appointed time is still to come. 	Dan 11:29-35

36“The king will do as he pleases, put himself above every god, and blaspheme the God of gods. He’ll succeed till the time of wrath is over because what’s been decreed will happen. 37He won’t show any regard for the gods of his ancestors, for any god women favor, or for any other god. He’ll magnify himself above them all. 38Instead, he’ll honor the god of fortresses, a god his ancestors never knew. He’ll honor him with gold, silver, costly gems, and costly gifts. 39He’ll attack the strongest fortresses with the help of a foreign god, and greatly honor those who acknowledge him. He’ll make them rulers over many people and parcel out land among them as their reward.	Dan 11:36-39

40“Toward the end of Israel’s time, the king of the South will attack him, and the king of the North will storm out against him like a tornado with chariots, cavalry, and a large navy. He’ll invade various lands and overrun them. 41He’ll enter the Glorious Land, and many countries will fall, but Edom, Moab, and most of Ammon will escape. 42Then he’ll attack still other countries, including Egypt. 43He’ll gain control of Egypt’s precious treasures, its gold and silver, Libyans and Nubians will become his subjects. 44But alarming news will come from the east and north, and he’ll go out with great fury to exterminate many. 45He’ll pitch his royal pavilion between the sea and the beautiful Holy Mountain. Yet he’ll come to his end, and nobody will help him.   	Dan 11:40-45

The Time of the End

12:1“At that time, Michael, the great prince that guards your people, will rise up. There’ll be a distressful time like nothing since nations began. Everyone among your people who are written in the scroll will be rescued. 2Many asleep in their graves will wake up, some to eternal life, some to disgrace and eternal contempt. 3The wise will shine as bright as the sky, including those who lead many to goodness—like the stars forever. 4Close up this message, Daniel, and seal the scroll till the time of the end. People will travel everywhere and spread knowledge.”	Dan 12:1-4

5Then I saw two others standing on opposite banks of the river. 6One asked the man dressed in linen, who was above the river, “How long will it be till those distressful events end?” 7The man raised his hands toward the sky and swore by the One that lives forever that it would be for a time, times, and half a time. And as soon as they finish shattering the power of the holy people, those things will come to an end. 8I heard it, but I couldn’t understand it. So I asked, “How will those things end up?”               	Dan 12:5-8

9He said,

“Go on with your life, Daniel. Those things are secret, sealed up till the time of the end. 10Many will purify themselves, make themselves white, and be refined. The wicked won’t understand, but the wise will. 11There will be 1,290 days between the time the daily sacrifice stops and the abomination that makes desolate is set up. 12How fortunate they are who persevere to the end of the 1,335 days! 13Live out the rest of your life. You’ll enter into rest and rise again for your reward at the end of the age.”	 Dan 12:9-13

HOSEA

1:1Messages from the LORD to Hosea Son of Beeri

at the Time of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, Kings of Judah,

and Jeroboam Son of Joash/Jehoash, King of Israel

Hosea’s Wife and Children

2When the LORD spoke the first time through Hosea, he said, “Marry a prostitute and have children, because the land is committing flagrant prostitution by abandoning me.” 3So he married Gomer daughter of Diblaim, and she had a son. 4The LORD said,

“Name him Jezreel. Soon I’ll punish Jehu’s dynasty for the bloodshed in Jezreel, and put an end to Israel. 5At that time, I’ll break Israel’s military strength in the Valley of ‘Jezreel.’”	Hos 1:1-5

6Then she had a daughter. The LORD told him,

“Name her Lo-ruhamah. I ‘won’t have mercy’ any more on Israel by forgiving them. 7But I will have mercy on Judah and deliver them, but not by bow, sword, battle, horses, or horsemen.”

8When she’d weaned Lo-ruhamah, she had another son. 9The LORD said, “Name him Lo-ammi. You’re ‘not my people,’ and I’m not your God.

Israel’s Unfaithfulness Punished

12I’ll destroy her grapevines and fig trees

Hosea’s Wife Redeemed

3:1Then the LORD told me, “Go love your wife again even though she’s an adulteress—like I love Israel though it turns to other gods and loves raisin cakes.” 2So I bought her for 6 oz 15 shekels of silver and 5 bushels a lethek of barley. 3I told her, “You’ll have to stay with me a long time. He found him at Bethel

5Yahveh God of Hosts,

Yahveh is his name. 		Hos 12:1-5

6So come back to your God,

observe kindness and justice;

7But he’s become a shrewd businessman with false balances,

8Ephraim has said, “I got rich;

I made myself wealthy.

Nobody caught me being dishonest;

that would have made it illegal!”

9“I’ve been Yahveh your God since Egypt;

I’ll make you live in tents again

as at the Festival of Booths.

10I’ve spoken to the prophets

and given them lots of visions;

I’ve delivered parables through them.”			Hos 12:6-10

11But there’s sinfulness in Gilead,

worthless people.

They sacrifice bulls in Gilgal too;

their altars are like rock piles

along a plowed field.

12Jacob fled to the land of Aram

and kept sheep to get a wife.

13Then Yahveh brought his descendants

out of Egypt by a prophet

14But they’ve made Yahveh bitterly angry;

so he’s sentenced them to death

in payment for their disgrace.		Hos 12:11-14

The LORD’s Anger at Israel

13:1When Ephraim spoke, people cringed;

2Now his people sin more and more

They say, “Sacrifice to them,

3So they’ll be like morning mist,

like chaff blown from a threshing floor,

like smoke from a chimney.		Hos 13:1-3

4“Yet I’ve been Yahveh your God since Egypt;

you weren’t to know any God but me

5I took care of you in the desert,

in a land of drought.

6But when you got to pasture,

fed to the full and satisfied,

7So I’ll be like a lion to you

8I’ll attack you like a bear robbed of her cubs

and tear your chests open.

I’ll devour you like a lioness

and maul you like a wild animal.		Hos 13:4-8

9“It’s to your destruction, Israel,

that you’re against me, your help.

10Where’s your king

that’s going to save you in all your towns?

Where are the officials you requested,

‘Give me a king and officials’?

11I gave you a king in my anger

and took him away in my wrath.

12“The iniquity of Ephraim has been collected

and stored up for retribution.

13The pains of childbirth have come on him;

he’s not a very smart son;

it’s too late to keep from being born. 			Hos 13:9-13

14“Should I ransom him from Sheol?

Should I redeem him from death?

No, I won’t show him mercy; so

Death, where are your thorns?

Death, where is your sting?

Bring it.

15Though he’s flourishing like a reed,

an east wind will come—

Yahveh’s wind from the desert—

and dry up his fountain;

his spring will go dry.

It will ‘blow away’ every precious article in his treasury.

16Samaria will bear the consequences of his guilt

because he rebelled against his God:

his residents will fall by the sword;

his little ones will be dashed to pieces;

Healing for the Repentant

14:1Israel, come back to the LORD your God;

you’ve stumbled because you sinned.

2Come back to the LORD

and bring your confession with you.

Say, “Take away our sin;

receive us graciously

so we can offer our praises to you.

3Assyria can’t save us;

neither can our warhorses.

We won’t say ‘our god’ anymore

to something we’ve made;

only from you can we orphans receive mercy.” 		Hos 14:1-3

4The LORD says,

“I’ll heal your apostasy

and love you freely

because my anger will be gone.

5I’ll be like dew to you;

you’ll blossom like a lily.

6Your roots will spread out like the cedars in Lebanon.

7Your people that live in your shade,

will raise grain again,

and blossom like grapevines.

You’ll be as fragrant as Lebanon’s wine.		Hos 14:4-7

8“Ephraim, I don’t have any connection with idols.

I directly am the One that answers your prayers

and takes care of you.

I’m like a green cypress;

your fruit all comes from me.”

9Whoever is wise, understand—

whoever perceives, be aware:

the Lord’s way is the right way;

good people follow it,

but sinners trip over it.		Hos 14:8-9

JOEL

1:1A Message from the LORD to Joel Son of Pethuel

Mourning over a Locust Invasion

2Listen to this, elders;

pay attention, everybody in the land.

Has anything like this ever happened in your lifetime

or your ancestors’ lifetime?

3Tell your descendants about it;

they need to tell their descendants, and so on.

Joel 1:1-3

4What the cutting locusts left

the swarming locusts have eaten.

What the swarming locusts left

the hopping locusts have eaten.

What the hopping locusts left

the stripping locusts have eaten.

5Wake up, you drunks, and cry;

wail, wine drinkers,

for the sweet wine you can’t find anymore.

6A nation has invaded my land,

powerful and without number.

Its teeth are like a lion’s teeth;

it has fangs like a lioness.

7It’s destroyed my grapevines

and ruined my fig trees.

It’s stripped off their bark and thrown it away,

so their branches are bare and white.	Joel 1:4-7

8Wail like a virgin wearing burlap

for her young groom.

9The grain offerings and liquid offerings have stopped

in the LORD’s Temple.

The priests, the LORD’s ministers, mourn.

10The fields are ruined, the land is bare

because the grain has been destroyed,

the new wine has dried up,

the fresh oil has failed.

11Despair, farmers; wail, vinedressers,

for the wheat and barley;

the harvest is ruined.

12The grapevines have shriveled up, the fig trees have withered;

the pomegranate, palm, and apple trees as well.

The fruit trees in the orchard have dried up,

the joy among the people too. 	Joel 1:8-12

A Call to Repentance

13Put on burlap and chant a dirge, priests;

wail, ministers at the altar!

Come, spend the night in burlap, ministers of God,

because the grain offerings and liquid offerings

have stopped in his Temple.

14Consecrate a fast, declare a solemn assembly;

gather the elders and the people to the LORD’s Temple,

and cry out to him.

15Dread the day!

The day of the LORD is upon us,

a day of destruction that’s coming from the Almighty.

16Hasn’t food disappeared in front of us,

and happiness left the Temple?

17Seeds shrivel under the clods;

barns stand empty;

granaries are abandoned

because the crops have failed.	Joel 1:13-17

18The cattle are bawling!

Herds are wandering aimlessly

because there’s no pasture;

flocks of sheep are bleating in misery.

19I’m calling out to you, LORD,

because fire has burned off the open range;

flames have burned up the trees in the fields.

20Even the wild animals pant for you

because the streams have dried up

and fire has scorched the pastures.  		Joel 1:18-20

The Day of the LORD

2:1Blow a bugle in Zion;

sound an alarm on my holy mountain!

Let the people in the land tremble

because the day of the LORD is coming.

It’s near,

2a dark and gloomy day,

a cloudy day with deep blackness.

A numerous, powerful army is spreading out

like shadows in the mountains.

There’s never been anything like them before,

and there won’t be for ages to come.

3Fire consumes ahead of them;

flames burn behind them.

The land is like the Orchard of Eden in front of them,

but desolation lies behind them;

nothing escapes.

4They look like horses;

they run like steeds.

5With rumbling like chariots,

they leap along on the hilltops—

like a crackling flame consuming stubble,

like a powerful army in battle formation.	Joel 2:1-5

6Defenders are in anguish in front of them

with faces turned pale.

7They run like warriors

and scale walls like soldiers;

they march in line

without breaking rank.

8They don’t bump into one another;

each one marches straight ahead.

When they break through the defenses,

they just keep going.

9They rush at the city and

run along its walls;

they climb into houses

through windows like thieves.

10 The ground quakes in front of them,

the sky shakes,

the sun and moon go out,

the stars grow dim.	Joel 2:6-10

11The LORD raises his voice in front of his army;

his camp is large

because he’s strong that carries out his word.

The day of the LORD is terrifying;

who can survive it?

A Call to Repentance

12“Yet even now,” the LORD says,

“come back to me with all your heart,

with fasting, tears, and mourning.

13Tear you hearts, not your clothes.”

Come back to him;

he’s gracious and merciful,

slow to get angry, full of enduring love,

and relents from carrying out destruction.

14Who knows if he’ll relent

and leave behind a blessing for you,

the possibility of offering again

a grain offering and a liquid offering

for the LORD your God.	Joel 2:11-14

15Blow a bugle in Zion,

consecrate a fast,

declare a solemn assembly,

16bring the people together,

sanctify the community,

assemble the elders,

gather the children and nursing infants.

Have the groom come out of his room

and the bride leave her quarters.

17Let the priests, the LORD’s ministers,

weep between the porch and altar.

Let them say, “Spare your people, LORD.

Don’t make your permanent possession a disgrace,

a byword the world over.

Why should they say,

‘Where’s their God?’”	Joel 2:15-17

The Lord Promises Restoration

18Then the LORD will become zealous for his land

and take pity on his people.

19He’ll answer them,

“I’m going to send you grain, new wine, and olive oil;

you’ll be satisfied.

I’ll never again make you a byword the world over.

20I’ll remove the northern threat far from you

and drive him into a parched, desolate land.

I’ll drive his vanguard into the Dead Sea,

his rear guard into the Mediterranean.

The stench from rotting bodies will rise over the land.”

The Lord has done great things! 	Joel 2:18-20

21Don’t be afraid, O land; celebrate and be happy

because the LORD has done great things.

22Don’t be afraid, animals in the field,

because the pastures in the countryside have turned green.

The trees have borne their fruit;

the fig tree and vine have given their full yield.

23So celebrate, people of Zion;

be happy in the LORD your God

because he’s given you the autumn rains to vindicate you.

He has poured down rain for you,

the autumn and spring rains like before.

24The threshing floor will be full of grain;

the vats will overflow with new wine and olive oil.

25 “Then I’ll make up to you for the years

the swarming locusts, crawling locusts,

stripping locusts, and cutting locusts have eaten—

the enormous army I sent at you.

26You’ll have plenty to eat;

praise the LORD your God,

who has dealt with you amazingly;

then you’ll never be disgraced.

27That’s how you’ll know I’m in the land,

that I’m the LORD your God,

and there’s no other.	Joel 2:21-27

The LORD Promises His Spirit

28“After that, I’ll pour out my Spirit on all kinds of people:

sons and daughters will prophesy,

old men will dream dreams,

young men will see visions.

29I’ll even pour out my Spirit

on male and female servants.

30I’ll display wonders in the sky and on the earth:

blood, fire, and columns of smoke.

31The sun will turn dark, and the moon will turn red

before that great, notable day of the LORD.”

32At that time, he’ll save whoever calls on him.

On Mount Zion and in Jerusalem

people will escape like the LORD said;

among the survivors will be the people the LORD calls.

Joel 2:28-32

Judgment Against Enemy Nations

3:1“When I restore the fortunes of Judah and Jerusalem, 2I’ll gather the nations to the Valley of Jehoshaphat and condemn them there on behalf of Israel, my permanent possession, my people. They scattered them among the nations, divided up my land, 3cast lots for my people, traded a boy for a prostitute, and sold a girl for wine to get drunk on.

4“What are you to me, Tyre, Sidon, Philistia? You think you’re going to pay me back? If you try, I’ll return it on your head swift and soon. 5You’ve stolen my silver and gold, taken my precious treasures into your temples, 6and sold Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks to remove them far away. 7So I’m going to raise them up from where you sold them and pay you back on your own head. 8I’ll sell your sons and daughters to Judah to sell to the Sabeans far away.

I, the LORD, have spoken.”	Joel 3:1-8

9Declare this among the nations:

“Prepare for war; rouse the powerful;

let the fighting men advance and engage.

10Beat your plowshares into swords,

your pruning hooks into spears;

have even the weak say, ‘I’m a soldier now.’

11Come quickly, nations everywhere;

gather there.”

LORD, bring out your soldiers!

12“Let the nations muster to the Valley of Jehoshaphat;

that’s where I’ll pronounce judgment on them all.	 Joel 3:9-12

13Use the sickle; the harvest is ripe.

Come and tread; the winepress is full;

the vats are overflowing with those people’s sinfulness.”

14Thousands upon thousands in the valley of decision!

The day of the LORD is near in the valley of decision!

15The sun and moon will grow dark;

the stars will quit shining.

16The LORD will roar out of Zion;

he’ll thunder from Jerusalem.

Earth and sky will reverberate;

the LORD will be his people’s refuge,

a strong fortress for the sons of Israel.

17Then you’ll know I’m the LORD your God,

who lives on Zion, my holy mountain.

So Jerusalem will be holy;

foreigners will never overrun it again.	Joel 3:13-17

Blessings for God’s People

18“At that time, the mountains will drip with sweet wine;

the hills will flow with milk.

Water will run down the wadis in Judah;

a spring will gush out of the LORD’s Temple

and water the Valley of Shittim.

19Egypt will be a wasteland

and Edom a desert

because of their violence against Judah

and the murder of its innocent people.

20But people will live in Judah forever,

in Jerusalem for all generations.

21I’ll avenge their blood that I haven’t already avenged

and make my home with them in Zion.”	Joel 3:18-21

AMOS

1:1The Message of Amos, Shepherd from Tekoa, That He Saw

at the Time of Uzziah, King of Judah, and Jeroboam Son of Joash, King of Israel,

Two Years Before the Earthquake

2He said,

“The LORD will roar from Zion;

he’ll thunder from Jerusalem.

The shepherds’ pastures will dry up;

the grass on Carmel’s summit will wither away.”

God’s Judgment on Israel’s Neighbors

3The LORD says,

“For three sins of Damascus and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:e said, He said

they threshed the people of Gilead

with sledges that had iron teeth.

4So I’ll send down fire on the house of Hazael,

consume the fortresses of Benhadad,

5break the bars on the gates of Damascus,

eliminate the people in the Valley of Aven

and the one that holds the scepter from Beth-eden.

The people of Syria will go to Kir in exile.” 	Amos 1:1-5

6The LORD says,

“For three sins of Gaza and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they deported an entire population to Edom.

7So I’ll send down fire on the walls of Gaza

and consume its fortresses.

8I’ll eliminate the people from Ashdod

and the one that holds the scepter in Ashkelon.

I’ll unleash my power on Ekron,

And the remnant of Philistines will perish.” 	Amos 1:6-8

9The LORD says,

“For three sins of Tyre and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they delivered an entire population to Edom

and broke the treaty between kin.

10So I’ll send down fire on the walls of Tyre

and burn its fortresses.”	Amos 1:9-10

11The LORD says,

“For three sins of Edom and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they pursued their brothers with a sword

In their anger they slashed them again and again;

12So I’ll send down fire on Teman

and burn the fortresses in Bozrah.”	Amos 1:11-12

13The LORD says,

“For three sins of the Ammonites and for four,

I won’t hold back their punishment:

they ripped open pregnant women in Gilead

14So I’ll kindle a fire on the walls of Rabbah

15Their king will go into exile with his officials.” 	Amos 1:13-15

2:1The LORD says,

“For three sins of Moab and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they burned the king of Edom’s bones into lime.

2So I’ll burn the fortresses in Kerioth;

Moab will die amid turmoil,

war cries, and bugle blasts.

3I’ll eliminate judges from him

and slay his officials with him.” 	Amos 2:1-3

God’s Judgment on Judah and Israel

4The LORD says,

“For three sins of Judah and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

he rejected the Law of the LORD

and didn’t keep his statutes.

The same lies have led them astray

that their ancestors followed.

5So I’ll send down fire on Judah

and burn the fortresses in Jerusalem.”	Amos 2:4-5

6The LORD says,

“For three sins of Israel and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they sell the good for money,

the poor for a pair of shoes.

7They walk on the heads of the poor in the dust

and abandon those who are suffering.

A man and his father sleep with the same girl

to profane my holy name.

8They lie down beside every altar

In God’s Temple they drink the wine

of the people they’ve fined.				Amos 2:6-8

9“Yet I was the One that destroyed the Amorites for you,

though they were as tall as cedars and strong as oaks.

I destroyed their fruit above and their roots below.

10I was the One that brought you up from Egypt,

and led you in the desert for 40 years

to take over the land of the Amorites.

11Then I raised up some of your offspring to be prophets

and some of your young men to be Nazirites.

Isn’t that so, Israel? 	Amos 2:9-11

12“But you made Nazirites drink wine

and told prophets not to prophesy!

13I’ll weigh you down like a wagon

overloaded with bundles,

14The swift won’t be able to flee;

the strong will lose their strength;

the powerful won’t save their lives.

15The archers won’t stand their ground;

the swift won’t escape;

the cavalry won’t save themselves.

16The bravest among the troops

will drop their weapons and run

when that time comes.” 	Amos 2:12-16

Witnesses Summoned Against Israel

3:1Listen to what the LORD says against you, Israel, against the entire family he brought out of Egypt:

2“Of all the families in the world, only you have me;

so I’ll punish you for your sins.

3Can two men walk together unless they’ve agreed on their route?

4Does a lion roar in the woods before it’s made a kill?

Does a young lion growl in his den unless he’s taken something?

5Does a bird fall into a trap on the ground if there’s no bait in it?

Does a trap snap shut if nothing trips it?

6If a bugle blows in the city, won’t the people be afraid?

If a catastrophe falls on a city, hasn’t the LORD planned it?

7For certain the LORD God doesn’t do anything

without revealing his secret counsel to his prophets.

8A lion has roared! Who’s not afraid?

The Lord GOD has spoken! Who can refuse to prophesy?”

Amos 3:1-8

9Declare on the fortresses in Ashdod and Egypt:

“Gather in the mountains around Samaria and watch the great turmoil and oppression in it. 10They don’t know how to do what’s right; they store up violence and devastation in their fortresses.”

11So the Lord GOD says,

“An enemy will surround the land,

pull down your fortresses,

and loot your strongholds.

12Like a shepherd snatches from a lion’s mouth

a couple legs or part of an ear,

so I’ll deliver the Israelites living in Samaria

like the corner of a couch and the cover on a bed.

13Listen and testify against Jacob’s house.

14When I punish Israel’s sins, I’ll punish Bethel’s altars too.

I’ll cut off the horns of the altar, and they’ll fall on the ground.

15I’ll strike their winter palaces and summer homes;

stately residences full of ivory will perish;

their mansions will meet their end.” 	Amos 3:9-15

Israel Does Not Learn

4:1Listen to this, you cows of Bashan living in Samaria,

that tell their husbands, “Bring the wine so we can get drunk!”

2The Lord GOD has sworn by his holiness,

“The time’s coming when they’ll take you away with meat hooks,

the last of you like fish on hooks.

3You’ll leave through the breaches in the walls,

each one straight ahead.

You’ll be thrown out into Harmon/Mt. Hermon.”	Amos 4:1-3

4“Go sacrifice at Bethel and sin;

multiply your disobedience in Gilgal!

Bring your sacrifices every morning,

your tithes every three days.

5Offer a thank offering with yeast in it;

declare freewill offerings and brag about it.

That’s what you like to do, you people in Israel.

6“I brought hunger to all your towns,

clean teeth everywhere you live;

yet you haven’t come back to me. 	Amos 4:4-6

7“I kept it from raining

Then I’d let it rain on one city

and not on another.

One place would get rain;

the place that didn’t, would dry up.

8So two or three towns would stagger to another to get a drink,

but they wouldn’t get enough;

yet you haven’t come back to me.

9“I struck you with blight and mildew,

and laid waste your orchards and vineyards.

The locusts ate your fig trees and olives;

yet you haven’t come back to me.” 	Amos 4:7-9

10“I sent a plague among you like I did in Egypt;

I killed your young men with the sword

along with your captured horses.

I made the stench in your camp fill your nostrils;

yet you haven’t come back to me.

11“I overthrew you like I overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah;

your survivors were like charred stakes snatched from the fire;

yet you haven’t come back to me. 	Amos 4:10-11

12“Because I’m going to do this to you, Israel,

prepare to meet your God.”

13The One that builds mountains and creates wind,

reveals to people what he’s thinking,

the One that turns dawn into darkness

and walks on mountaintops—

the LORD God of Hosts.	Amos 4:12-13

A Call to Repentance

5:1Listen to the dirge I’m chanting for you, Israel:

2“She’s fallen;

virgin Israel won’t get up again.

She’s abandoned on the ground;

no one will help get her up.

3The city that goes out 1,000 strong

will have 100 left;

the one that goes out 100 strong

will have 10.”	Amos 5:1-3

4The LORD tells Israel,

“Rely on me so you can live.

5Don’t rely on Bethel or go to Gilgal or Beersheba;

Gilgal is headed for captivity,

and Bethel will cease to exist.

6Rely on me so you can live,

so I don’t break out like fire, House of Joseph,

and burn in Bethel with no one to quench it,

7you that pervert justice into bitter oppression

and toss goodness on the ground.” 	Amos 5:4-7

8The LORD is the One that made Pleiades and Orion,

that changes deep darkness into morning

and darkens day into night,

that calls water out of the ocean

and pours it out on land.

9He’s the One that flashes destruction at the strong

and demolishes their fortresses.	Amos 5:8-9

10They hate the one that reproves in court;

11So, since you impose heavy rent on the poor

and exact tribute on their grain,

though you build houses out of well-hewn stone,

you won’t live in them;

though you plant lush vineyards,

you won’t drink their wine.

12I know about your many, serious sins,

you that distress decent people, accept bribes,

and deprive the poor of justice in court.

13In such cases, prudent people keep quiet

because it’s an evil time.	Amos 5:10-13

14Do what’s good so you can live,

so the LORD God of Hosts will be with you

like you said.

15Hate evil, love good;

establish justice in court!

Maybe the LORD God of Hosts

will show grace to the remnant in Joseph.	Amos 5:14-15

16So, the LORD God of Hosts says,

“What wailing there is in all the squares!

17In all the vineyards there’ll be wailing

because I’ll pass through your midst.”	Amos 5:16-17

The Day of the LORD

18What longing you have for the day of the LORD!

But what good will it do you?

That day will be darkness for you, not light.

19It will be like a man that runs from a lion

and meets a bear;

or goes home, leans his hand on the wall,

and gets bit by a snake.

20Won’t the day of the LORD be darkness instead of light,

gloom without brightness?	Amos 5:18-20

21“I despise your festivals;

I don’t delight in your solemn assemblies.

22Though you offer me burnt offerings and grain offerings,

I won’t accept them.

I won’t even look at your peace offerings of grain-fed animals.

23Take away your noisy songs;

and goodness like a constant-flowing stream.	Amos 5:21-24

25“Did you bring me sacrifices and grain offerings in the desert for 40 years, Israel? 26Well, you also carried along Sakkuth your king god and Kaiwan your star god, images you made for yourselves. 27So I’ll send you into exile beyond Damascus,” the LORD says, whose name is The God of Hosts.

Amos 5:25-27

Woe to the Complacent

6:1“Misfortune awaits those of you at ease in Zion,

who feel secure in Samaria,

2Go over to Calneh and look at what happened there;

Are you better than those kingdoms?

3Are you trying to push away the time of catastrophe?

You’re only bringing the violence nearer.	Amos 6:1-3

4“Misfortune awaits you that stretch out on ivory beds,

and calves from the stall,

5that sing idle songs to the sound of a lyre
